Yoits [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: minnesota_bound ...1/3rd of Hollywood jobs have disappeared. 48,000 gone. Most I suspect due to the terrible scold movies and tv shows they make but AI is replacing background players and set design builders etc. Some of that is due to the industry shift away from Hollywood. The Arri Alexa digital movie camera was released in 2010. Since then, movie producers had a more plentiful, less expensive, and better filming options than Hollywood could offer. The James Bond movie "Skyfall" (2012) was filmed using Alexa digital cameras and won the Academy Award for Best Cinematography. Add in Computer Generated Imagery and regular television shows can be filmed against a blue screen (or green screen), cutting back on set construction by instead using digital backgrounds created by lower cost overseas video editors. 20 posted on 11/04/2025 5:15:39 AM PST by T.B. Yoits [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 9 | View Replies] Navigation: use the links below to view more comments. first 1-20, 21-22 next last Disclaimer: Opinions posted on Free Republic are those of the individual posters and do not necessarily represent the opinion of Free Republic or its management. All materials posted herein are protected by copyright law and the exemption for fair use of copyrighted works. Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search General/Chat Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson UPS, meanwhile, revealed that it had cut 34,000 operational jobs during the first nine months of this year‚Äîa significantly larger reduction than the 20,000 layoffs announced in April‚Äîas part of its ‚Äúefficiency reimagined‚Äù initiative.Nestl√© said on Oct. 16 that it will reduce 16,000 jobs worldwide over the next two years in an effort to achieve ‚Äúoperational efficiency‚Äù by ‚Äúleveraging shared services and automating [its] processes.‚ÄùIn August, Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff disclosed on an podcast that the company had replaced about 4,000 customer support workers with AI agents.In the past, businesses typically downsized during economic downturns, but these recent staff reductions occurred during a period of robust profitability, signaling something different‚Äîa transformation in the way work itself is organized, driven by the rapid diffusion of AI.Unlike past automation waves that mimicked the functions of the human body‚Äîreplacing manual or routine tasks‚ÄîAI targets the human brain‚Äôs cognitive abilities. It doesn‚Äôt just perform repetitive processes; it learns, analyzes, and makes decisions.Together, these twin shifts‚Äîmanual automation and cognitive automation‚Äîare remaking both unskilled and skilled labor. The result: some jobs are being transformed, others are being cut.In a statement included in its job cut announcement, the company explained that AI‚Äôs transformative force requires new organizational structures: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs enabling companies to innovate much faster than ever before ... We‚Äôre convinced that we need to be organized more leanly, with fewer layers and more ownership, to move as quickly as possible for our customers and business.‚ÄùHowever, Amazon CEO Andy Jassy said during the company‚Äôs Oct. 30 earnings call that the recent layoff announcement was not ‚Äúreally AI-driven, not right now, at least.‚ÄùAI Diffusion Across the WorkforceEconomists, central banks, and think tanks have documented AI‚Äôs rapid spread across workplaces.A report by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis found that by early 2023, generative AI‚Äîthe class of AI capable of creating new content‚Äîhad become widespread across the American workforce. Tools such as ChatGPT were embedded in browsers, office software, and search engines, making large language model usage routine for millions of workers.The bank found that occupations adopting generative AI most intensively‚Äîparticularly computer and mathematical fields‚Äîexperienced the steepest unemployment gains.‚ÄúOur results suggest we may be witnessing the early stages of AI-driven job displacement,‚Äù the report noted. ‚ÄúUnlike previous technological revolutions that primarily affected manufacturing or routine clerical work, generative AI can target cognitive tasks performed by knowledge workers‚Äîtraditionally among the most secure employment categories.‚ÄùA Brookings Institution report estimates that 30 percent of all U.S. workers could see at least half of their job tasks disrupted by generative AI. Unlike earlier automation, which primarily affected blue-collar work, AI is expected to reshape a broad range of ‚Äúcognitive‚Äù and ‚Äúnonroutine‚Äù occupations‚Äîespecially those in middle- and high-income professions.Similarly, the McKinsey Global Institute has projected that automation (a combination of AI and robotics) could displace up to 54 million workers in the United States by 2030.Meanwhile, a Goldman Sachs analysis projects that widespread AI adoption could displace 6 to 7 percent of the U.S. workforce, equivalent to millions of jobs.Goldman Sachs economists estimate that temporary unemployment spikes by roughly 0.3 percentage points for each percentage-point gain in productivity from labor-saving technology.Jobs Most at RiskA Society for Human Resource Management study, published on April 25, offers a detailed snapshot of U.S. employment exposure to AI.According to the report, 12.6 percent of jobs‚Äîapproximately 19.2 million positions‚Äîface a high or very high risk of automation-related displacement. Among them, 14 percent of blue-collar jobs, 12.3 percent of white-collar jobs, and 12.1 percent of service-sector jobs are considered at high risk.Meanwhile, a June 9 report from the freelance work platform Upwork identifies 120 jobs that are hard to be replaced by AI, including clinical, creative, and skilled trades roles.AI and Changing Nature of SkillsA December 2024 Harvard Business School paper shows that AI has a mixed impact on businesses‚Äô labor demand.In automation-prone roles, AI reduces the need for specialized expertise by simplifying complex tasks. In augmentation-prone roles, however, it boosts productivity and increases demand for advanced, complementary skill sets.‚ÄúAs generative AI continues to evolve, understanding its heterogeneous effects on labor demand is critical,‚Äù the authors wrote. ‚ÄúPolicymakers and business practitioners must recognize the dual forces of automation and augmentation to ensure that workers are equipped to adapt and thrive.‚ÄùAt the same time, research by Nobel laureate Daron Acemoglu and colleagues‚Äîpublished in the Journal of Labor Economics‚Äîshows that as establishments adopt AI, they reduce hiring in non-AI positions and shift skill requirements across remaining roles.Andy Zenkevich, founder and CEO of Epiic, a digital agency specializing in generative engine optimization (GEO), told The Epoch Times that the fear of mass AI-driven job losses is overstated.‚ÄúAmong the companies we work with in digital marketing‚Äîincluding major tech firms‚Äîlayoffs haven‚Äôt been the story,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúInstead, jobs are morphing. A junior copywriter becomes an ‚ÄòAI content editor,‚Äô responsible for prompt engineering, fact-checking, and editing AI-generated copy.‚ÄùZenkevich estimated that roughly 2.5 percent of jobs are genuinely at risk under a full-scale AI rollout, noting that ‚Äútrue end-to-end automation is much harder than headlines suggest.‚Äù‚ÄúOver a third of jobs now require hybrid skill sets that combine technical literacy with human qualities machines can‚Äôt replicate,‚Äù he said.Georgios Koimisis, associate professor of finance at Manhattan University, echoed a similar skepticism.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a growing fear that artificial intelligence is wiping out jobs, but the reality is more complex,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúCompanies aren‚Äôt cutting workers simply because AI made them redundant. In an uncertain economy, firms want to appear modern and future-ready. Announcing an ‚ÄòAI transformation‚Äô reassures investors that management has a plan.‚ÄùKoimisis argues that some layoffs, framed as part of AI restructuring, are more about signaling discipline to shareholders than about reflecting genuine technological necessity.‚ÄúAI is changing not just how work is organized, but how value itself is defined,‚Äù he said.Izhar Haq, director of the School of Professional Accountancy at Long Island University, agrees that the slowing economy and business cycle are also contributing factors to recent job reductions.Haq told The Epoch Times that while the long-term economic effects of AI remain uncertain, ‚Äúwhite-collar analytical jobs are most at risk from AI integration, while manual labor jobs face risk from robotics.‚Äù TOPICS: Business/Economy; Computers/Internet; Society KEYWORDS: ai; jobs; unemployment Click here: to donate by Credit Card Or here: to donate by PayPal Or by mail to: Free Republic, LLC - PO Box 9771 - Fresno, CA 93794 Thank you very much and God bless you. Tens of thousands of layoffs have been announced across major sectors in late October 2025, with UPS, Amazon, Intel and Nestl√© leading the cuts. Over 112,000 tech jobs alone have been eliminated this year, and broader corporate downsizing is accelerating. Just during October alone, UPS announced 48,000 job cuts, Amazon 14,000, Intel 24,000, Nestle 16,000, Accenture 11,000, Novo Nordisk 9,000, Applied Materials 1,444, Target 1,000, Charter Telecom 1,200 and CBS/Paramount 1,000. These are notable corporations cutting staff, but other major companies like JPMorgan Chase have implemented a hiring freeze across multiple divisions in late 2025, driven by its aggressive deployment of artificial intelligence and cost discipline. Tens of thousands of layoffs have been announced across major sectors in late October 2025, with UPS, Amazon, Intel and Nestl√© leading the cuts. Over 112,000 tech jobs alone have been eliminated this year, and broader corporate downsizing is accelerating. Just during October alone, UPS announced 48,000 job cuts, Amazon 14,000, Intel 24,000, Nestle 16,000, Accenture 11,000, Novo Nordisk 9,000, Applied Materials 1,444, Target 1,000, Charter Telecom 1,200 and CBS/Paramount 1,000. These are notable corporations cutting staff, but other major companies like JPMorgan Chase have implemented a hiring freeze across multiple divisions in late 2025, driven by its aggressive deployment of artificial intelligence and cost discipline. Managers have been instructed to avoid hiring unless absolutely necessary. 5 posted on 11/03/2025 9:02:54 PM PST by SeekAndFind [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 3 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind All of this screams to me, ‚ÄúWork for yourself!‚Äù 6 posted on 11/03/2025 9:28:31 PM PST by SaxxonWoods (Annnd....TRUMP IS RIGHT AGAIN.) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind wanna keep your business going? Have a human answering the phone instead of a computer. I threw contracts to providers simply because a human answered the phone. All it takes is one trip through ‚Äúautomated phone hell‚Äù to make up the price difference for parts. 7 posted on 11/03/2025 9:50:48 PM PST by dagunk [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind customer support In the old days of touchtone phones, I would just press 0 to find a human. An online AI chat is very common these days. Instead of 0, I type in HUMAN. Sometimes it takes typing human 2 or 3 times. I have also run into AI while using the telephone customer service. No matter what the "choices" from the AI are, I just repeat HUMAN until they transfer to a living, breathing person. PS - I wonder if some young entrepreneur will develop an AI customer service with a thick East Indian accent. 8 posted on 11/03/2025 10:40:21 PM PST by Ronaldus Magnus III (Do, or do not, there is no try ) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind I recently read that 1/3rd of hollywood jobs have disappeared. 48,000 gone. Fixing problems created by bad management and using AI to identify better ways of running operations and eliminating inefficiencies, waste, and useless jobs.Here's an example of what Palantir is doing with its clients using AI: Swiss Re: After installing Palantir's software, they cut reporting time by up to 80%, freed about 30% of underwriters‚Äô time, boosted data-team output by 50%, and earned back the entire cost of the system in 7 months, ending with a 170% return (independently audited). Airbus: Used Palantir to improve assembly of the A350 by about 30%‚Äîfewer delays, fewer mistakes, and more planes finished each month using the same factories and workers. BP: Runs virtual ‚Äúdigital twins‚Äù of oil platforms and fields so engineers can spot problems early, prevent breakdowns, and make better decisions before something goes wrong. National power company (unnamed): Used Palantir to map 10,000+ miles of power lines and find weak spots before they fail. These aren‚Äôt future promises‚Äîthey‚Äôre real improvements in speed, cost, reliability, and output. This is what applied AI actually looks like in the real world.Stronger companies create real jobs. 15 posted on 11/04/2025 2:18:15 AM PST by RoosterRedux (‚ÄúCritical thinking is hard; that‚Äôs why most people just jump to conclusions.‚Äù‚ÄîJung (paraphrased)) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 12 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind If you‚Äôre a low level coder, your days are numbered. If you‚Äôre a designer/engineer, AI is making your life easier as you don‚Äôt have to farm the work out to the aforementioned. If you‚Äôre a data analyst or financial manager, you are already prompting AI to build the queries to pull your data and create your decks. If not, you‚Äôve probably missed the boat. 16 posted on 11/04/2025 2:19:44 AM PST by Sirius Lee ("Never argue with a fool, onlookers may not be able to tell the difference.‚Äù) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 5 | View Replies] To: dpetty121263 ‚ÄúGuess there is always starvation...can‚Äôt work so no eats.‚Äù There‚Äôs ALWAYS electrical work... and Electrical Workers hold the key to shutting AI off. Yoits [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: minnesota_bound ...1/3rd of Hollywood jobs have disappeared. 48,000 gone. Most I suspect due to the terrible scold movies and tv shows they make but AI is replacing background players and set design builders etc. Some of that is due to the industry shift away from Hollywood. The Arri Alexa digital movie camera was released in 2010. Since then, movie producers had a more plentiful, less expensive, and better filming options than Hollywood could offer. The James Bond movie "Skyfall" (2012) was filmed using Alexa digital cameras and won the Academy Award for Best Cinematography. Add in Computer Generated Imagery and regular television shows can be filmed against a blue screen (or green screen), cutting back on set construction by instead using digital backgrounds created by lower cost overseas video editors. 20 posted on 11/04/2025 5:15:39 AM PST by T.B. Yoits [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 9 | View Replies] Navigation: use the links below to view more comments. first 1-20, 21-22 next last Disclaimer: Opinions posted on Free Republic are those of the individual posters and do not necessarily represent the opinion of Free Republic or its management. All materials posted herein are protected by copyright law and the exemption for fair use of copyrighted works. Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search General/Chat Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson In August, Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff disclosed on an podcast that the company had replaced about 4,000 customer support workers with AI agents.In the past, businesses typically downsized during economic downturns, but these recent staff reductions occurred during a period of robust profitability, signaling something different‚Äîa transformation in the way work itself is organized, driven by the rapid diffusion of AI.Unlike past automation waves that mimicked the functions of the human body‚Äîreplacing manual or routine tasks‚ÄîAI targets the human brain‚Äôs cognitive abilities. It doesn‚Äôt just perform repetitive processes; it learns, analyzes, and makes decisions.Together, these twin shifts‚Äîmanual automation and cognitive automation‚Äîare remaking both unskilled and skilled labor. The result: some jobs are being transformed, others are being cut.In a statement included in its job cut announcement, the company explained that AI‚Äôs transformative force requires new organizational structures: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs enabling companies to innovate much faster than ever before ... We‚Äôre convinced that we need to be organized more leanly, with fewer layers and more ownership, to move as quickly as possible for our customers and business.‚ÄùHowever, Amazon CEO Andy Jassy said during the company‚Äôs Oct. 30 earnings call that the recent layoff announcement was not ‚Äúreally AI-driven, not right now, at least.‚ÄùAI Diffusion Across the WorkforceEconomists, central banks, and think tanks have documented AI‚Äôs rapid spread across workplaces.A report by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis found that by early 2023, generative AI‚Äîthe class of AI capable of creating new content‚Äîhad become widespread across the American workforce. Tools such as ChatGPT were embedded in browsers, office software, and search engines, making large language model usage routine for millions of workers.The bank found that occupations adopting generative AI most intensively‚Äîparticularly computer and mathematical fields‚Äîexperienced the steepest unemployment gains.‚ÄúOur results suggest we may be witnessing the early stages of AI-driven job displacement,‚Äù the report noted. ‚ÄúUnlike previous technological revolutions that primarily affected manufacturing or routine clerical work, generative AI can target cognitive tasks performed by knowledge workers‚Äîtraditionally among the most secure employment categories.‚ÄùA Brookings Institution report estimates that 30 percent of all U.S. workers could see at least half of their job tasks disrupted by generative AI. Unlike earlier automation, which primarily affected blue-collar work, AI is expected to reshape a broad range of ‚Äúcognitive‚Äù and ‚Äúnonroutine‚Äù occupations‚Äîespecially those in middle- and high-income professions.Similarly, the McKinsey Global Institute has projected that automation (a combination of AI and robotics) could displace up to 54 million workers in the United States by 2030.Meanwhile, a Goldman Sachs analysis projects that widespread AI adoption could displace 6 to 7 percent of the U.S. workforce, equivalent to millions of jobs.Goldman Sachs economists estimate that temporary unemployment spikes by roughly 0.3 percentage points for each percentage-point gain in productivity from labor-saving technology.Jobs Most at RiskA Society for Human Resource Management study, published on April 25, offers a detailed snapshot of U.S. employment exposure to AI.According to the report, 12.6 percent of jobs‚Äîapproximately 19.2 million positions‚Äîface a high or very high risk of automation-related displacement. Among them, 14 percent of blue-collar jobs, 12.3 percent of white-collar jobs, and 12.1 percent of service-sector jobs are considered at high risk.Meanwhile, a June 9 report from the freelance work platform Upwork identifies 120 jobs that are hard to be replaced by AI, including clinical, creative, and skilled trades roles.AI and Changing Nature of SkillsA December 2024 Harvard Business School paper shows that AI has a mixed impact on businesses‚Äô labor demand.In automation-prone roles, AI reduces the need for specialized expertise by simplifying complex tasks. In augmentation-prone roles, however, it boosts productivity and increases demand for advanced, complementary skill sets.‚ÄúAs generative AI continues to evolve, understanding its heterogeneous effects on labor demand is critical,‚Äù the authors wrote. ‚ÄúPolicymakers and business practitioners must recognize the dual forces of automation and augmentation to ensure that workers are equipped to adapt and thrive.‚ÄùAt the same time, research by Nobel laureate Daron Acemoglu and colleagues‚Äîpublished in the Journal of Labor Economics‚Äîshows that as establishments adopt AI, they reduce hiring in non-AI positions and shift skill requirements across remaining roles.Andy Zenkevich, founder and CEO of Epiic, a digital agency specializing in generative engine optimization (GEO), told The Epoch Times that the fear of mass AI-driven job losses is overstated.‚ÄúAmong the companies we work with in digital marketing‚Äîincluding major tech firms‚Äîlayoffs haven‚Äôt been the story,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúInstead, jobs are morphing. A junior copywriter becomes an ‚ÄòAI content editor,‚Äô responsible for prompt engineering, fact-checking, and editing AI-generated copy.‚ÄùZenkevich estimated that roughly 2.5 percent of jobs are genuinely at risk under a full-scale AI rollout, noting that ‚Äútrue end-to-end automation is much harder than headlines suggest.‚Äù‚ÄúOver a third of jobs now require hybrid skill sets that combine technical literacy with human qualities machines can‚Äôt replicate,‚Äù he said.Georgios Koimisis, associate professor of finance at Manhattan University, echoed a similar skepticism.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a growing fear that artificial intelligence is wiping out jobs, but the reality is more complex,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúCompanies aren‚Äôt cutting workers simply because AI made them redundant. In an uncertain economy, firms want to appear modern and future-ready. Announcing an ‚ÄòAI transformation‚Äô reassures investors that management has a plan.‚ÄùKoimisis argues that some layoffs, framed as part of AI restructuring, are more about signaling discipline to shareholders than about reflecting genuine technological necessity.‚ÄúAI is changing not just how work is organized, but how value itself is defined,‚Äù he said.Izhar Haq, director of the School of Professional Accountancy at Long Island University, agrees that the slowing economy and business cycle are also contributing factors to recent job reductions.Haq told The Epoch Times that while the long-term economic effects of AI remain uncertain, ‚Äúwhite-collar analytical jobs are most at risk from AI integration, while manual labor jobs face risk from robotics.‚Äù TOPICS: Business/Economy; Computers/Internet; Society KEYWORDS: ai; jobs; unemployment Click here: to donate by Credit Card Or here: to donate by PayPal Or by mail to: Free Republic, LLC - PO Box 9771 - Fresno, CA 93794 Thank you very much and God bless you. A junior copywriter becomes an ‚ÄòAI content editor,‚Äô responsible for prompt engineering, fact-checking, and editing AI-generated copy.‚ÄùZenkevich estimated that roughly 2.5 percent of jobs are genuinely at risk under a full-scale AI rollout, noting that ‚Äútrue end-to-end automation is much harder than headlines suggest.‚Äù‚ÄúOver a third of jobs now require hybrid skill sets that combine technical literacy with human qualities machines can‚Äôt replicate,‚Äù he said.Georgios Koimisis, associate professor of finance at Manhattan University, echoed a similar skepticism.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a growing fear that artificial intelligence is wiping out jobs, but the reality is more complex,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúCompanies aren‚Äôt cutting workers simply because AI made them redundant. In an uncertain economy, firms want to appear modern and future-ready. Announcing an ‚ÄòAI transformation‚Äô reassures investors that management has a plan.‚ÄùKoimisis argues that some layoffs, framed as part of AI restructuring, are more about signaling discipline to shareholders than about reflecting genuine technological necessity.‚ÄúAI is changing not just how work is organized, but how value itself is defined,‚Äù he said.Izhar Haq, director of the School of Professional Accountancy at Long Island University, agrees that the slowing economy and business cycle are also contributing factors to recent job reductions.Haq told The Epoch Times that while the long-term economic effects of AI remain uncertain, ‚Äúwhite-collar analytical jobs are most at risk from AI integration, while manual labor jobs face risk from robotics.‚Äù TOPICS: Business/Economy; Computers/Internet; Society KEYWORDS: ai; jobs; unemployment Click here: to donate by Credit Card Or here: to donate by PayPal Or by mail to: Free Republic, LLC - PO Box 9771 - Fresno, CA 93794 Thank you very much and God bless you. Fixing problems created by bad management and using AI to identify better ways of running operations and eliminating inefficiencies, waste, and useless jobs.Here's an example of what Palantir is doing with its clients using AI: Swiss Re: After installing Palantir's software, they cut reporting time by up to 80%, freed about 30% of underwriters‚Äô time, boosted data-team output by 50%, and earned back the entire cost of the system in 7 months, ending with a 170% return (independently audited). Airbus: Used Palantir to improve assembly of the A350 by about 30%‚Äîfewer delays, fewer mistakes, and more planes finished each month using the same factories and workers. BP: Runs virtual ‚Äúdigital twins‚Äù of oil platforms and fields so engineers can spot problems early, prevent breakdowns, and make better decisions before something goes wrong. National power company (unnamed): Used Palantir to map 10,000+ miles of power lines and find weak spots before they fail. These aren‚Äôt future promises‚Äîthey‚Äôre real improvements in speed, cost, reliability, and output. This is what applied AI actually looks like in the real world.Stronger companies create real jobs. 15 posted on 11/04/2025 2:18:15 AM PST by RoosterRedux (‚ÄúCritical thinking is hard; that‚Äôs why most people just jump to conclusions.‚Äù‚ÄîJung (paraphrased)) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 12 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind If you‚Äôre a low level coder, your days are numbered. Yoits [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: minnesota_bound ...1/3rd of Hollywood jobs have disappeared. 48,000 gone. Most I suspect due to the terrible scold movies and tv shows they make but AI is replacing background players and set design builders etc. Some of that is due to the industry shift away from Hollywood. The Arri Alexa digital movie camera was released in 2010. Since then, movie producers had a more plentiful, less expensive, and better filming options than Hollywood could offer. The James Bond movie "Skyfall" (2012) was filmed using Alexa digital cameras and won the Academy Award for Best Cinematography. Add in Computer Generated Imagery and regular television shows can be filmed against a blue screen (or green screen), cutting back on set construction by instead using digital backgrounds created by lower cost overseas video editors. 20 posted on 11/04/2025 5:15:39 AM PST by T.B. Yoits [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 9 | View Replies] Navigation: use the links below to view more comments. first 1-20, 21-22 next last Disclaimer: Opinions posted on Free Republic are those of the individual posters and do not necessarily represent the opinion of Free Republic or its management. Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search General/Chat Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson Unlike past automation waves that mimicked the functions of the human body‚Äîreplacing manual or routine tasks‚ÄîAI targets the human brain‚Äôs cognitive abilities. It doesn‚Äôt just perform repetitive processes; it learns, analyzes, and makes decisions.Together, these twin shifts‚Äîmanual automation and cognitive automation‚Äîare remaking both unskilled and skilled labor. The result: some jobs are being transformed, others are being cut.In a statement included in its job cut announcement, the company explained that AI‚Äôs transformative force requires new organizational structures: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs enabling companies to innovate much faster than ever before ... We‚Äôre convinced that we need to be organized more leanly, with fewer layers and more ownership, to move as quickly as possible for our customers and business.‚ÄùHowever, Amazon CEO Andy Jassy said during the company‚Äôs Oct. 30 earnings call that the recent layoff announcement was not ‚Äúreally AI-driven, not right now, at least.‚ÄùAI Diffusion Across the WorkforceEconomists, central banks, and think tanks have documented AI‚Äôs rapid spread across workplaces.A report by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis found that by early 2023, generative AI‚Äîthe class of AI capable of creating new content‚Äîhad become widespread across the American workforce. Tools such as ChatGPT were embedded in browsers, office software, and search engines, making large language model usage routine for millions of workers.The bank found that occupations adopting generative AI most intensively‚Äîparticularly computer and mathematical fields‚Äîexperienced the steepest unemployment gains.‚ÄúOur results suggest we may be witnessing the early stages of AI-driven job displacement,‚Äù the report noted. ‚ÄúUnlike previous technological revolutions that primarily affected manufacturing or routine clerical work, generative AI can target cognitive tasks performed by knowledge workers‚Äîtraditionally among the most secure employment categories.‚ÄùA Brookings Institution report estimates that 30 percent of all U.S. workers could see at least half of their job tasks disrupted by generative AI. Unlike earlier automation, which primarily affected blue-collar work, AI is expected to reshape a broad range of ‚Äúcognitive‚Äù and ‚Äúnonroutine‚Äù occupations‚Äîespecially those in middle- and high-income professions.Similarly, the McKinsey Global Institute has projected that automation (a combination of AI and robotics) could displace up to 54 million workers in the United States by 2030.Meanwhile, a Goldman Sachs analysis projects that widespread AI adoption could displace 6 to 7 percent of the U.S. workforce, equivalent to millions of jobs.Goldman Sachs economists estimate that temporary unemployment spikes by roughly 0.3 percentage points for each percentage-point gain in productivity from labor-saving technology.Jobs Most at RiskA Society for Human Resource Management study, published on April 25, offers a detailed snapshot of U.S. employment exposure to AI.According to the report, 12.6 percent of jobs‚Äîapproximately 19.2 million positions‚Äîface a high or very high risk of automation-related displacement. Among them, 14 percent of blue-collar jobs, 12.3 percent of white-collar jobs, and 12.1 percent of service-sector jobs are considered at high risk.Meanwhile, a June 9 report from the freelance work platform Upwork identifies 120 jobs that are hard to be replaced by AI, including clinical, creative, and skilled trades roles.AI and Changing Nature of SkillsA December 2024 Harvard Business School paper shows that AI has a mixed impact on businesses‚Äô labor demand.In automation-prone roles, AI reduces the need for specialized expertise by simplifying complex tasks. In augmentation-prone roles, however, it boosts productivity and increases demand for advanced, complementary skill sets.‚ÄúAs generative AI continues to evolve, understanding its heterogeneous effects on labor demand is critical,‚Äù the authors wrote. ‚ÄúPolicymakers and business practitioners must recognize the dual forces of automation and augmentation to ensure that workers are equipped to adapt and thrive.‚ÄùAt the same time, research by Nobel laureate Daron Acemoglu and colleagues‚Äîpublished in the Journal of Labor Economics‚Äîshows that as establishments adopt AI, they reduce hiring in non-AI positions and shift skill requirements across remaining roles.Andy Zenkevich, founder and CEO of Epiic, a digital agency specializing in generative engine optimization (GEO), told The Epoch Times that the fear of mass AI-driven job losses is overstated.‚ÄúAmong the companies we work with in digital marketing‚Äîincluding major tech firms‚Äîlayoffs haven‚Äôt been the story,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúInstead, jobs are morphing. A junior copywriter becomes an ‚ÄòAI content editor,‚Äô responsible for prompt engineering, fact-checking, and editing AI-generated copy.‚ÄùZenkevich estimated that roughly 2.5 percent of jobs are genuinely at risk under a full-scale AI rollout, noting that ‚Äútrue end-to-end automation is much harder than headlines suggest.‚Äù‚ÄúOver a third of jobs now require hybrid skill sets that combine technical literacy with human qualities machines can‚Äôt replicate,‚Äù he said.Georgios Koimisis, associate professor of finance at Manhattan University, echoed a similar skepticism.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a growing fear that artificial intelligence is wiping out jobs, but the reality is more complex,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúCompanies aren‚Äôt cutting workers simply because AI made them redundant. In an uncertain economy, firms want to appear modern and future-ready. Announcing an ‚ÄòAI transformation‚Äô reassures investors that management has a plan.‚ÄùKoimisis argues that some layoffs, framed as part of AI restructuring, are more about signaling discipline to shareholders than about reflecting genuine technological necessity.‚ÄúAI is changing not just how work is organized, but how value itself is defined,‚Äù he said.Izhar Haq, director of the School of Professional Accountancy at Long Island University, agrees that the slowing economy and business cycle are also contributing factors to recent job reductions.Haq told The Epoch Times that while the long-term economic effects of AI remain uncertain, ‚Äúwhite-collar analytical jobs are most at risk from AI integration, while manual labor jobs face risk from robotics.‚Äù TOPICS: Business/Economy; Computers/Internet; Society KEYWORDS: ai; jobs; unemployment Click here: to donate by Credit Card Or here: to donate by PayPal Or by mail to: Free Republic, LLC - PO Box 9771 - Fresno, CA 93794 Thank you very much and God bless you. Unlike earlier automation, which primarily affected blue-collar work, AI is expected to reshape a broad range of ‚Äúcognitive‚Äù and ‚Äúnonroutine‚Äù occupations‚Äîespecially those in middle- and high-income professions.Similarly, the McKinsey Global Institute has projected that automation (a combination of AI and robotics) could displace up to 54 million workers in the United States by 2030.Meanwhile, a Goldman Sachs analysis projects that widespread AI adoption could displace 6 to 7 percent of the U.S. workforce, equivalent to millions of jobs.Goldman Sachs economists estimate that temporary unemployment spikes by roughly 0.3 percentage points for each percentage-point gain in productivity from labor-saving technology.Jobs Most at RiskA Society for Human Resource Management study, published on April 25, offers a detailed snapshot of U.S. employment exposure to AI.According to the report, 12.6 percent of jobs‚Äîapproximately 19.2 million positions‚Äîface a high or very high risk of automation-related displacement. Among them, 14 percent of blue-collar jobs, 12.3 percent of white-collar jobs, and 12.1 percent of service-sector jobs are considered at high risk.Meanwhile, a June 9 report from the freelance work platform Upwork identifies 120 jobs that are hard to be replaced by AI, including clinical, creative, and skilled trades roles.AI and Changing Nature of SkillsA December 2024 Harvard Business School paper shows that AI has a mixed impact on businesses‚Äô labor demand.In automation-prone roles, AI reduces the need for specialized expertise by simplifying complex tasks. In augmentation-prone roles, however, it boosts productivity and increases demand for advanced, complementary skill sets.‚ÄúAs generative AI continues to evolve, understanding its heterogeneous effects on labor demand is critical,‚Äù the authors wrote. ‚ÄúPolicymakers and business practitioners must recognize the dual forces of automation and augmentation to ensure that workers are equipped to adapt and thrive.‚ÄùAt the same time, research by Nobel laureate Daron Acemoglu and colleagues‚Äîpublished in the Journal of Labor Economics‚Äîshows that as establishments adopt AI, they reduce hiring in non-AI positions and shift skill requirements across remaining roles.Andy Zenkevich, founder and CEO of Epiic, a digital agency specializing in generative engine optimization (GEO), told The Epoch Times that the fear of mass AI-driven job losses is overstated.‚ÄúAmong the companies we work with in digital marketing‚Äîincluding major tech firms‚Äîlayoffs haven‚Äôt been the story,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúInstead, jobs are morphing. A junior copywriter becomes an ‚ÄòAI content editor,‚Äô responsible for prompt engineering, fact-checking, and editing AI-generated copy.‚ÄùZenkevich estimated that roughly 2.5 percent of jobs are genuinely at risk under a full-scale AI rollout, noting that ‚Äútrue end-to-end automation is much harder than headlines suggest.‚Äù‚ÄúOver a third of jobs now require hybrid skill sets that combine technical literacy with human qualities machines can‚Äôt replicate,‚Äù he said.Georgios Koimisis, associate professor of finance at Manhattan University, echoed a similar skepticism.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a growing fear that artificial intelligence is wiping out jobs, but the reality is more complex,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúCompanies aren‚Äôt cutting workers simply because AI made them redundant. In an uncertain economy, firms want to appear modern and future-ready. Announcing an ‚ÄòAI transformation‚Äô reassures investors that management has a plan.‚ÄùKoimisis argues that some layoffs, framed as part of AI restructuring, are more about signaling discipline to shareholders than about reflecting genuine technological necessity.‚ÄúAI is changing not just how work is organized, but how value itself is defined,‚Äù he said.Izhar Haq, director of the School of Professional Accountancy at Long Island University, agrees that the slowing economy and business cycle are also contributing factors to recent job reductions.Haq told The Epoch Times that while the long-term economic effects of AI remain uncertain, ‚Äúwhite-collar analytical jobs are most at risk from AI integration, while manual labor jobs face risk from robotics.‚Äù TOPICS: Business/Economy; Computers/Internet; Society KEYWORDS: ai; jobs; unemployment Click here: to donate by Credit Card Or here: to donate by PayPal Or by mail to: Free Republic, LLC - PO Box 9771 - Fresno, CA 93794 Thank you very much and God bless you. Tens of thousands of layoffs have been announced across major sectors in late October 2025, with UPS, Amazon, Intel and Nestl√© leading the cuts. Over 112,000 tech jobs alone have been eliminated this year, and broader corporate downsizing is accelerating. Just during October alone, UPS announced 48,000 job cuts, Amazon 14,000, Intel 24,000, Nestle 16,000, Accenture 11,000, Novo Nordisk 9,000, Applied Materials 1,444, Target 1,000, Charter Telecom 1,200 and CBS/Paramount 1,000. Fixing problems created by bad management and using AI to identify better ways of running operations and eliminating inefficiencies, waste, and useless jobs.Here's an example of what Palantir is doing with its clients using AI: Swiss Re: After installing Palantir's software, they cut reporting time by up to 80%, freed about 30% of underwriters‚Äô time, boosted data-team output by 50%, and earned back the entire cost of the system in 7 months, ending with a 170% return (independently audited). Airbus: Used Palantir to improve assembly of the A350 by about 30%‚Äîfewer delays, fewer mistakes, and more planes finished each month using the same factories and workers. BP: Runs virtual ‚Äúdigital twins‚Äù of oil platforms and fields so engineers can spot problems early, prevent breakdowns, and make better decisions before something goes wrong. National power company (unnamed): Used Palantir to map 10,000+ miles of power lines and find weak spots before they fail. These aren‚Äôt future promises‚Äîthey‚Äôre real improvements in speed, cost, reliability, and output. This is what applied AI actually looks like in the real world.Stronger companies create real jobs. 15 posted on 11/04/2025 2:18:15 AM PST by RoosterRedux (‚ÄúCritical thinking is hard; that‚Äôs why most people just jump to conclusions.‚Äù‚ÄîJung (paraphrased)) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 12 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind If you‚Äôre a low level coder, your days are numbered. Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search General/Chat Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson In a statement included in its job cut announcement, the company explained that AI‚Äôs transformative force requires new organizational structures: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs enabling companies to innovate much faster than ever before ... We‚Äôre convinced that we need to be organized more leanly, with fewer layers and more ownership, to move as quickly as possible for our customers and business.‚ÄùHowever, Amazon CEO Andy Jassy said during the company‚Äôs Oct. 30 earnings call that the recent layoff announcement was not ‚Äúreally AI-driven, not right now, at least.‚ÄùAI Diffusion Across the WorkforceEconomists, central banks, and think tanks have documented AI‚Äôs rapid spread across workplaces.A report by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis found that by early 2023, generative AI‚Äîthe class of AI capable of creating new content‚Äîhad become widespread across the American workforce. Tools such as ChatGPT were embedded in browsers, office software, and search engines, making large language model usage routine for millions of workers.The bank found that occupations adopting generative AI most intensively‚Äîparticularly computer and mathematical fields‚Äîexperienced the steepest unemployment gains.‚ÄúOur results suggest we may be witnessing the early stages of AI-driven job displacement,‚Äù the report noted. ‚ÄúUnlike previous technological revolutions that primarily affected manufacturing or routine clerical work, generative AI can target cognitive tasks performed by knowledge workers‚Äîtraditionally among the most secure employment categories.‚ÄùA Brookings Institution report estimates that 30 percent of all U.S. workers could see at least half of their job tasks disrupted by generative AI. Unlike earlier automation, which primarily affected blue-collar work, AI is expected to reshape a broad range of ‚Äúcognitive‚Äù and ‚Äúnonroutine‚Äù occupations‚Äîespecially those in middle- and high-income professions.Similarly, the McKinsey Global Institute has projected that automation (a combination of AI and robotics) could displace up to 54 million workers in the United States by 2030.Meanwhile, a Goldman Sachs analysis projects that widespread AI adoption could displace 6 to 7 percent of the U.S. workforce, equivalent to millions of jobs.Goldman Sachs economists estimate that temporary unemployment spikes by roughly 0.3 percentage points for each percentage-point gain in productivity from labor-saving technology.Jobs Most at RiskA Society for Human Resource Management study, published on April 25, offers a detailed snapshot of U.S. employment exposure to AI.According to the report, 12.6 percent of jobs‚Äîapproximately 19.2 million positions‚Äîface a high or very high risk of automation-related displacement. Among them, 14 percent of blue-collar jobs, 12.3 percent of white-collar jobs, and 12.1 percent of service-sector jobs are considered at high risk.Meanwhile, a June 9 report from the freelance work platform Upwork identifies 120 jobs that are hard to be replaced by AI, including clinical, creative, and skilled trades roles.AI and Changing Nature of SkillsA December 2024 Harvard Business School paper shows that AI has a mixed impact on businesses‚Äô labor demand.In automation-prone roles, AI reduces the need for specialized expertise by simplifying complex tasks. In augmentation-prone roles, however, it boosts productivity and increases demand for advanced, complementary skill sets.‚ÄúAs generative AI continues to evolve, understanding its heterogeneous effects on labor demand is critical,‚Äù the authors wrote. ‚ÄúPolicymakers and business practitioners must recognize the dual forces of automation and augmentation to ensure that workers are equipped to adapt and thrive.‚ÄùAt the same time, research by Nobel laureate Daron Acemoglu and colleagues‚Äîpublished in the Journal of Labor Economics‚Äîshows that as establishments adopt AI, they reduce hiring in non-AI positions and shift skill requirements across remaining roles.Andy Zenkevich, founder and CEO of Epiic, a digital agency specializing in generative engine optimization (GEO), told The Epoch Times that the fear of mass AI-driven job losses is overstated.‚ÄúAmong the companies we work with in digital marketing‚Äîincluding major tech firms‚Äîlayoffs haven‚Äôt been the story,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúInstead, jobs are morphing. A junior copywriter becomes an ‚ÄòAI content editor,‚Äô responsible for prompt engineering, fact-checking, and editing AI-generated copy.‚ÄùZenkevich estimated that roughly 2.5 percent of jobs are genuinely at risk under a full-scale AI rollout, noting that ‚Äútrue end-to-end automation is much harder than headlines suggest.‚Äù‚ÄúOver a third of jobs now require hybrid skill sets that combine technical literacy with human qualities machines can‚Äôt replicate,‚Äù he said.Georgios Koimisis, associate professor of finance at Manhattan University, echoed a similar skepticism.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a growing fear that artificial intelligence is wiping out jobs, but the reality is more complex,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúCompanies aren‚Äôt cutting workers simply because AI made them redundant. In an uncertain economy, firms want to appear modern and future-ready. Announcing an ‚ÄòAI transformation‚Äô reassures investors that management has a plan.‚ÄùKoimisis argues that some layoffs, framed as part of AI restructuring, are more about signaling discipline to shareholders than about reflecting genuine technological necessity.‚ÄúAI is changing not just how work is organized, but how value itself is defined,‚Äù he said.Izhar Haq, director of the School of Professional Accountancy at Long Island University, agrees that the slowing economy and business cycle are also contributing factors to recent job reductions.Haq told The Epoch Times that while the long-term economic effects of AI remain uncertain, ‚Äúwhite-collar analytical jobs are most at risk from AI integration, while manual labor jobs face risk from robotics.‚Äù TOPICS: Business/Economy; Computers/Internet; Society KEYWORDS: ai; jobs; unemployment Click here: to donate by Credit Card Or here: to donate by PayPal Or by mail to: Free Republic, LLC - PO Box 9771 - Fresno, CA 93794 Thank you very much and God bless you. Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search General/Chat Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson However, Amazon CEO Andy Jassy said during the company‚Äôs Oct. 30 earnings call that the recent layoff announcement was not ‚Äúreally AI-driven, not right now, at least.‚ÄùAI Diffusion Across the WorkforceEconomists, central banks, and think tanks have documented AI‚Äôs rapid spread across workplaces.A report by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis found that by early 2023, generative AI‚Äîthe class of AI capable of creating new content‚Äîhad become widespread across the American workforce. Tools such as ChatGPT were embedded in browsers, office software, and search engines, making large language model usage routine for millions of workers.The bank found that occupations adopting generative AI most intensively‚Äîparticularly computer and mathematical fields‚Äîexperienced the steepest unemployment gains.‚ÄúOur results suggest we may be witnessing the early stages of AI-driven job displacement,‚Äù the report noted. ‚ÄúUnlike previous technological revolutions that primarily affected manufacturing or routine clerical work, generative AI can target cognitive tasks performed by knowledge workers‚Äîtraditionally among the most secure employment categories.‚ÄùA Brookings Institution report estimates that 30 percent of all U.S. workers could see at least half of their job tasks disrupted by generative AI. Unlike earlier automation, which primarily affected blue-collar work, AI is expected to reshape a broad range of ‚Äúcognitive‚Äù and ‚Äúnonroutine‚Äù occupations‚Äîespecially those in middle- and high-income professions.Similarly, the McKinsey Global Institute has projected that automation (a combination of AI and robotics) could displace up to 54 million workers in the United States by 2030.Meanwhile, a Goldman Sachs analysis projects that widespread AI adoption could displace 6 to 7 percent of the U.S. workforce, equivalent to millions of jobs.Goldman Sachs economists estimate that temporary unemployment spikes by roughly 0.3 percentage points for each percentage-point gain in productivity from labor-saving technology.Jobs Most at RiskA Society for Human Resource Management study, published on April 25, offers a detailed snapshot of U.S. employment exposure to AI.According to the report, 12.6 percent of jobs‚Äîapproximately 19.2 million positions‚Äîface a high or very high risk of automation-related displacement. Among them, 14 percent of blue-collar jobs, 12.3 percent of white-collar jobs, and 12.1 percent of service-sector jobs are considered at high risk.Meanwhile, a June 9 report from the freelance work platform Upwork identifies 120 jobs that are hard to be replaced by AI, including clinical, creative, and skilled trades roles.AI and Changing Nature of SkillsA December 2024 Harvard Business School paper shows that AI has a mixed impact on businesses‚Äô labor demand.In automation-prone roles, AI reduces the need for specialized expertise by simplifying complex tasks. In augmentation-prone roles, however, it boosts productivity and increases demand for advanced, complementary skill sets.‚ÄúAs generative AI continues to evolve, understanding its heterogeneous effects on labor demand is critical,‚Äù the authors wrote. ‚ÄúPolicymakers and business practitioners must recognize the dual forces of automation and augmentation to ensure that workers are equipped to adapt and thrive.‚ÄùAt the same time, research by Nobel laureate Daron Acemoglu and colleagues‚Äîpublished in the Journal of Labor Economics‚Äîshows that as establishments adopt AI, they reduce hiring in non-AI positions and shift skill requirements across remaining roles.Andy Zenkevich, founder and CEO of Epiic, a digital agency specializing in generative engine optimization (GEO), told The Epoch Times that the fear of mass AI-driven job losses is overstated.‚ÄúAmong the companies we work with in digital marketing‚Äîincluding major tech firms‚Äîlayoffs haven‚Äôt been the story,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúInstead, jobs are morphing. A junior copywriter becomes an ‚ÄòAI content editor,‚Äô responsible for prompt engineering, fact-checking, and editing AI-generated copy.‚ÄùZenkevich estimated that roughly 2.5 percent of jobs are genuinely at risk under a full-scale AI rollout, noting that ‚Äútrue end-to-end automation is much harder than headlines suggest.‚Äù‚ÄúOver a third of jobs now require hybrid skill sets that combine technical literacy with human qualities machines can‚Äôt replicate,‚Äù he said.Georgios Koimisis, associate professor of finance at Manhattan University, echoed a similar skepticism.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a growing fear that artificial intelligence is wiping out jobs, but the reality is more complex,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúCompanies aren‚Äôt cutting workers simply because AI made them redundant. In an uncertain economy, firms want to appear modern and future-ready. Announcing an ‚ÄòAI transformation‚Äô reassures investors that management has a plan.‚ÄùKoimisis argues that some layoffs, framed as part of AI restructuring, are more about signaling discipline to shareholders than about reflecting genuine technological necessity.‚ÄúAI is changing not just how work is organized, but how value itself is defined,‚Äù he said.Izhar Haq, director of the School of Professional Accountancy at Long Island University, agrees that the slowing economy and business cycle are also contributing factors to recent job reductions.Haq told The Epoch Times that while the long-term economic effects of AI remain uncertain, ‚Äúwhite-collar analytical jobs are most at risk from AI integration, while manual labor jobs face risk from robotics.‚Äù TOPICS: Business/Economy; Computers/Internet; Society KEYWORDS: ai; jobs; unemployment Click here: to donate by Credit Card Or here: to donate by PayPal Or by mail to: Free Republic, LLC - PO Box 9771 - Fresno, CA 93794 Thank you very much and God bless you. Tens of thousands of layoffs have been announced across major sectors in late October 2025, with UPS, Amazon, Intel and Nestl√© leading the cuts. Over 112,000 tech jobs alone have been eliminated this year, and broader corporate downsizing is accelerating. Just during October alone, UPS announced 48,000 job cuts, Amazon 14,000, Intel 24,000, Nestle 16,000, Accenture 11,000, Novo Nordisk 9,000, Applied Materials 1,444, Target 1,000, Charter Telecom 1,200 and CBS/Paramount 1,000. These are notable corporations cutting staff, but other major companies like JPMorgan Chase have implemented a hiring freeze across multiple divisions in late 2025, driven by its aggressive deployment of artificial intelligence and cost discipline. Managers have been instructed to avoid hiring unless absolutely necessary. 5 posted on 11/03/2025 9:02:54 PM PST by SeekAndFind [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 3 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind All of this screams to me, ‚ÄúWork for yourself!‚Äù 6 posted on 11/03/2025 9:28:31 PM PST by SaxxonWoods (Annnd....TRUMP IS RIGHT AGAIN.) No matter what the "choices" from the AI are, I just repeat HUMAN until they transfer to a living, breathing person. Fixing problems created by bad management and using AI to identify better ways of running operations and eliminating inefficiencies, waste, and useless jobs.Here's an example of what Palantir is doing with its clients using AI: Swiss Re: After installing Palantir's software, they cut reporting time by up to 80%, freed about 30% of underwriters‚Äô time, boosted data-team output by 50%, and earned back the entire cost of the system in 7 months, ending with a 170% return (independently audited). Airbus: Used Palantir to improve assembly of the A350 by about 30%‚Äîfewer delays, fewer mistakes, and more planes finished each month using the same factories and workers. BP: Runs virtual ‚Äúdigital twins‚Äù of oil platforms and fields so engineers can spot problems early, prevent breakdowns, and make better decisions before something goes wrong. National power company (unnamed): Used Palantir to map 10,000+ miles of power lines and find weak spots before they fail. These aren‚Äôt future promises‚Äîthey‚Äôre real improvements in speed, cost, reliability, and output. This is what applied AI actually looks like in the real world.Stronger companies create real jobs. 15 posted on 11/04/2025 2:18:15 AM PST by RoosterRedux (‚ÄúCritical thinking is hard; that‚Äôs why most people just jump to conclusions.‚Äù‚ÄîJung (paraphrased)) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 12 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind If you‚Äôre a low level coder, your days are numbered. If you‚Äôre a designer/engineer, AI is making your life easier as you don‚Äôt have to farm the work out to the aforementioned. If you‚Äôre a data analyst or financial manager, you are already prompting AI to build the queries to pull your data and create your decks. If not, you‚Äôve probably missed the boat. 16 posted on 11/04/2025 2:19:44 AM PST by Sirius Lee ("Never argue with a fool, onlookers may not be able to tell the difference.‚Äù) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 5 | View Replies] To: dpetty121263 ‚ÄúGuess there is always starvation...can‚Äôt work so no eats.‚Äù There‚Äôs ALWAYS electrical work... and Electrical Workers hold the key to shutting AI off. Yoits [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: minnesota_bound ...1/3rd of Hollywood jobs have disappeared. 48,000 gone. Most I suspect due to the terrible scold movies and tv shows they make but AI is replacing background players and set design builders etc. Some of that is due to the industry shift away from Hollywood. The Arri Alexa digital movie camera was released in 2010. Since then, movie producers had a more plentiful, less expensive, and better filming options than Hollywood could offer. The James Bond movie "Skyfall" (2012) was filmed using Alexa digital cameras and won the Academy Award for Best Cinematography. Add in Computer Generated Imagery and regular television shows can be filmed against a blue screen (or green screen), cutting back on set construction by instead using digital backgrounds created by lower cost overseas video editors. 20 posted on 11/04/2025 5:15:39 AM PST by T.B. Among them, 14 percent of blue-collar jobs, 12.3 percent of white-collar jobs, and 12.1 percent of service-sector jobs are considered at high risk.Meanwhile, a June 9 report from the freelance work platform Upwork identifies 120 jobs that are hard to be replaced by AI, including clinical, creative, and skilled trades roles.AI and Changing Nature of SkillsA December 2024 Harvard Business School paper shows that AI has a mixed impact on businesses‚Äô labor demand.In automation-prone roles, AI reduces the need for specialized expertise by simplifying complex tasks. In augmentation-prone roles, however, it boosts productivity and increases demand for advanced, complementary skill sets.‚ÄúAs generative AI continues to evolve, understanding its heterogeneous effects on labor demand is critical,‚Äù the authors wrote. ‚ÄúPolicymakers and business practitioners must recognize the dual forces of automation and augmentation to ensure that workers are equipped to adapt and thrive.‚ÄùAt the same time, research by Nobel laureate Daron Acemoglu and colleagues‚Äîpublished in the Journal of Labor Economics‚Äîshows that as establishments adopt AI, they reduce hiring in non-AI positions and shift skill requirements across remaining roles.Andy Zenkevich, founder and CEO of Epiic, a digital agency specializing in generative engine optimization (GEO), told The Epoch Times that the fear of mass AI-driven job losses is overstated.‚ÄúAmong the companies we work with in digital marketing‚Äîincluding major tech firms‚Äîlayoffs haven‚Äôt been the story,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúInstead, jobs are morphing. A junior copywriter becomes an ‚ÄòAI content editor,‚Äô responsible for prompt engineering, fact-checking, and editing AI-generated copy.‚ÄùZenkevich estimated that roughly 2.5 percent of jobs are genuinely at risk under a full-scale AI rollout, noting that ‚Äútrue end-to-end automation is much harder than headlines suggest.‚Äù‚ÄúOver a third of jobs now require hybrid skill sets that combine technical literacy with human qualities machines can‚Äôt replicate,‚Äù he said.Georgios Koimisis, associate professor of finance at Manhattan University, echoed a similar skepticism.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a growing fear that artificial intelligence is wiping out jobs, but the reality is more complex,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúCompanies aren‚Äôt cutting workers simply because AI made them redundant. In an uncertain economy, firms want to appear modern and future-ready. Announcing an ‚ÄòAI transformation‚Äô reassures investors that management has a plan.‚ÄùKoimisis argues that some layoffs, framed as part of AI restructuring, are more about signaling discipline to shareholders than about reflecting genuine technological necessity.‚ÄúAI is changing not just how work is organized, but how value itself is defined,‚Äù he said.Izhar Haq, director of the School of Professional Accountancy at Long Island University, agrees that the slowing economy and business cycle are also contributing factors to recent job reductions.Haq told The Epoch Times that while the long-term economic effects of AI remain uncertain, ‚Äúwhite-collar analytical jobs are most at risk from AI integration, while manual labor jobs face risk from robotics.‚Äù TOPICS: Business/Economy; Computers/Internet; Society KEYWORDS: ai; jobs; unemployment Click here: to donate by Credit Card Or here: to donate by PayPal Or by mail to: Free Republic, LLC - PO Box 9771 - Fresno, CA 93794 Thank you very much and God bless you. Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search General/Chat Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson A report by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis found that by early 2023, generative AI‚Äîthe class of AI capable of creating new content‚Äîhad become widespread across the American workforce. Tools such as ChatGPT were embedded in browsers, office software, and search engines, making large language model usage routine for millions of workers.The bank found that occupations adopting generative AI most intensively‚Äîparticularly computer and mathematical fields‚Äîexperienced the steepest unemployment gains.‚ÄúOur results suggest we may be witnessing the early stages of AI-driven job displacement,‚Äù the report noted. ‚ÄúUnlike previous technological revolutions that primarily affected manufacturing or routine clerical work, generative AI can target cognitive tasks performed by knowledge workers‚Äîtraditionally among the most secure employment categories.‚ÄùA Brookings Institution report estimates that 30 percent of all U.S. workers could see at least half of their job tasks disrupted by generative AI. Unlike earlier automation, which primarily affected blue-collar work, AI is expected to reshape a broad range of ‚Äúcognitive‚Äù and ‚Äúnonroutine‚Äù occupations‚Äîespecially those in middle- and high-income professions.Similarly, the McKinsey Global Institute has projected that automation (a combination of AI and robotics) could displace up to 54 million workers in the United States by 2030.Meanwhile, a Goldman Sachs analysis projects that widespread AI adoption could displace 6 to 7 percent of the U.S. workforce, equivalent to millions of jobs.Goldman Sachs economists estimate that temporary unemployment spikes by roughly 0.3 percentage points for each percentage-point gain in productivity from labor-saving technology.Jobs Most at RiskA Society for Human Resource Management study, published on April 25, offers a detailed snapshot of U.S. employment exposure to AI.According to the report, 12.6 percent of jobs‚Äîapproximately 19.2 million positions‚Äîface a high or very high risk of automation-related displacement. Among them, 14 percent of blue-collar jobs, 12.3 percent of white-collar jobs, and 12.1 percent of service-sector jobs are considered at high risk.Meanwhile, a June 9 report from the freelance work platform Upwork identifies 120 jobs that are hard to be replaced by AI, including clinical, creative, and skilled trades roles.AI and Changing Nature of SkillsA December 2024 Harvard Business School paper shows that AI has a mixed impact on businesses‚Äô labor demand.In automation-prone roles, AI reduces the need for specialized expertise by simplifying complex tasks. In augmentation-prone roles, however, it boosts productivity and increases demand for advanced, complementary skill sets.‚ÄúAs generative AI continues to evolve, understanding its heterogeneous effects on labor demand is critical,‚Äù the authors wrote. ‚ÄúPolicymakers and business practitioners must recognize the dual forces of automation and augmentation to ensure that workers are equipped to adapt and thrive.‚ÄùAt the same time, research by Nobel laureate Daron Acemoglu and colleagues‚Äîpublished in the Journal of Labor Economics‚Äîshows that as establishments adopt AI, they reduce hiring in non-AI positions and shift skill requirements across remaining roles.Andy Zenkevich, founder and CEO of Epiic, a digital agency specializing in generative engine optimization (GEO), told The Epoch Times that the fear of mass AI-driven job losses is overstated.‚ÄúAmong the companies we work with in digital marketing‚Äîincluding major tech firms‚Äîlayoffs haven‚Äôt been the story,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúInstead, jobs are morphing. A junior copywriter becomes an ‚ÄòAI content editor,‚Äô responsible for prompt engineering, fact-checking, and editing AI-generated copy.‚ÄùZenkevich estimated that roughly 2.5 percent of jobs are genuinely at risk under a full-scale AI rollout, noting that ‚Äútrue end-to-end automation is much harder than headlines suggest.‚Äù‚ÄúOver a third of jobs now require hybrid skill sets that combine technical literacy with human qualities machines can‚Äôt replicate,‚Äù he said.Georgios Koimisis, associate professor of finance at Manhattan University, echoed a similar skepticism.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a growing fear that artificial intelligence is wiping out jobs, but the reality is more complex,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúCompanies aren‚Äôt cutting workers simply because AI made them redundant. In an uncertain economy, firms want to appear modern and future-ready. Announcing an ‚ÄòAI transformation‚Äô reassures investors that management has a plan.‚ÄùKoimisis argues that some layoffs, framed as part of AI restructuring, are more about signaling discipline to shareholders than about reflecting genuine technological necessity.‚ÄúAI is changing not just how work is organized, but how value itself is defined,‚Äù he said.Izhar Haq, director of the School of Professional Accountancy at Long Island University, agrees that the slowing economy and business cycle are also contributing factors to recent job reductions.Haq told The Epoch Times that while the long-term economic effects of AI remain uncertain, ‚Äúwhite-collar analytical jobs are most at risk from AI integration, while manual labor jobs face risk from robotics.‚Äù TOPICS: Business/Economy; Computers/Internet; Society KEYWORDS: ai; jobs; unemployment Click here: to donate by Credit Card Or here: to donate by PayPal Or by mail to: Free Republic, LLC - PO Box 9771 - Fresno, CA 93794 Thank you very much and God bless you. Tens of thousands of layoffs have been announced across major sectors in late October 2025, with UPS, Amazon, Intel and Nestl√© leading the cuts. Over 112,000 tech jobs alone have been eliminated this year, and broader corporate downsizing is accelerating. Just during October alone, UPS announced 48,000 job cuts, Amazon 14,000, Intel 24,000, Nestle 16,000, Accenture 11,000, Novo Nordisk 9,000, Applied Materials 1,444, Target 1,000, Charter Telecom 1,200 and CBS/Paramount 1,000. These are notable corporations cutting staff, but other major companies like JPMorgan Chase have implemented a hiring freeze across multiple divisions in late 2025, driven by its aggressive deployment of artificial intelligence and cost discipline. Fixing problems created by bad management and using AI to identify better ways of running operations and eliminating inefficiencies, waste, and useless jobs.Here's an example of what Palantir is doing with its clients using AI: Swiss Re: After installing Palantir's software, they cut reporting time by up to 80%, freed about 30% of underwriters‚Äô time, boosted data-team output by 50%, and earned back the entire cost of the system in 7 months, ending with a 170% return (independently audited). Airbus: Used Palantir to improve assembly of the A350 by about 30%‚Äîfewer delays, fewer mistakes, and more planes finished each month using the same factories and workers. BP: Runs virtual ‚Äúdigital twins‚Äù of oil platforms and fields so engineers can spot problems early, prevent breakdowns, and make better decisions before something goes wrong. National power company (unnamed): Used Palantir to map 10,000+ miles of power lines and find weak spots before they fail. These aren‚Äôt future promises‚Äîthey‚Äôre real improvements in speed, cost, reliability, and output. This is what applied AI actually looks like in the real world.Stronger companies create real jobs. 15 posted on 11/04/2025 2:18:15 AM PST by RoosterRedux (‚ÄúCritical thinking is hard; that‚Äôs why most people just jump to conclusions.‚Äù‚ÄîJung (paraphrased)) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 12 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind If you‚Äôre a low level coder, your days are numbered. If you‚Äôre a designer/engineer, AI is making your life easier as you don‚Äôt have to farm the work out to the aforementioned. If you‚Äôre a data analyst or financial manager, you are already prompting AI to build the queries to pull your data and create your decks. If not, you‚Äôve probably missed the boat. 16 posted on 11/04/2025 2:19:44 AM PST by Sirius Lee ("Never argue with a fool, onlookers may not be able to tell the difference.‚Äù) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 5 | View Replies] To: dpetty121263 ‚ÄúGuess there is always starvation...can‚Äôt work so no eats.‚Äù There‚Äôs ALWAYS electrical work... and Electrical Workers hold the key to shutting AI off. Yoits [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: minnesota_bound ...1/3rd of Hollywood jobs have disappeared. 48,000 gone. Most I suspect due to the terrible scold movies and tv shows they make but AI is replacing background players and set design builders etc. Some of that is due to the industry shift away from Hollywood. The Arri Alexa digital movie camera was released in 2010. Since then, movie producers had a more plentiful, less expensive, and better filming options than Hollywood could offer. The James Bond movie "Skyfall" (2012) was filmed using Alexa digital cameras and won the Academy Award for Best Cinematography. Add in Computer Generated Imagery and regular television shows can be filmed against a blue screen (or green screen), cutting back on set construction by instead using digital backgrounds created by lower cost overseas video editors. 20 posted on 11/04/2025 5:15:39 AM PST by T.B. Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search General/Chat Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson ‚ÄúOur results suggest we may be witnessing the early stages of AI-driven job displacement,‚Äù the report noted. ‚ÄúUnlike previous technological revolutions that primarily affected manufacturing or routine clerical work, generative AI can target cognitive tasks performed by knowledge workers‚Äîtraditionally among the most secure employment categories.‚ÄùA Brookings Institution report estimates that 30 percent of all U.S. workers could see at least half of their job tasks disrupted by generative AI. Unlike earlier automation, which primarily affected blue-collar work, AI is expected to reshape a broad range of ‚Äúcognitive‚Äù and ‚Äúnonroutine‚Äù occupations‚Äîespecially those in middle- and high-income professions.Similarly, the McKinsey Global Institute has projected that automation (a combination of AI and robotics) could displace up to 54 million workers in the United States by 2030.Meanwhile, a Goldman Sachs analysis projects that widespread AI adoption could displace 6 to 7 percent of the U.S. workforce, equivalent to millions of jobs.Goldman Sachs economists estimate that temporary unemployment spikes by roughly 0.3 percentage points for each percentage-point gain in productivity from labor-saving technology.Jobs Most at RiskA Society for Human Resource Management study, published on April 25, offers a detailed snapshot of U.S. employment exposure to AI.According to the report, 12.6 percent of jobs‚Äîapproximately 19.2 million positions‚Äîface a high or very high risk of automation-related displacement. Among them, 14 percent of blue-collar jobs, 12.3 percent of white-collar jobs, and 12.1 percent of service-sector jobs are considered at high risk.Meanwhile, a June 9 report from the freelance work platform Upwork identifies 120 jobs that are hard to be replaced by AI, including clinical, creative, and skilled trades roles.AI and Changing Nature of SkillsA December 2024 Harvard Business School paper shows that AI has a mixed impact on businesses‚Äô labor demand.In automation-prone roles, AI reduces the need for specialized expertise by simplifying complex tasks. In augmentation-prone roles, however, it boosts productivity and increases demand for advanced, complementary skill sets.‚ÄúAs generative AI continues to evolve, understanding its heterogeneous effects on labor demand is critical,‚Äù the authors wrote. ‚ÄúPolicymakers and business practitioners must recognize the dual forces of automation and augmentation to ensure that workers are equipped to adapt and thrive.‚ÄùAt the same time, research by Nobel laureate Daron Acemoglu and colleagues‚Äîpublished in the Journal of Labor Economics‚Äîshows that as establishments adopt AI, they reduce hiring in non-AI positions and shift skill requirements across remaining roles.Andy Zenkevich, founder and CEO of Epiic, a digital agency specializing in generative engine optimization (GEO), told The Epoch Times that the fear of mass AI-driven job losses is overstated.‚ÄúAmong the companies we work with in digital marketing‚Äîincluding major tech firms‚Äîlayoffs haven‚Äôt been the story,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúInstead, jobs are morphing. A junior copywriter becomes an ‚ÄòAI content editor,‚Äô responsible for prompt engineering, fact-checking, and editing AI-generated copy.‚ÄùZenkevich estimated that roughly 2.5 percent of jobs are genuinely at risk under a full-scale AI rollout, noting that ‚Äútrue end-to-end automation is much harder than headlines suggest.‚Äù‚ÄúOver a third of jobs now require hybrid skill sets that combine technical literacy with human qualities machines can‚Äôt replicate,‚Äù he said.Georgios Koimisis, associate professor of finance at Manhattan University, echoed a similar skepticism.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a growing fear that artificial intelligence is wiping out jobs, but the reality is more complex,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúCompanies aren‚Äôt cutting workers simply because AI made them redundant. In an uncertain economy, firms want to appear modern and future-ready. Announcing an ‚ÄòAI transformation‚Äô reassures investors that management has a plan.‚ÄùKoimisis argues that some layoffs, framed as part of AI restructuring, are more about signaling discipline to shareholders than about reflecting genuine technological necessity.‚ÄúAI is changing not just how work is organized, but how value itself is defined,‚Äù he said.Izhar Haq, director of the School of Professional Accountancy at Long Island University, agrees that the slowing economy and business cycle are also contributing factors to recent job reductions.Haq told The Epoch Times that while the long-term economic effects of AI remain uncertain, ‚Äúwhite-collar analytical jobs are most at risk from AI integration, while manual labor jobs face risk from robotics.‚Äù TOPICS: Business/Economy; Computers/Internet; Society KEYWORDS: ai; jobs; unemployment Click here: to donate by Credit Card Or here: to donate by PayPal Or by mail to: Free Republic, LLC - PO Box 9771 - Fresno, CA 93794 Thank you very much and God bless you. Tens of thousands of layoffs have been announced across major sectors in late October 2025, with UPS, Amazon, Intel and Nestl√© leading the cuts. Over 112,000 tech jobs alone have been eliminated this year, and broader corporate downsizing is accelerating. Just during October alone, UPS announced 48,000 job cuts, Amazon 14,000, Intel 24,000, Nestle 16,000, Accenture 11,000, Novo Nordisk 9,000, Applied Materials 1,444, Target 1,000, Charter Telecom 1,200 and CBS/Paramount 1,000. These are notable corporations cutting staff, but other major companies like JPMorgan Chase have implemented a hiring freeze across multiple divisions in late 2025, driven by its aggressive deployment of artificial intelligence and cost discipline. Fixing problems created by bad management and using AI to identify better ways of running operations and eliminating inefficiencies, waste, and useless jobs.Here's an example of what Palantir is doing with its clients using AI: Swiss Re: After installing Palantir's software, they cut reporting time by up to 80%, freed about 30% of underwriters‚Äô time, boosted data-team output by 50%, and earned back the entire cost of the system in 7 months, ending with a 170% return (independently audited). Airbus: Used Palantir to improve assembly of the A350 by about 30%‚Äîfewer delays, fewer mistakes, and more planes finished each month using the same factories and workers. BP: Runs virtual ‚Äúdigital twins‚Äù of oil platforms and fields so engineers can spot problems early, prevent breakdowns, and make better decisions before something goes wrong. National power company (unnamed): Used Palantir to map 10,000+ miles of power lines and find weak spots before they fail. These aren‚Äôt future promises‚Äîthey‚Äôre real improvements in speed, cost, reliability, and output. This is what applied AI actually looks like in the real world.Stronger companies create real jobs. 15 posted on 11/04/2025 2:18:15 AM PST by RoosterRedux (‚ÄúCritical thinking is hard; that‚Äôs why most people just jump to conclusions.‚Äù‚ÄîJung (paraphrased)) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 12 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind If you‚Äôre a low level coder, your days are numbered. If you‚Äôre a data analyst or financial manager, you are already prompting AI to build the queries to pull your data and create your decks. If not, you‚Äôve probably missed the boat. 16 posted on 11/04/2025 2:19:44 AM PST by Sirius Lee ("Never argue with a fool, onlookers may not be able to tell the difference.‚Äù) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 5 | View Replies] To: dpetty121263 ‚ÄúGuess there is always starvation...can‚Äôt work so no eats.‚Äù There‚Äôs ALWAYS electrical work... and Electrical Workers hold the key to shutting AI off. Yoits [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: minnesota_bound ...1/3rd of Hollywood jobs have disappeared. 48,000 gone. Most I suspect due to the terrible scold movies and tv shows they make but AI is replacing background players and set design builders etc. Some of that is due to the industry shift away from Hollywood. The Arri Alexa digital movie camera was released in 2010. Since then, movie producers had a more plentiful, less expensive, and better filming options than Hollywood could offer. The James Bond movie "Skyfall" (2012) was filmed using Alexa digital cameras and won the Academy Award for Best Cinematography. Add in Computer Generated Imagery and regular television shows can be filmed against a blue screen (or green screen), cutting back on set construction by instead using digital backgrounds created by lower cost overseas video editors. 20 posted on 11/04/2025 5:15:39 AM PST by T.B.
