Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search General/Chat Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson A Brookings Institution report estimates that 30 percent of all U.S. workers could see at least half of their job tasks disrupted by generative AI. Unlike earlier automation, which primarily affected blue-collar work, AI is expected to reshape a broad range of ‚Äúcognitive‚Äù and ‚Äúnonroutine‚Äù occupations‚Äîespecially those in middle- and high-income professions.Similarly, the McKinsey Global Institute has projected that automation (a combination of AI and robotics) could displace up to 54 million workers in the United States by 2030.Meanwhile, a Goldman Sachs analysis projects that widespread AI adoption could displace 6 to 7 percent of the U.S. workforce, equivalent to millions of jobs.Goldman Sachs economists estimate that temporary unemployment spikes by roughly 0.3 percentage points for each percentage-point gain in productivity from labor-saving technology.Jobs Most at RiskA Society for Human Resource Management study, published on April 25, offers a detailed snapshot of U.S. employment exposure to AI.According to the report, 12.6 percent of jobs‚Äîapproximately 19.2 million positions‚Äîface a high or very high risk of automation-related displacement. Among them, 14 percent of blue-collar jobs, 12.3 percent of white-collar jobs, and 12.1 percent of service-sector jobs are considered at high risk.Meanwhile, a June 9 report from the freelance work platform Upwork identifies 120 jobs that are hard to be replaced by AI, including clinical, creative, and skilled trades roles.AI and Changing Nature of SkillsA December 2024 Harvard Business School paper shows that AI has a mixed impact on businesses‚Äô labor demand.In automation-prone roles, AI reduces the need for specialized expertise by simplifying complex tasks. In augmentation-prone roles, however, it boosts productivity and increases demand for advanced, complementary skill sets.‚ÄúAs generative AI continues to evolve, understanding its heterogeneous effects on labor demand is critical,‚Äù the authors wrote. ‚ÄúPolicymakers and business practitioners must recognize the dual forces of automation and augmentation to ensure that workers are equipped to adapt and thrive.‚ÄùAt the same time, research by Nobel laureate Daron Acemoglu and colleagues‚Äîpublished in the Journal of Labor Economics‚Äîshows that as establishments adopt AI, they reduce hiring in non-AI positions and shift skill requirements across remaining roles.Andy Zenkevich, founder and CEO of Epiic, a digital agency specializing in generative engine optimization (GEO), told The Epoch Times that the fear of mass AI-driven job losses is overstated.‚ÄúAmong the companies we work with in digital marketing‚Äîincluding major tech firms‚Äîlayoffs haven‚Äôt been the story,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúInstead, jobs are morphing. A junior copywriter becomes an ‚ÄòAI content editor,‚Äô responsible for prompt engineering, fact-checking, and editing AI-generated copy.‚ÄùZenkevich estimated that roughly 2.5 percent of jobs are genuinely at risk under a full-scale AI rollout, noting that ‚Äútrue end-to-end automation is much harder than headlines suggest.‚Äù‚ÄúOver a third of jobs now require hybrid skill sets that combine technical literacy with human qualities machines can‚Äôt replicate,‚Äù he said.Georgios Koimisis, associate professor of finance at Manhattan University, echoed a similar skepticism.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a growing fear that artificial intelligence is wiping out jobs, but the reality is more complex,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúCompanies aren‚Äôt cutting workers simply because AI made them redundant. In an uncertain economy, firms want to appear modern and future-ready. Announcing an ‚ÄòAI transformation‚Äô reassures investors that management has a plan.‚ÄùKoimisis argues that some layoffs, framed as part of AI restructuring, are more about signaling discipline to shareholders than about reflecting genuine technological necessity.‚ÄúAI is changing not just how work is organized, but how value itself is defined,‚Äù he said.Izhar Haq, director of the School of Professional Accountancy at Long Island University, agrees that the slowing economy and business cycle are also contributing factors to recent job reductions.Haq told The Epoch Times that while the long-term economic effects of AI remain uncertain, ‚Äúwhite-collar analytical jobs are most at risk from AI integration, while manual labor jobs face risk from robotics.‚Äù TOPICS: Business/Economy; Computers/Internet; Society KEYWORDS: ai; jobs; unemployment Click here: to donate by Credit Card Or here: to donate by PayPal Or by mail to: Free Republic, LLC - PO Box 9771 - Fresno, CA 93794 Thank you very much and God bless you. Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search General/Chat Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson Similarly, the McKinsey Global Institute has projected that automation (a combination of AI and robotics) could displace up to 54 million workers in the United States by 2030.Meanwhile, a Goldman Sachs analysis projects that widespread AI adoption could displace 6 to 7 percent of the U.S. workforce, equivalent to millions of jobs.Goldman Sachs economists estimate that temporary unemployment spikes by roughly 0.3 percentage points for each percentage-point gain in productivity from labor-saving technology.Jobs Most at RiskA Society for Human Resource Management study, published on April 25, offers a detailed snapshot of U.S. employment exposure to AI.According to the report, 12.6 percent of jobs‚Äîapproximately 19.2 million positions‚Äîface a high or very high risk of automation-related displacement. Among them, 14 percent of blue-collar jobs, 12.3 percent of white-collar jobs, and 12.1 percent of service-sector jobs are considered at high risk.Meanwhile, a June 9 report from the freelance work platform Upwork identifies 120 jobs that are hard to be replaced by AI, including clinical, creative, and skilled trades roles.AI and Changing Nature of SkillsA December 2024 Harvard Business School paper shows that AI has a mixed impact on businesses‚Äô labor demand.In automation-prone roles, AI reduces the need for specialized expertise by simplifying complex tasks. In augmentation-prone roles, however, it boosts productivity and increases demand for advanced, complementary skill sets.‚ÄúAs generative AI continues to evolve, understanding its heterogeneous effects on labor demand is critical,‚Äù the authors wrote. ‚ÄúPolicymakers and business practitioners must recognize the dual forces of automation and augmentation to ensure that workers are equipped to adapt and thrive.‚ÄùAt the same time, research by Nobel laureate Daron Acemoglu and colleagues‚Äîpublished in the Journal of Labor Economics‚Äîshows that as establishments adopt AI, they reduce hiring in non-AI positions and shift skill requirements across remaining roles.Andy Zenkevich, founder and CEO of Epiic, a digital agency specializing in generative engine optimization (GEO), told The Epoch Times that the fear of mass AI-driven job losses is overstated.‚ÄúAmong the companies we work with in digital marketing‚Äîincluding major tech firms‚Äîlayoffs haven‚Äôt been the story,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúInstead, jobs are morphing. A junior copywriter becomes an ‚ÄòAI content editor,‚Äô responsible for prompt engineering, fact-checking, and editing AI-generated copy.‚ÄùZenkevich estimated that roughly 2.5 percent of jobs are genuinely at risk under a full-scale AI rollout, noting that ‚Äútrue end-to-end automation is much harder than headlines suggest.‚Äù‚ÄúOver a third of jobs now require hybrid skill sets that combine technical literacy with human qualities machines can‚Äôt replicate,‚Äù he said.Georgios Koimisis, associate professor of finance at Manhattan University, echoed a similar skepticism.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a growing fear that artificial intelligence is wiping out jobs, but the reality is more complex,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúCompanies aren‚Äôt cutting workers simply because AI made them redundant. In an uncertain economy, firms want to appear modern and future-ready. Announcing an ‚ÄòAI transformation‚Äô reassures investors that management has a plan.‚ÄùKoimisis argues that some layoffs, framed as part of AI restructuring, are more about signaling discipline to shareholders than about reflecting genuine technological necessity.‚ÄúAI is changing not just how work is organized, but how value itself is defined,‚Äù he said.Izhar Haq, director of the School of Professional Accountancy at Long Island University, agrees that the slowing economy and business cycle are also contributing factors to recent job reductions.Haq told The Epoch Times that while the long-term economic effects of AI remain uncertain, ‚Äúwhite-collar analytical jobs are most at risk from AI integration, while manual labor jobs face risk from robotics.‚Äù TOPICS: Business/Economy; Computers/Internet; Society KEYWORDS: ai; jobs; unemployment Click here: to donate by Credit Card Or here: to donate by PayPal Or by mail to: Free Republic, LLC - PO Box 9771 - Fresno, CA 93794 Thank you very much and God bless you. Tens of thousands of layoffs have been announced across major sectors in late October 2025, with UPS, Amazon, Intel and Nestl√© leading the cuts. Over 112,000 tech jobs alone have been eliminated this year, and broader corporate downsizing is accelerating. Just during October alone, UPS announced 48,000 job cuts, Amazon 14,000, Intel 24,000, Nestle 16,000, Accenture 11,000, Novo Nordisk 9,000, Applied Materials 1,444, Target 1,000, Charter Telecom 1,200 and CBS/Paramount 1,000. These are notable corporations cutting staff, but other major companies like JPMorgan Chase have implemented a hiring freeze across multiple divisions in late 2025, driven by its aggressive deployment of artificial intelligence and cost discipline. Managers have been instructed to avoid hiring unless absolutely necessary. 5 posted on 11/03/2025 9:02:54 PM PST by SeekAndFind [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 3 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind All of this screams to me, ‚ÄúWork for yourself!‚Äù 6 posted on 11/03/2025 9:28:31 PM PST by SaxxonWoods (Annnd....TRUMP IS RIGHT AGAIN.) An online AI chat is very common these days. Instead of 0, I type in HUMAN. Sometimes it takes typing human 2 or 3 times. I have also run into AI while using the telephone customer service. No matter what the "choices" from the AI are, I just repeat HUMAN until they transfer to a living, breathing person. Et tu? 14 posted on 11/04/2025 2:10:58 AM PST by Sirius Lee ("Never argue with a fool, onlookers may not be able to tell the difference.‚Äù) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: MMusson Yes. Fixing problems created by bad management and using AI to identify better ways of running operations and eliminating inefficiencies, waste, and useless jobs.Here's an example of what Palantir is doing with its clients using AI: Swiss Re: After installing Palantir's software, they cut reporting time by up to 80%, freed about 30% of underwriters‚Äô time, boosted data-team output by 50%, and earned back the entire cost of the system in 7 months, ending with a 170% return (independently audited). Airbus: Used Palantir to improve assembly of the A350 by about 30%‚Äîfewer delays, fewer mistakes, and more planes finished each month using the same factories and workers. BP: Runs virtual ‚Äúdigital twins‚Äù of oil platforms and fields so engineers can spot problems early, prevent breakdowns, and make better decisions before something goes wrong. National power company (unnamed): Used Palantir to map 10,000+ miles of power lines and find weak spots before they fail. These aren‚Äôt future promises‚Äîthey‚Äôre real improvements in speed, cost, reliability, and output. This is what applied AI actually looks like in the real world.Stronger companies create real jobs. 15 posted on 11/04/2025 2:18:15 AM PST by RoosterRedux (‚ÄúCritical thinking is hard; that‚Äôs why most people just jump to conclusions.‚Äù‚ÄîJung (paraphrased)) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 12 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind If you‚Äôre a low level coder, your days are numbered. If you‚Äôre a designer/engineer, AI is making your life easier as you don‚Äôt have to farm the work out to the aforementioned. If you‚Äôre a data analyst or financial manager, you are already prompting AI to build the queries to pull your data and create your decks. If not, you‚Äôve probably missed the boat. 16 posted on 11/04/2025 2:19:44 AM PST by Sirius Lee ("Never argue with a fool, onlookers may not be able to tell the difference.‚Äù) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 5 | View Replies] To: dpetty121263 ‚ÄúGuess there is always starvation...can‚Äôt work so no eats.‚Äù There‚Äôs ALWAYS electrical work... and Electrical Workers hold the key to shutting AI off. Yoits [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: minnesota_bound ...1/3rd of Hollywood jobs have disappeared. 48,000 gone. Most I suspect due to the terrible scold movies and tv shows they make but AI is replacing background players and set design builders etc. Some of that is due to the industry shift away from Hollywood. The Arri Alexa digital movie camera was released in 2010. Since then, movie producers had a more plentiful, less expensive, and better filming options than Hollywood could offer. The James Bond movie "Skyfall" (2012) was filmed using Alexa digital cameras and won the Academy Award for Best Cinematography. Add in Computer Generated Imagery and regular television shows can be filmed against a blue screen (or green screen), cutting back on set construction by instead using digital backgrounds created by lower cost overseas video editors. 20 posted on 11/04/2025 5:15:39 AM PST by T.B. In augmentation-prone roles, however, it boosts productivity and increases demand for advanced, complementary skill sets.‚ÄúAs generative AI continues to evolve, understanding its heterogeneous effects on labor demand is critical,‚Äù the authors wrote. ‚ÄúPolicymakers and business practitioners must recognize the dual forces of automation and augmentation to ensure that workers are equipped to adapt and thrive.‚ÄùAt the same time, research by Nobel laureate Daron Acemoglu and colleagues‚Äîpublished in the Journal of Labor Economics‚Äîshows that as establishments adopt AI, they reduce hiring in non-AI positions and shift skill requirements across remaining roles.Andy Zenkevich, founder and CEO of Epiic, a digital agency specializing in generative engine optimization (GEO), told The Epoch Times that the fear of mass AI-driven job losses is overstated.‚ÄúAmong the companies we work with in digital marketing‚Äîincluding major tech firms‚Äîlayoffs haven‚Äôt been the story,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúInstead, jobs are morphing. A junior copywriter becomes an ‚ÄòAI content editor,‚Äô responsible for prompt engineering, fact-checking, and editing AI-generated copy.‚ÄùZenkevich estimated that roughly 2.5 percent of jobs are genuinely at risk under a full-scale AI rollout, noting that ‚Äútrue end-to-end automation is much harder than headlines suggest.‚Äù‚ÄúOver a third of jobs now require hybrid skill sets that combine technical literacy with human qualities machines can‚Äôt replicate,‚Äù he said.Georgios Koimisis, associate professor of finance at Manhattan University, echoed a similar skepticism.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a growing fear that artificial intelligence is wiping out jobs, but the reality is more complex,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúCompanies aren‚Äôt cutting workers simply because AI made them redundant. In an uncertain economy, firms want to appear modern and future-ready. Announcing an ‚ÄòAI transformation‚Äô reassures investors that management has a plan.‚ÄùKoimisis argues that some layoffs, framed as part of AI restructuring, are more about signaling discipline to shareholders than about reflecting genuine technological necessity.‚ÄúAI is changing not just how work is organized, but how value itself is defined,‚Äù he said.Izhar Haq, director of the School of Professional Accountancy at Long Island University, agrees that the slowing economy and business cycle are also contributing factors to recent job reductions.Haq told The Epoch Times that while the long-term economic effects of AI remain uncertain, ‚Äúwhite-collar analytical jobs are most at risk from AI integration, while manual labor jobs face risk from robotics.‚Äù TOPICS: Business/Economy; Computers/Internet; Society KEYWORDS: ai; jobs; unemployment Click here: to donate by Credit Card Or here: to donate by PayPal Or by mail to: Free Republic, LLC - PO Box 9771 - Fresno, CA 93794 Thank you very much and God bless you. Fixing problems created by bad management and using AI to identify better ways of running operations and eliminating inefficiencies, waste, and useless jobs.Here's an example of what Palantir is doing with its clients using AI: Swiss Re: After installing Palantir's software, they cut reporting time by up to 80%, freed about 30% of underwriters‚Äô time, boosted data-team output by 50%, and earned back the entire cost of the system in 7 months, ending with a 170% return (independently audited). Airbus: Used Palantir to improve assembly of the A350 by about 30%‚Äîfewer delays, fewer mistakes, and more planes finished each month using the same factories and workers. BP: Runs virtual ‚Äúdigital twins‚Äù of oil platforms and fields so engineers can spot problems early, prevent breakdowns, and make better decisions before something goes wrong. National power company (unnamed): Used Palantir to map 10,000+ miles of power lines and find weak spots before they fail. These aren‚Äôt future promises‚Äîthey‚Äôre real improvements in speed, cost, reliability, and output. This is what applied AI actually looks like in the real world.Stronger companies create real jobs. 15 posted on 11/04/2025 2:18:15 AM PST by RoosterRedux (‚ÄúCritical thinking is hard; that‚Äôs why most people just jump to conclusions.‚Äù‚ÄîJung (paraphrased)) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 12 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind If you‚Äôre a low level coder, your days are numbered. If you‚Äôre a data analyst or financial manager, you are already prompting AI to build the queries to pull your data and create your decks. If not, you‚Äôve probably missed the boat. 16 posted on 11/04/2025 2:19:44 AM PST by Sirius Lee ("Never argue with a fool, onlookers may not be able to tell the difference.‚Äù) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 5 | View Replies] To: dpetty121263 ‚ÄúGuess there is always starvation...can‚Äôt work so no eats.‚Äù There‚Äôs ALWAYS electrical work... and Electrical Workers hold the key to shutting AI off. Yoits [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: minnesota_bound ...1/3rd of Hollywood jobs have disappeared. 48,000 gone. Most I suspect due to the terrible scold movies and tv shows they make but AI is replacing background players and set design builders etc. Some of that is due to the industry shift away from Hollywood. The Arri Alexa digital movie camera was released in 2010. Since then, movie producers had a more plentiful, less expensive, and better filming options than Hollywood could offer. The James Bond movie "Skyfall" (2012) was filmed using Alexa digital cameras and won the Academy Award for Best Cinematography. Add in Computer Generated Imagery and regular television shows can be filmed against a blue screen (or green screen), cutting back on set construction by instead using digital backgrounds created by lower cost overseas video editors. 20 posted on 11/04/2025 5:15:39 AM PST by T.B. Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search General/Chat Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson A Society for Human Resource Management study, published on April 25, offers a detailed snapshot of U.S. employment exposure to AI.According to the report, 12.6 percent of jobs‚Äîapproximately 19.2 million positions‚Äîface a high or very high risk of automation-related displacement. Among them, 14 percent of blue-collar jobs, 12.3 percent of white-collar jobs, and 12.1 percent of service-sector jobs are considered at high risk.Meanwhile, a June 9 report from the freelance work platform Upwork identifies 120 jobs that are hard to be replaced by AI, including clinical, creative, and skilled trades roles.AI and Changing Nature of SkillsA December 2024 Harvard Business School paper shows that AI has a mixed impact on businesses‚Äô labor demand.In automation-prone roles, AI reduces the need for specialized expertise by simplifying complex tasks. In augmentation-prone roles, however, it boosts productivity and increases demand for advanced, complementary skill sets.‚ÄúAs generative AI continues to evolve, understanding its heterogeneous effects on labor demand is critical,‚Äù the authors wrote. ‚ÄúPolicymakers and business practitioners must recognize the dual forces of automation and augmentation to ensure that workers are equipped to adapt and thrive.‚ÄùAt the same time, research by Nobel laureate Daron Acemoglu and colleagues‚Äîpublished in the Journal of Labor Economics‚Äîshows that as establishments adopt AI, they reduce hiring in non-AI positions and shift skill requirements across remaining roles.Andy Zenkevich, founder and CEO of Epiic, a digital agency specializing in generative engine optimization (GEO), told The Epoch Times that the fear of mass AI-driven job losses is overstated.‚ÄúAmong the companies we work with in digital marketing‚Äîincluding major tech firms‚Äîlayoffs haven‚Äôt been the story,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúInstead, jobs are morphing. A junior copywriter becomes an ‚ÄòAI content editor,‚Äô responsible for prompt engineering, fact-checking, and editing AI-generated copy.‚ÄùZenkevich estimated that roughly 2.5 percent of jobs are genuinely at risk under a full-scale AI rollout, noting that ‚Äútrue end-to-end automation is much harder than headlines suggest.‚Äù‚ÄúOver a third of jobs now require hybrid skill sets that combine technical literacy with human qualities machines can‚Äôt replicate,‚Äù he said.Georgios Koimisis, associate professor of finance at Manhattan University, echoed a similar skepticism.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a growing fear that artificial intelligence is wiping out jobs, but the reality is more complex,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúCompanies aren‚Äôt cutting workers simply because AI made them redundant. In an uncertain economy, firms want to appear modern and future-ready. Announcing an ‚ÄòAI transformation‚Äô reassures investors that management has a plan.‚ÄùKoimisis argues that some layoffs, framed as part of AI restructuring, are more about signaling discipline to shareholders than about reflecting genuine technological necessity.‚ÄúAI is changing not just how work is organized, but how value itself is defined,‚Äù he said.Izhar Haq, director of the School of Professional Accountancy at Long Island University, agrees that the slowing economy and business cycle are also contributing factors to recent job reductions.Haq told The Epoch Times that while the long-term economic effects of AI remain uncertain, ‚Äúwhite-collar analytical jobs are most at risk from AI integration, while manual labor jobs face risk from robotics.‚Äù TOPICS: Business/Economy; Computers/Internet; Society KEYWORDS: ai; jobs; unemployment Click here: to donate by Credit Card Or here: to donate by PayPal Or by mail to: Free Republic, LLC - PO Box 9771 - Fresno, CA 93794 Thank you very much and God bless you. I threw contracts to providers simply because a human answered the phone. No matter what the "choices" from the AI are, I just repeat HUMAN until they transfer to a living, breathing person. Et tu? 14 posted on 11/04/2025 2:10:58 AM PST by Sirius Lee ("Never argue with a fool, onlookers may not be able to tell the difference.‚Äù) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: MMusson Yes. Fixing problems created by bad management and using AI to identify better ways of running operations and eliminating inefficiencies, waste, and useless jobs.Here's an example of what Palantir is doing with its clients using AI: Swiss Re: After installing Palantir's software, they cut reporting time by up to 80%, freed about 30% of underwriters‚Äô time, boosted data-team output by 50%, and earned back the entire cost of the system in 7 months, ending with a 170% return (independently audited). Airbus: Used Palantir to improve assembly of the A350 by about 30%‚Äîfewer delays, fewer mistakes, and more planes finished each month using the same factories and workers. BP: Runs virtual ‚Äúdigital twins‚Äù of oil platforms and fields so engineers can spot problems early, prevent breakdowns, and make better decisions before something goes wrong. National power company (unnamed): Used Palantir to map 10,000+ miles of power lines and find weak spots before they fail. These aren‚Äôt future promises‚Äîthey‚Äôre real improvements in speed, cost, reliability, and output. This is what applied AI actually looks like in the real world.Stronger companies create real jobs. 15 posted on 11/04/2025 2:18:15 AM PST by RoosterRedux (‚ÄúCritical thinking is hard; that‚Äôs why most people just jump to conclusions.‚Äù‚ÄîJung (paraphrased)) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 12 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind If you‚Äôre a low level coder, your days are numbered. If you‚Äôre a designer/engineer, AI is making your life easier as you don‚Äôt have to farm the work out to the aforementioned. If you‚Äôre a data analyst or financial manager, you are already prompting AI to build the queries to pull your data and create your decks. If not, you‚Äôve probably missed the boat. 16 posted on 11/04/2025 2:19:44 AM PST by Sirius Lee ("Never argue with a fool, onlookers may not be able to tell the difference.‚Äù) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 5 | View Replies] To: dpetty121263 ‚ÄúGuess there is always starvation...can‚Äôt work so no eats.‚Äù There‚Äôs ALWAYS electrical work... and Electrical Workers hold the key to shutting AI off. Yoits [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: minnesota_bound ...1/3rd of Hollywood jobs have disappeared. 48,000 gone. Most I suspect due to the terrible scold movies and tv shows they make but AI is replacing background players and set design builders etc. Some of that is due to the industry shift away from Hollywood. The Arri Alexa digital movie camera was released in 2010. Since then, movie producers had a more plentiful, less expensive, and better filming options than Hollywood could offer. The James Bond movie "Skyfall" (2012) was filmed using Alexa digital cameras and won the Academy Award for Best Cinematography. Add in Computer Generated Imagery and regular television shows can be filmed against a blue screen (or green screen), cutting back on set construction by instead using digital backgrounds created by lower cost overseas video editors. 20 posted on 11/04/2025 5:15:39 AM PST by T.B. Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search General/Chat Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson Meanwhile, a June 9 report from the freelance work platform Upwork identifies 120 jobs that are hard to be replaced by AI, including clinical, creative, and skilled trades roles.AI and Changing Nature of SkillsA December 2024 Harvard Business School paper shows that AI has a mixed impact on businesses‚Äô labor demand.In automation-prone roles, AI reduces the need for specialized expertise by simplifying complex tasks. In augmentation-prone roles, however, it boosts productivity and increases demand for advanced, complementary skill sets.‚ÄúAs generative AI continues to evolve, understanding its heterogeneous effects on labor demand is critical,‚Äù the authors wrote. ‚ÄúPolicymakers and business practitioners must recognize the dual forces of automation and augmentation to ensure that workers are equipped to adapt and thrive.‚ÄùAt the same time, research by Nobel laureate Daron Acemoglu and colleagues‚Äîpublished in the Journal of Labor Economics‚Äîshows that as establishments adopt AI, they reduce hiring in non-AI positions and shift skill requirements across remaining roles.Andy Zenkevich, founder and CEO of Epiic, a digital agency specializing in generative engine optimization (GEO), told The Epoch Times that the fear of mass AI-driven job losses is overstated.‚ÄúAmong the companies we work with in digital marketing‚Äîincluding major tech firms‚Äîlayoffs haven‚Äôt been the story,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúInstead, jobs are morphing. A junior copywriter becomes an ‚ÄòAI content editor,‚Äô responsible for prompt engineering, fact-checking, and editing AI-generated copy.‚ÄùZenkevich estimated that roughly 2.5 percent of jobs are genuinely at risk under a full-scale AI rollout, noting that ‚Äútrue end-to-end automation is much harder than headlines suggest.‚Äù‚ÄúOver a third of jobs now require hybrid skill sets that combine technical literacy with human qualities machines can‚Äôt replicate,‚Äù he said.Georgios Koimisis, associate professor of finance at Manhattan University, echoed a similar skepticism.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a growing fear that artificial intelligence is wiping out jobs, but the reality is more complex,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúCompanies aren‚Äôt cutting workers simply because AI made them redundant. In an uncertain economy, firms want to appear modern and future-ready. Announcing an ‚ÄòAI transformation‚Äô reassures investors that management has a plan.‚ÄùKoimisis argues that some layoffs, framed as part of AI restructuring, are more about signaling discipline to shareholders than about reflecting genuine technological necessity.‚ÄúAI is changing not just how work is organized, but how value itself is defined,‚Äù he said.Izhar Haq, director of the School of Professional Accountancy at Long Island University, agrees that the slowing economy and business cycle are also contributing factors to recent job reductions.Haq told The Epoch Times that while the long-term economic effects of AI remain uncertain, ‚Äúwhite-collar analytical jobs are most at risk from AI integration, while manual labor jobs face risk from robotics.‚Äù TOPICS: Business/Economy; Computers/Internet; Society KEYWORDS: ai; jobs; unemployment Click here: to donate by Credit Card Or here: to donate by PayPal Or by mail to: Free Republic, LLC - PO Box 9771 - Fresno, CA 93794 Thank you very much and God bless you. In augmentation-prone roles, however, it boosts productivity and increases demand for advanced, complementary skill sets.‚ÄúAs generative AI continues to evolve, understanding its heterogeneous effects on labor demand is critical,‚Äù the authors wrote. ‚ÄúPolicymakers and business practitioners must recognize the dual forces of automation and augmentation to ensure that workers are equipped to adapt and thrive.‚ÄùAt the same time, research by Nobel laureate Daron Acemoglu and colleagues‚Äîpublished in the Journal of Labor Economics‚Äîshows that as establishments adopt AI, they reduce hiring in non-AI positions and shift skill requirements across remaining roles.Andy Zenkevich, founder and CEO of Epiic, a digital agency specializing in generative engine optimization (GEO), told The Epoch Times that the fear of mass AI-driven job losses is overstated.‚ÄúAmong the companies we work with in digital marketing‚Äîincluding major tech firms‚Äîlayoffs haven‚Äôt been the story,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúInstead, jobs are morphing. National power company (unnamed): Used Palantir to map 10,000+ miles of power lines and find weak spots before they fail. These aren‚Äôt future promises‚Äîthey‚Äôre real improvements in speed, cost, reliability, and output. This is what applied AI actually looks like in the real world.Stronger companies create real jobs. 15 posted on 11/04/2025 2:18:15 AM PST by RoosterRedux (‚ÄúCritical thinking is hard; that‚Äôs why most people just jump to conclusions.‚Äù‚ÄîJung (paraphrased)) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 12 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind If you‚Äôre a low level coder, your days are numbered. If you‚Äôre a designer/engineer, AI is making your life easier as you don‚Äôt have to farm the work out to the aforementioned. If you‚Äôre a data analyst or financial manager, you are already prompting AI to build the queries to pull your data and create your decks. If not, you‚Äôve probably missed the boat. 16 posted on 11/04/2025 2:19:44 AM PST by Sirius Lee ("Never argue with a fool, onlookers may not be able to tell the difference.‚Äù) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 5 | View Replies] To: dpetty121263 ‚ÄúGuess there is always starvation...can‚Äôt work so no eats.‚Äù There‚Äôs ALWAYS electrical work... and Electrical Workers hold the key to shutting AI off. Yoits [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: minnesota_bound ...1/3rd of Hollywood jobs have disappeared. 48,000 gone. Most I suspect due to the terrible scold movies and tv shows they make but AI is replacing background players and set design builders etc. Some of that is due to the industry shift away from Hollywood. The Arri Alexa digital movie camera was released in 2010. Since then, movie producers had a more plentiful, less expensive, and better filming options than Hollywood could offer. The James Bond movie "Skyfall" (2012) was filmed using Alexa digital cameras and won the Academy Award for Best Cinematography. Add in Computer Generated Imagery and regular television shows can be filmed against a blue screen (or green screen), cutting back on set construction by instead using digital backgrounds created by lower cost overseas video editors. 20 posted on 11/04/2025 5:15:39 AM PST by T.B. Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search General/Chat Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson In automation-prone roles, AI reduces the need for specialized expertise by simplifying complex tasks. In augmentation-prone roles, however, it boosts productivity and increases demand for advanced, complementary skill sets.‚ÄúAs generative AI continues to evolve, understanding its heterogeneous effects on labor demand is critical,‚Äù the authors wrote. ‚ÄúPolicymakers and business practitioners must recognize the dual forces of automation and augmentation to ensure that workers are equipped to adapt and thrive.‚ÄùAt the same time, research by Nobel laureate Daron Acemoglu and colleagues‚Äîpublished in the Journal of Labor Economics‚Äîshows that as establishments adopt AI, they reduce hiring in non-AI positions and shift skill requirements across remaining roles.Andy Zenkevich, founder and CEO of Epiic, a digital agency specializing in generative engine optimization (GEO), told The Epoch Times that the fear of mass AI-driven job losses is overstated.‚ÄúAmong the companies we work with in digital marketing‚Äîincluding major tech firms‚Äîlayoffs haven‚Äôt been the story,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúInstead, jobs are morphing. A junior copywriter becomes an ‚ÄòAI content editor,‚Äô responsible for prompt engineering, fact-checking, and editing AI-generated copy.‚ÄùZenkevich estimated that roughly 2.5 percent of jobs are genuinely at risk under a full-scale AI rollout, noting that ‚Äútrue end-to-end automation is much harder than headlines suggest.‚Äù‚ÄúOver a third of jobs now require hybrid skill sets that combine technical literacy with human qualities machines can‚Äôt replicate,‚Äù he said.Georgios Koimisis, associate professor of finance at Manhattan University, echoed a similar skepticism.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a growing fear that artificial intelligence is wiping out jobs, but the reality is more complex,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúCompanies aren‚Äôt cutting workers simply because AI made them redundant. In an uncertain economy, firms want to appear modern and future-ready. Announcing an ‚ÄòAI transformation‚Äô reassures investors that management has a plan.‚ÄùKoimisis argues that some layoffs, framed as part of AI restructuring, are more about signaling discipline to shareholders than about reflecting genuine technological necessity.‚ÄúAI is changing not just how work is organized, but how value itself is defined,‚Äù he said.Izhar Haq, director of the School of Professional Accountancy at Long Island University, agrees that the slowing economy and business cycle are also contributing factors to recent job reductions.Haq told The Epoch Times that while the long-term economic effects of AI remain uncertain, ‚Äúwhite-collar analytical jobs are most at risk from AI integration, while manual labor jobs face risk from robotics.‚Äù TOPICS: Business/Economy; Computers/Internet; Society KEYWORDS: ai; jobs; unemployment Click here: to donate by Credit Card Or here: to donate by PayPal Or by mail to: Free Republic, LLC - PO Box 9771 - Fresno, CA 93794 Thank you very much and God bless you. Tens of thousands of layoffs have been announced across major sectors in late October 2025, with UPS, Amazon, Intel and Nestl√© leading the cuts. Over 112,000 tech jobs alone have been eliminated this year, and broader corporate downsizing is accelerating. Just during October alone, UPS announced 48,000 job cuts, Amazon 14,000, Intel 24,000, Nestle 16,000, Accenture 11,000, Novo Nordisk 9,000, Applied Materials 1,444, Target 1,000, Charter Telecom 1,200 and CBS/Paramount 1,000. Fixing problems created by bad management and using AI to identify better ways of running operations and eliminating inefficiencies, waste, and useless jobs.Here's an example of what Palantir is doing with its clients using AI: Swiss Re: After installing Palantir's software, they cut reporting time by up to 80%, freed about 30% of underwriters‚Äô time, boosted data-team output by 50%, and earned back the entire cost of the system in 7 months, ending with a 170% return (independently audited). Airbus: Used Palantir to improve assembly of the A350 by about 30%‚Äîfewer delays, fewer mistakes, and more planes finished each month using the same factories and workers. BP: Runs virtual ‚Äúdigital twins‚Äù of oil platforms and fields so engineers can spot problems early, prevent breakdowns, and make better decisions before something goes wrong. National power company (unnamed): Used Palantir to map 10,000+ miles of power lines and find weak spots before they fail. A junior copywriter becomes an ‚ÄòAI content editor,‚Äô responsible for prompt engineering, fact-checking, and editing AI-generated copy.‚ÄùZenkevich estimated that roughly 2.5 percent of jobs are genuinely at risk under a full-scale AI rollout, noting that ‚Äútrue end-to-end automation is much harder than headlines suggest.‚Äù‚ÄúOver a third of jobs now require hybrid skill sets that combine technical literacy with human qualities machines can‚Äôt replicate,‚Äù he said.Georgios Koimisis, associate professor of finance at Manhattan University, echoed a similar skepticism.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a growing fear that artificial intelligence is wiping out jobs, but the reality is more complex,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúCompanies aren‚Äôt cutting workers simply because AI made them redundant. In an uncertain economy, firms want to appear modern and future-ready. Announcing an ‚ÄòAI transformation‚Äô reassures investors that management has a plan.‚ÄùKoimisis argues that some layoffs, framed as part of AI restructuring, are more about signaling discipline to shareholders than about reflecting genuine technological necessity.‚ÄúAI is changing not just how work is organized, but how value itself is defined,‚Äù he said.Izhar Haq, director of the School of Professional Accountancy at Long Island University, agrees that the slowing economy and business cycle are also contributing factors to recent job reductions.Haq told The Epoch Times that while the long-term economic effects of AI remain uncertain, ‚Äúwhite-collar analytical jobs are most at risk from AI integration, while manual labor jobs face risk from robotics.‚Äù TOPICS: Business/Economy; Computers/Internet; Society KEYWORDS: ai; jobs; unemployment Click here: to donate by Credit Card Or here: to donate by PayPal Or by mail to: Free Republic, LLC - PO Box 9771 - Fresno, CA 93794 Thank you very much and God bless you. Tens of thousands of layoffs have been announced across major sectors in late October 2025, with UPS, Amazon, Intel and Nestl√© leading the cuts. Over 112,000 tech jobs alone have been eliminated this year, and broader corporate downsizing is accelerating. Just during October alone, UPS announced 48,000 job cuts, Amazon 14,000, Intel 24,000, Nestle 16,000, Accenture 11,000, Novo Nordisk 9,000, Applied Materials 1,444, Target 1,000, Charter Telecom 1,200 and CBS/Paramount 1,000. These are notable corporations cutting staff, but other major companies like JPMorgan Chase have implemented a hiring freeze across multiple divisions in late 2025, driven by its aggressive deployment of artificial intelligence and cost discipline. Managers have been instructed to avoid hiring unless absolutely necessary. 5 posted on 11/03/2025 9:02:54 PM PST by SeekAndFind [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 3 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind All of this screams to me, ‚ÄúWork for yourself!‚Äù 6 posted on 11/03/2025 9:28:31 PM PST by SaxxonWoods (Annnd....TRUMP IS RIGHT AGAIN.) Fixing problems created by bad management and using AI to identify better ways of running operations and eliminating inefficiencies, waste, and useless jobs.Here's an example of what Palantir is doing with its clients using AI: Swiss Re: After installing Palantir's software, they cut reporting time by up to 80%, freed about 30% of underwriters‚Äô time, boosted data-team output by 50%, and earned back the entire cost of the system in 7 months, ending with a 170% return (independently audited). Airbus: Used Palantir to improve assembly of the A350 by about 30%‚Äîfewer delays, fewer mistakes, and more planes finished each month using the same factories and workers. BP: Runs virtual ‚Äúdigital twins‚Äù of oil platforms and fields so engineers can spot problems early, prevent breakdowns, and make better decisions before something goes wrong. National power company (unnamed): Used Palantir to map 10,000+ miles of power lines and find weak spots before they fail. These aren‚Äôt future promises‚Äîthey‚Äôre real improvements in speed, cost, reliability, and output. This is what applied AI actually looks like in the real world.Stronger companies create real jobs. 15 posted on 11/04/2025 2:18:15 AM PST by RoosterRedux (‚ÄúCritical thinking is hard; that‚Äôs why most people just jump to conclusions.‚Äù‚ÄîJung (paraphrased)) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 12 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind If you‚Äôre a low level coder, your days are numbered. If you‚Äôre a data analyst or financial manager, you are already prompting AI to build the queries to pull your data and create your decks. If not, you‚Äôve probably missed the boat. 16 posted on 11/04/2025 2:19:44 AM PST by Sirius Lee ("Never argue with a fool, onlookers may not be able to tell the difference.‚Äù) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 5 | View Replies] To: dpetty121263 ‚ÄúGuess there is always starvation...can‚Äôt work so no eats.‚Äù There‚Äôs ALWAYS electrical work... and Electrical Workers hold the key to shutting AI off. Yoits [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: minnesota_bound ...1/3rd of Hollywood jobs have disappeared. 48,000 gone. Most I suspect due to the terrible scold movies and tv shows they make but AI is replacing background players and set design builders etc. Some of that is due to the industry shift away from Hollywood. The Arri Alexa digital movie camera was released in 2010. Since then, movie producers had a more plentiful, less expensive, and better filming options than Hollywood could offer. The James Bond movie "Skyfall" (2012) was filmed using Alexa digital cameras and won the Academy Award for Best Cinematography. Add in Computer Generated Imagery and regular television shows can be filmed against a blue screen (or green screen), cutting back on set construction by instead using digital backgrounds created by lower cost overseas video editors. 20 posted on 11/04/2025 5:15:39 AM PST by T.B. Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search General/Chat Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson Andy Zenkevich, founder and CEO of Epiic, a digital agency specializing in generative engine optimization (GEO), told The Epoch Times that the fear of mass AI-driven job losses is overstated.‚ÄúAmong the companies we work with in digital marketing‚Äîincluding major tech firms‚Äîlayoffs haven‚Äôt been the story,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúInstead, jobs are morphing. A junior copywriter becomes an ‚ÄòAI content editor,‚Äô responsible for prompt engineering, fact-checking, and editing AI-generated copy.‚ÄùZenkevich estimated that roughly 2.5 percent of jobs are genuinely at risk under a full-scale AI rollout, noting that ‚Äútrue end-to-end automation is much harder than headlines suggest.‚Äù‚ÄúOver a third of jobs now require hybrid skill sets that combine technical literacy with human qualities machines can‚Äôt replicate,‚Äù he said.Georgios Koimisis, associate professor of finance at Manhattan University, echoed a similar skepticism.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a growing fear that artificial intelligence is wiping out jobs, but the reality is more complex,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúCompanies aren‚Äôt cutting workers simply because AI made them redundant. In an uncertain economy, firms want to appear modern and future-ready. Announcing an ‚ÄòAI transformation‚Äô reassures investors that management has a plan.‚ÄùKoimisis argues that some layoffs, framed as part of AI restructuring, are more about signaling discipline to shareholders than about reflecting genuine technological necessity.‚ÄúAI is changing not just how work is organized, but how value itself is defined,‚Äù he said.Izhar Haq, director of the School of Professional Accountancy at Long Island University, agrees that the slowing economy and business cycle are also contributing factors to recent job reductions.Haq told The Epoch Times that while the long-term economic effects of AI remain uncertain, ‚Äúwhite-collar analytical jobs are most at risk from AI integration, while manual labor jobs face risk from robotics.‚Äù TOPICS: Business/Economy; Computers/Internet; Society KEYWORDS: ai; jobs; unemployment Click here: to donate by Credit Card Or here: to donate by PayPal Or by mail to: Free Republic, LLC - PO Box 9771 - Fresno, CA 93794 Thank you very much and God bless you. Et tu, Epoch Times? Et tu? 14 posted on 11/04/2025 2:10:58 AM PST by Sirius Lee ("Never argue with a fool, onlookers may not be able to tell the difference.‚Äù) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: MMusson Yes. Fixing problems created by bad management and using AI to identify better ways of running operations and eliminating inefficiencies, waste, and useless jobs.Here's an example of what Palantir is doing with its clients using AI: Swiss Re: After installing Palantir's software, they cut reporting time by up to 80%, freed about 30% of underwriters‚Äô time, boosted data-team output by 50%, and earned back the entire cost of the system in 7 months, ending with a 170% return (independently audited). Airbus: Used Palantir to improve assembly of the A350 by about 30%‚Äîfewer delays, fewer mistakes, and more planes finished each month using the same factories and workers. BP: Runs virtual ‚Äúdigital twins‚Äù of oil platforms and fields so engineers can spot problems early, prevent breakdowns, and make better decisions before something goes wrong. National power company (unnamed): Used Palantir to map 10,000+ miles of power lines and find weak spots before they fail. These aren‚Äôt future promises‚Äîthey‚Äôre real improvements in speed, cost, reliability, and output. This is what applied AI actually looks like in the real world.Stronger companies create real jobs. 15 posted on 11/04/2025 2:18:15 AM PST by RoosterRedux (‚ÄúCritical thinking is hard; that‚Äôs why most people just jump to conclusions.‚Äù‚ÄîJung (paraphrased)) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 12 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind If you‚Äôre a low level coder, your days are numbered. If you‚Äôre a designer/engineer, AI is making your life easier as you don‚Äôt have to farm the work out to the aforementioned. If you‚Äôre a data analyst or financial manager, you are already prompting AI to build the queries to pull your data and create your decks. If not, you‚Äôve probably missed the boat. 16 posted on 11/04/2025 2:19:44 AM PST by Sirius Lee ("Never argue with a fool, onlookers may not be able to tell the difference.‚Äù) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 5 | View Replies] To: dpetty121263 ‚ÄúGuess there is always starvation...can‚Äôt work so no eats.‚Äù There‚Äôs ALWAYS electrical work... and Electrical Workers hold the key to shutting AI off. Job security. 17 posted on 11/04/2025 4:37:23 AM PST by Clutch Martin ("The dawn cracks hard like a bull whip and it ain't taking no lip from the night before" Tom Waits) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 2 | View Replies] To: Clutch Martin Well I already got that skill...working with that kind of voltage is a life ender... 18 posted on 11/04/2025 4:50:56 AM PST by dpetty121263 [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 17 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind From the article: Some major companies have recently triggered a wave of layoffs... Most cited artificial intelligence (AI) integration and automation... They're blaming the "AI" boogeyman but it's the automation and lower cost Indian programmers supporting that automation. 19 posted on 11/04/2025 4:57:40 AM PST by T.B. Yoits [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: minnesota_bound ...1/3rd of Hollywood jobs have disappeared. 48,000 gone. Most I suspect due to the terrible scold movies and tv shows they make but AI is replacing background players and set design builders etc. Some of that is due to the industry shift away from Hollywood. The Arri Alexa digital movie camera was released in 2010. Since then, movie producers had a more plentiful, less expensive, and better filming options than Hollywood could offer. The James Bond movie "Skyfall" (2012) was filmed using Alexa digital cameras and won the Academy Award for Best Cinematography. Add in Computer Generated Imagery and regular television shows can be filmed against a blue screen (or green screen), cutting back on set construction by instead using digital backgrounds created by lower cost overseas video editors. 20 posted on 11/04/2025 5:15:39 AM PST by T.B. Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search General/Chat Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson Zenkevich estimated that roughly 2.5 percent of jobs are genuinely at risk under a full-scale AI rollout, noting that ‚Äútrue end-to-end automation is much harder than headlines suggest.‚Äù‚ÄúOver a third of jobs now require hybrid skill sets that combine technical literacy with human qualities machines can‚Äôt replicate,‚Äù he said.Georgios Koimisis, associate professor of finance at Manhattan University, echoed a similar skepticism.‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a growing fear that artificial intelligence is wiping out jobs, but the reality is more complex,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúCompanies aren‚Äôt cutting workers simply because AI made them redundant. In an uncertain economy, firms want to appear modern and future-ready. Announcing an ‚ÄòAI transformation‚Äô reassures investors that management has a plan.‚ÄùKoimisis argues that some layoffs, framed as part of AI restructuring, are more about signaling discipline to shareholders than about reflecting genuine technological necessity.‚ÄúAI is changing not just how work is organized, but how value itself is defined,‚Äù he said.Izhar Haq, director of the School of Professional Accountancy at Long Island University, agrees that the slowing economy and business cycle are also contributing factors to recent job reductions.Haq told The Epoch Times that while the long-term economic effects of AI remain uncertain, ‚Äúwhite-collar analytical jobs are most at risk from AI integration, while manual labor jobs face risk from robotics.‚Äù TOPICS: Business/Economy; Computers/Internet; Society KEYWORDS: ai; jobs; unemployment Click here: to donate by Credit Card Or here: to donate by PayPal Or by mail to: Free Republic, LLC - PO Box 9771 - Fresno, CA 93794 Thank you very much and God bless you. Tens of thousands of layoffs have been announced across major sectors in late October 2025, with UPS, Amazon, Intel and Nestl√© leading the cuts. Over 112,000 tech jobs alone have been eliminated this year, and broader corporate downsizing is accelerating. Just during October alone, UPS announced 48,000 job cuts, Amazon 14,000, Intel 24,000, Nestle 16,000, Accenture 11,000, Novo Nordisk 9,000, Applied Materials 1,444, Target 1,000, Charter Telecom 1,200 and CBS/Paramount 1,000. These are notable corporations cutting staff, but other major companies like JPMorgan Chase have implemented a hiring freeze across multiple divisions in late 2025, driven by its aggressive deployment of artificial intelligence and cost discipline. Managers have been instructed to avoid hiring unless absolutely necessary. 5 posted on 11/03/2025 9:02:54 PM PST by SeekAndFind [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 3 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind All of this screams to me, ‚ÄúWork for yourself!‚Äù 6 posted on 11/03/2025 9:28:31 PM PST by SaxxonWoods (Annnd....TRUMP IS RIGHT AGAIN.) Tens of thousands of layoffs have been announced across major sectors in late October 2025, with UPS, Amazon, Intel and Nestl√© leading the cuts. Over 112,000 tech jobs alone have been eliminated this year, and broader corporate downsizing is accelerating. Just during October alone, UPS announced 48,000 job cuts, Amazon 14,000, Intel 24,000, Nestle 16,000, Accenture 11,000, Novo Nordisk 9,000, Applied Materials 1,444, Target 1,000, Charter Telecom 1,200 and CBS/Paramount 1,000. These are notable corporations cutting staff, but other major companies like JPMorgan Chase have implemented a hiring freeze across multiple divisions in late 2025, driven by its aggressive deployment of artificial intelligence and cost discipline. Managers have been instructed to avoid hiring unless absolutely necessary. 5 posted on 11/03/2025 9:02:54 PM PST by SeekAndFind [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 3 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind All of this screams to me, ‚ÄúWork for yourself!‚Äù 6 posted on 11/03/2025 9:28:31 PM PST by SaxxonWoods (Annnd....TRUMP IS RIGHT AGAIN.) I threw contracts to providers simply because a human answered the phone. All it takes is one trip through ‚Äúautomated phone hell‚Äù to make up the price difference for parts. 7 posted on 11/03/2025 9:50:48 PM PST by dagunk [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind customer support In the old days of touchtone phones, I would just press 0 to find a human. An online AI chat is very common these days. Instead of 0, I type in HUMAN. Sometimes it takes typing human 2 or 3 times. I have also run into AI while using the telephone customer service. No matter what the "choices" from the AI are, I just repeat HUMAN until they transfer to a living, breathing person. PS - I wonder if some young entrepreneur will develop an AI customer service with a thick East Indian accent. 8 posted on 11/03/2025 10:40:21 PM PST by Ronaldus Magnus III (Do, or do not, there is no try ) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind I recently read that 1/3rd of hollywood jobs have disappeared. 48,000 gone. Et tu? 14 posted on 11/04/2025 2:10:58 AM PST by Sirius Lee ("Never argue with a fool, onlookers may not be able to tell the difference.‚Äù) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: MMusson Yes. Fixing problems created by bad management and using AI to identify better ways of running operations and eliminating inefficiencies, waste, and useless jobs.Here's an example of what Palantir is doing with its clients using AI: Swiss Re: After installing Palantir's software, they cut reporting time by up to 80%, freed about 30% of underwriters‚Äô time, boosted data-team output by 50%, and earned back the entire cost of the system in 7 months, ending with a 170% return (independently audited). Airbus: Used Palantir to improve assembly of the A350 by about 30%‚Äîfewer delays, fewer mistakes, and more planes finished each month using the same factories and workers. BP: Runs virtual ‚Äúdigital twins‚Äù of oil platforms and fields so engineers can spot problems early, prevent breakdowns, and make better decisions before something goes wrong. National power company (unnamed): Used Palantir to map 10,000+ miles of power lines and find weak spots before they fail. These aren‚Äôt future promises‚Äîthey‚Äôre real improvements in speed, cost, reliability, and output. This is what applied AI actually looks like in the real world.Stronger companies create real jobs. 15 posted on 11/04/2025 2:18:15 AM PST by RoosterRedux (‚ÄúCritical thinking is hard; that‚Äôs why most people just jump to conclusions.‚Äù‚ÄîJung (paraphrased)) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 12 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind If you‚Äôre a low level coder, your days are numbered. If you‚Äôre a designer/engineer, AI is making your life easier as you don‚Äôt have to farm the work out to the aforementioned. If you‚Äôre a data analyst or financial manager, you are already prompting AI to build the queries to pull your data and create your decks. If not, you‚Äôve probably missed the boat. 16 posted on 11/04/2025 2:19:44 AM PST by Sirius Lee ("Never argue with a fool, onlookers may not be able to tell the difference.‚Äù) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 5 | View Replies] To: dpetty121263 ‚ÄúGuess there is always starvation...can‚Äôt work so no eats.‚Äù There‚Äôs ALWAYS electrical work... and Electrical Workers hold the key to shutting AI off. Job security. 17 posted on 11/04/2025 4:37:23 AM PST by Clutch Martin ("The dawn cracks hard like a bull whip and it ain't taking no lip from the night before" Tom Waits) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 2 | View Replies] To: Clutch Martin Well I already got that skill...working with that kind of voltage is a life ender... 18 posted on 11/04/2025 4:50:56 AM PST by dpetty121263 [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 17 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind From the article: Some major companies have recently triggered a wave of layoffs... Most cited artificial intelligence (AI) integration and automation... They're blaming the "AI" boogeyman but it's the automation and lower cost Indian programmers supporting that automation. 19 posted on 11/04/2025 4:57:40 AM PST by T.B. Yoits [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies] To: minnesota_bound ...1/3rd of Hollywood jobs have disappeared. 48,000 gone. Most I suspect due to the terrible scold movies and tv shows they make but AI is replacing background players and set design builders etc. Some of that is due to the industry shift away from Hollywood. The Arri Alexa digital movie camera was released in 2010. Since then, movie producers had a more plentiful, less expensive, and better filming options than Hollywood could offer. The James Bond movie "Skyfall" (2012) was filmed using Alexa digital cameras and won the Academy Award for Best Cinematography. Add in Computer Generated Imagery and regular television shows can be filmed against a blue screen (or green screen), cutting back on set construction by instead using digital backgrounds created by lower cost overseas video editors. 20 posted on 11/04/2025 5:15:39 AM PST by T.B. Free Republic Browse ¬∑ Search General/Chat Topics ¬∑ Post Article FreeRepublic, LLC, PO BOX 9771, FRESNO, CA 93794 FreeRepublic.com is powered by software copyright 2000-2008 John Robinson ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a growing fear that artificial intelligence is wiping out jobs, but the reality is more complex,‚Äù he told The Epoch Times. ‚ÄúCompanies aren‚Äôt cutting workers simply because AI made them redundant. In an uncertain economy, firms want to appear modern and future-ready. Announcing an ‚ÄòAI transformation‚Äô reassures investors that management has a plan.‚ÄùKoimisis argues that some layoffs, framed as part of AI restructuring, are more about signaling discipline to shareholders than about reflecting genuine technological necessity.‚ÄúAI is changing not just how work is organized, but how value itself is defined,‚Äù he said.Izhar Haq, director of the School of Professional Accountancy at Long Island University, agrees that the slowing economy and business cycle are also contributing factors to recent job reductions.Haq told The Epoch Times that while the long-term economic effects of AI remain uncertain, ‚Äúwhite-collar analytical jobs are most at risk from AI integration, while manual labor jobs face risk from robotics.‚Äù TOPICS: Business/Economy; Computers/Internet; Society KEYWORDS: ai; jobs; unemployment Click here: to donate by Credit Card Or here: to donate by PayPal Or by mail to: Free Republic, LLC - PO Box 9771 - Fresno, CA 93794 Thank you very much and God bless you. Most I suspect due to the terrible scold movies and tv shows they make but AI is replacing background players and set design builders etc. Some of that is due to the industry shift away from Hollywood. The Arri Alexa digital movie camera was released in 2010. Since then, movie producers had a more plentiful, less expensive, and better filming options than Hollywood could offer. The James Bond movie "Skyfall" (2012) was filmed using Alexa digital cameras and won the Academy Award for Best Cinematography. Add in Computer Generated Imagery and regular television shows can be filmed against a blue screen (or green screen), cutting back on set construction by instead using digital backgrounds created by lower cost overseas video editors. 20 posted on 11/04/2025 5:15:39 AM PST by T.B. Tens of thousands of layoffs have been announced across major sectors in late October 2025, with UPS, Amazon, Intel and Nestl√© leading the cuts. Over 112,000 tech jobs alone have been eliminated this year, and broader corporate downsizing is accelerating. Just during October alone, UPS announced 48,000 job cuts, Amazon 14,000, Intel 24,000, Nestle 16,000, Accenture 11,000, Novo Nordisk 9,000, Applied Materials 1,444, Target 1,000, Charter Telecom 1,200 and CBS/Paramount 1,000. These are notable corporations cutting staff, but other major companies like JPMorgan Chase have implemented a hiring freeze across multiple divisions in late 2025, driven by its aggressive deployment of artificial intelligence and cost discipline. Fixing problems created by bad management and using AI to identify better ways of running operations and eliminating inefficiencies, waste, and useless jobs.Here's an example of what Palantir is doing with its clients using AI: Swiss Re: After installing Palantir's software, they cut reporting time by up to 80%, freed about 30% of underwriters‚Äô time, boosted data-team output by 50%, and earned back the entire cost of the system in 7 months, ending with a 170% return (independently audited). Airbus: Used Palantir to improve assembly of the A350 by about 30%‚Äîfewer delays, fewer mistakes, and more planes finished each month using the same factories and workers. BP: Runs virtual ‚Äúdigital twins‚Äù of oil platforms and fields so engineers can spot problems early, prevent breakdowns, and make better decisions before something goes wrong. National power company (unnamed): Used Palantir to map 10,000+ miles of power lines and find weak spots before they fail. These aren‚Äôt future promises‚Äîthey‚Äôre real improvements in speed, cost, reliability, and output. This is what applied AI actually looks like in the real world.Stronger companies create real jobs. 15 posted on 11/04/2025 2:18:15 AM PST by RoosterRedux (‚ÄúCritical thinking is hard; that‚Äôs why most people just jump to conclusions.‚Äù‚ÄîJung (paraphrased)) [ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 12 | View Replies] To: SeekAndFind If you‚Äôre a low level coder, your days are numbered. Tens of thousands of layoffs have been announced across major sectors in late October 2025, with UPS, Amazon, Intel and Nestl√© leading the cuts. Over 112,000 tech jobs alone have been eliminated this year, and broader corporate downsizing is accelerating. Just during October alone, UPS announced 48,000 job cuts, Amazon 14,000, Intel 24,000, Nestle 16,000, Accenture 11,000, Novo Nordisk 9,000, Applied Materials 1,444, Target 1,000, Charter Telecom 1,200 and CBS/Paramount 1,000. These are notable corporations cutting staff, but other major companies like JPMorgan Chase have implemented a hiring freeze across multiple divisions in late 2025, driven by its aggressive deployment of artificial intelligence and cost discipline. Managers have been instructed to avoid hiring unless absolutely necessary. All of this screams to me, ‚ÄúWork for yourself!‚Äù wanna keep your business going? Have a human answering the phone instead of a computer. I threw contracts to providers simply because a human answered the phone. All it takes is one trip through ‚Äúautomated phone hell‚Äù to make up the price difference for parts. In the old days of touchtone phones, I would just press 0 to find a human. An online AI chat is very common these days. Instead of 0, I type in HUMAN. Sometimes it takes typing human 2 or 3 times. I have also run into AI while using the telephone customer service. No matter what the "choices" from the AI are, I just repeat HUMAN until they transfer to a living, breathing person. Here's an example of what Palantir is doing with its clients using AI: Swiss Re: After installing Palantir's software, they cut reporting time by up to 80%, freed about 30% of underwriters‚Äô time, boosted data-team output by 50%, and earned back the entire cost of the system in 7 months, ending with a 170% return (independently audited). Airbus: Used Palantir to improve assembly of the A350 by about 30%‚Äîfewer delays, fewer mistakes, and more planes finished each month using the same factories and workers. BP: Runs virtual ‚Äúdigital twins‚Äù of oil platforms and fields so engineers can spot problems early, prevent breakdowns, and make better decisions before something goes wrong. National power company (unnamed): Used Palantir to map 10,000+ miles of power lines and find weak spots before they fail. These aren‚Äôt future promises‚Äîthey‚Äôre real improvements in speed, cost, reliability, and output. This is what applied AI actually looks like in the real world.Stronger companies create real jobs. Job security. Well I already got that skill...working with that kind of voltage is a life ender... They're blaming the "AI" boogeyman but it's the automation and lower cost Indian programmers supporting that automation. Some of that is due to the industry shift away from Hollywood. The Arri Alexa digital movie camera was released in 2010. Since then, movie producers had a more plentiful, less expensive, and better filming options than Hollywood could offer. The James Bond movie "Skyfall" (2012) was filmed using Alexa digital cameras and won the Academy Award for Best Cinematography. Add in Computer Generated Imagery and regular television shows can be filmed against a blue screen (or green screen), cutting back on set construction by instead using digital backgrounds created by lower cost overseas video editors. Add in Computer Generated Imagery and regular television shows can be filmed against a blue screen (or green screen), cutting back on set construction by instead using digital backgrounds created by lower cost overseas video editors. Title: Layoffs accelerate as Trump economy flashes red warning signs
URL: https://www.rawstory.com/trump-economy-2674261893/
Time Published: 2025-11-04T01:38:12Z
Full Content:
Several major US corporations in the last month have announced plans to cut thousands of workers as layoffs in the American economy have reached their highest level since 2020, when much of the global economy was shut down due to the Covid-19 pandemic. As reported by Bloomberg on Monday, major firms including Target, Amazon, Paramount, and Molson Coors in October announced plans to lay off a combined total of more than 17,000 workers for a wide variety of reasons ranging from the impact of artificial intelligence to declining sales. Taken together, these layoffs point to a significantly weakened labor market, which had already ground to a halt over the summer when the last jobs report released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) showed the economy created just 22,000 jobs in the month of August. And while the BLS has stopped releasing monthly employment reports during the ongoing shutdown of the federal government, Bloomberg pointed to data collected by outplacement firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas showing that there have been ‚Äúalmost 950,000 US job cuts this year through September, the highest year-to-date total since 2020‚Äîand that was before the heavy October run of announcements.‚Äù Dan North, senior economist at Allianz Trade Americas, told Bloomberg that he has detected a definite shift in the jobs market in recent weeks. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not just in a low hire, low fire environment anymore,‚Äù he explained. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre firing.‚Äù Joseph Brusuelas, chief economist at RSM US, said in an interview with Reuters that he also expected the labor market to get worse in the coming months due to ‚Äúadverse policy shocks emanating from Washington,‚Äù as well as ‚Äúthe change in behavior among corporates who hoarded labor for the past four to five years,‚Äù and were thus reluctant to carry out layoffs. ‚ÄúThat was never an indefinite behavior,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to see migration up in the unemployment rate.‚Äù John Challenger, CEO of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, told CBS News last week that he didn‚Äôt think that the layoffs announced over the last month were just a blip. ‚ÄúThese are major layoffs, the kind of which we only see in periods of real change in the economy,‚Äù he emphasized. One challenge for economists in assessing the current state of the economy is the vast gulf between the experiences of America‚Äôs highest-earning households and households at the bottom of the economic ladder. According to a Monday report from CNBC, recent corporate earnings reports have shown signs of a so-called ‚ÄúK-shaped‚Äù economy in which well-off consumers are maintaining or increasing their spending while low-income consumers are being forced to cut back. ‚ÄúLast week, Chipotle reported it‚Äôs seeing consumers who make less than $100,000 a year, which represents roughly 40% of the company‚Äôs customer base, spending less frequently due to concerns about the economy and inflation,‚Äù CNBC noted. ‚ÄúCoca-Cola said in its third-quarter earnings that pricier products like Topo Chico sparkling water and Fairlife protein shakes are driving its growth. Procter & Gamble reported similar results, saying wealthier customers are buying more from club retailers, which sell bigger pack sizes, while lower-income shoppers are significantly pulling back.‚Äù A Monday report from Fortune similarly picked up on evidence that the US is in the midst of a K-shaped economy, as it found that the percentage of Americans taking on subprime loans in the third quarter of 2025 reached its highest level since 2019. This is significant, Fortune noted, because an increased reliance on subprime loans ‚Äúadds to signs that many are facing increased financial pressure‚Äù to make ends meet. What‚Äôs more, Fortune pointed to a recent analysis from Moody‚Äôs showing that the top 20% of households in the US are now responsible for economic growth, while the bottom 80% have essentially been stagnant. Lucia Dunn, an economist at Ohio State University, told Fortune that this economic disparity could increase instability if not addressed. ‚ÄúWe are losing the middle class,‚Äù Dunn said. ‚ÄúAnd when you get to a society where there are a lot of people at the bottom and then a small group at the top, that‚Äôs a prescription for real trouble.‚Äù The reports of the layoffs in corporate American come as a new analysis released Monday by Oxfam offered the latest look at extreme wealth inequality in the US, with the the 10 wealthiest Americans gaining nearly $700 billion so far this year‚Äîand as millions of people have lost crucial federal food assistance due to the government shutdown and the Trump administration‚Äôs refusal to release full benefits. ALSO READ: Shutdown chaos could unleash accused terrorist boss back onto the streets Copyright ¬© 2025 Raw Story Media, Inc. Title: Palantir is proud of its 'disciplined' hiring practices
URL: https://www.businessinsider.com/palantirs-ceo-alex-karp-disciplined-approch-not-over-hiring-layoff-2025-11
Time Published: 2025-11-04T00:54:40Z
Full Content:
Every time Katherine publishes a story, you‚Äôll get an alert straight to your inbox! Enter your email By clicking ‚ÄúSign up‚Äù, you agree to receive emails from Business Insider. In addition, you accept Insider‚Äôs Terms of Service and Privacy Policy. Palantir is proud of its "disciplined" hiring practices. The defense tech company reported earnings that beat estimates on Monday, and CEO Alex Karp touted Palantir's approach to talent recruitment in his shareholder letter. Karp notes that while the company has "grown quite significantly," it has kept to its "constraints." "Our head count is one manifestation of this disciplined approach," Karp wrote in the letter to shareholders. "The casual expansion of our ranks would have diminished the need to lean even more heavily on the strength of our software and the Ontology and to ensure their continued maturation. "The alternative would have been to rely on an army of bright minds to do work that would have obscured the platform's weaknesses and ultimately hindered its development," Karp added. The message of maintaining a lean head count arrives at a moment when other companies are pivoting to leaner workforces. There have been significant layoffs at multiple large companies, particularly in middle-management roles. Throughout the year, Microsoft has laid off around 15,000 employees in total with multiple rounds of cuts. In October, Amazon announced it is cutting about 14,000 corporate jobs, or roughly 4% of its white-collar workforce, as part of an effort to streamline operations and reduce bureaucracy. Target, the retail giant, also announced in the same month that it would lay off 1,000 corporate employees to eliminate what the company called "overlapping work." During Amazon's latest earnings call, CEO Andy Jassy said that the company's rapid growth in recent years created "a lot more layers" that have slowed decision-making, and that the layoff is about "culture" instead of cost cutting or AI. To make the job market picture more unclear, the government shutdown is preventing the release of job data from September onwards. Based on the most recent available data from August, the labor market missed expectations by a wide margin. Jump to
--------------------------------------------------

Title: US stock market today: Why S&P, Nasdaq gain while Dow slips? Here‚Äôs how Apple, Nvidia, and Tesla drove Wall Street today
URL: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/us/us-stock-market-today-why-sp-nasdaq-gain-while-dow-slips-heres-how-apple-nvidia-and-tesla-drove-wall-street-today/articleshow/125072108.cms
Time Published: 2025-11-04T00:35:27Z
Full Content:
US stock market ended mixed on Monday as investors chased the AI trade after a wave of billion-dollar tech deals. Nasdaq rose 0.46% to 23,834.72, the S&P 500 gained 0.17% to 6,851.97, but the Dow fell 0.48% to 47,336.68. Apple jumped 2%, Nvidia climbed 1.8%, and Tesla surged 3%, driving tech higher. Energy and industrials sank as Chevron and Boeing dropped. Yields held near 4.58%, keeping rate fears alive. Investors rotated into AI and chips, betting big on growth. The S&P 500 stays up 14% YTD, Nasdaq 22%, with AI stocks dominating November‚Äôs rally.
