Title: Entering The Age of The Ozempic Company
URL: https://www.forbes.com/sites/stephenmiles/2025/11/03/entering-the-age-of-the-ozempic-company/
Time Published: 2025-11-03T14:57:33Z
Full Content:
ByStephen Miles, Contributor. For decades, a company‚Äôs success was largely measured by how many people it employed. The equation, growth equals headcount, defined an entire generation of business leadership from early-stage startups to Fortune 100 Companies. Adding employees was one of the key metrics that captured a company‚Äôs growth potential within its industry. The epicenter of this was in the technology sector, where founders and CEOs continuously talked about hyper-scaling through the lens of employee headcount expansion. This metric translated into the ‚Äúhyper-scaling‚Äù narrative, which further translated into eye-watering valuations and market premiums. Headcount growth peaked during COVID, with many companies in the technology sector hiring as fast and furiously as their recruiting functions could handle. Employees in this era assumed significant power and asserted it through a total rejection of returning to the office (RTO), planting a firm flag on working from home indefinitely. Some went further, forming unions to collectively push back against company strategies and policies, including work with the Department of Defense, hybrid work models, and DE&I positions. The Year of Efficiency Post-COVID, we entered a new era highlighted by Mark Zuckerberg, the founder and CEO of Meta, announcing ‚Äúthe year of efficiency.‚Äù This marked a clear pivot away from headcount as a measure of hyper growth and a signal that trimming over-hiring and bloat would be the new mantra. Many founders and CEOs quickly followed, and we have seen a trend of high-performing companies continuing to announce reductions in their workforce, including Amazon, UPS, Target, Microsoft, and others. Historically, downsizing was viewed as a sign of weakness. In this new era, it has become a mark of discipline and strength, which also requires new leadership muscle from those still around. The old mindset held that a company grew its employee base and added spans and layers during prosperous times, only to shed them when conditions worsened. The new mindset is to run the company like an Olympic athlete, lean and efficient even in good times, with the goal of staying in top form year-round rather than letting bureaucracy creep in. The world we operate in has become less predictable, and the velocity of change has surpassed most executives‚Äô wildest predictions. Leading a company that stays ‚Äúfit‚Äù allows leaders to reduce bloat and bureaucracy, increasing the likelihood that the company can move faster and adapt better than its competitors. Entering the AI Era We are now entering the next phase, ushered in by the artificial intelligence revolution. We are still in the first chapter of this new era, and the true future of work and the corporation is yet to be defined. Across industries, leaders are converging on the same mindset. In my thirty years of coaching, this is the first time I have seen every CEO focused on running their company with fewer employees next year and beyond. The first chapter of this era has been less about front-page headlines of massive layoffs and more about stealth. CEOs are freezing headcount and putting real restrictions on hiring, allowing natural churn and attrition to reduce workforce size quietly. Most companies churn between 5 and 15 percent of their employees annually, and when you restrict rehiring, reductions happen without announcements. If you are a knowledge worker, you know what I mean. This is one of the hardest job markets ever for those looking to change roles or get hired. The competition is fierce, and openings are scarce outside of highly specialized roles such as AI. It is harder to get a new job than to get into an elite university, with thousands of applications for a handful of positions. Even the students from the most elite business schools are struggling to enter this job market. The AI Revolution and Its Reach The AI revolution has not even fully hit most companies yet. If you believe this is more like electricity than snake oil, it will transform the operating models and blueprints of every company and every employee. Apart from the internet, it is the only time a new technology truly touches everyone across an organization. Previous technological revolutions affected only small portions of the workforce. The database and cloud computing eras were largely handled by specialists and technology executives. AI, by contrast, reaches everyone, whether you are in a plant, on the front line, driving a truck, or working at corporate headquarters. Naysayers argue that new technologies take decades to fully integrate into the workforce. The difference this time is that everyone who owns a mobile phone (important to note that more phones exist than humans) already has access to AI. Most people have already experimented with ChatGPT, Gemini, or Claude, often for fun or travel planning. Others have started using AI to increase productivity, eliminating repetitive work and focusing on higher-order problems. These employees are already differentiating themselves and will continue to pull ahead. As they make AI their personal superpower and become truly reflexive in its use, they will get noticed and likely elevated. At the employee level, we will enter a phase of ‚Äúelevate or be disintermediated.‚Äù The future of being an employee is about higher density through elevated work or risk becoming irrelevant. The Risk of AI Slop This is not all doom and gloom. Every employee has the opportunity to make AI their superpower and, instead of being replaced by automation, use it to accelerate their growth. The challenge is that AI is still in its infancy and often confidently wrong. It is a tool to enhance productivity and eliminate low-value effort, not a place to dump your cognitive load and disengage. AI can help every employee become the highest-performing version of themselves, better, faster, and smarter, but it still requires human oversight. We have entered the era of ‚ÄúAI slop,‚Äù where employees risk lowering their potential if they treat AI as the answer rather than as an enhancer. The best employees will apply their cognition to higher-order problems, using AI‚Äôs speed to amplify their contextual thinking. Context Is the New Differentiator AI will dominate content creation, and its ability to synthesize and organize data is unmatched. Humans, however, are the best at context. The better you are at contextualizing a problem for an AI agent, the better the result you will get. As Tobi L√ºtke, the founder and CEO of Shopify, said on the ACQ2 podcast, it is not ‚Äúprompt engineering,‚Äù it is ‚Äúcontext engineering.‚Äù Employees who master context engineering faster will stand out early in this revolution. The way employees work will also change dramatically. For decades, many workers were measured by activity: meetings attended, insights generated, and presentations created. Accountability was cumulative, building through recurring meetings until someone finally made a decision. That model is dying. The premium on activities will decrease, perhaps to zero, as AI agents take on content assembly, allowing fewer, higher-density employees to focus on decisions and actions. What once took many meetings will soon happen in one or two. These high-density meetings will demand full cognitive engagement. Employees will need to re-learn how to have meaningful, high-accountability discussions. As recent CEOs have noted, leaders are pushing back against multitasking and texting in meetings. The future workplace will require attention, presence, and decisive ownership. Making the Case for Humans in an AI World As more routine and repetitive work is automated through AI, human factors will become the premium differentiators: leadership, relationships, trust, judgment, decision making, prioritization, and high-context communication. This comes at a time when years of isolation and remote work have dulled even the strongest interpersonal skills. Companies and employees alike must focus on two elements: making AI reflexive for every employee and strengthening human factors to turn enhanced content and higher-density collaboration into speed and execution. The companies and individuals that master both will define the true age of the Ozempic Company, lean, fast, and built to endure.
--------------------------------------------------

Title: Republican warns Trump now 'losing' on economy ‚Äî and says it's 'going to get a lot worse'
URL: https://www.rawstory.com/goper-warns-trump-losing-on-economy-and-says-it-s-going-to-get-a-lot-worse/
Time Published: 2025-11-03T14:44:32Z
Full Content:
As the government shutdown continues with millions of Americans losing Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits and federal employees going without pay forcing many to turn to food banks, President Donald Trump's focus on foreign policy and building a ballroom is causing supporters and Republicans to question his priorities, according to NBC News. The shutdown, NBC reports, is compounding problems that have intensified "broader anxiety over an economy that in recent months has been marked by lingering high prices for many consumer goods, rough jobs numbers, mass layoffs at major companies ‚Äî including Amazon and Target ‚Äî and an uptick in inflation." Recent polls show that a majority of Americans disapprove of President Trump's handling of the economy, with approval ratings generally falling in the range of 37 percent to 41 percent and disapproval ratings around 57 percent to 62 percent. His economic approval numbers are currently the lowest of his second term in office. Republicans, NBC says, are sounding the alarm about this "bleak" outlook, but are afraid to tell Trump the truth. ‚ÄúNo one wants to tell the president he‚Äôs losing on the economy,‚Äù according to a Republican strategist who said they recently warned the White House about their concerns. Despite that, some Republicans are still optimistic. Sen. Bernie Moreno (R-OH) says that despite the numbers and the millions of Americans relying on food banks, "the state of the economy is very strong." NBC notes that many Republicans are intentionally remaining silent about the abysmal state of Trump's economy. "Republicans running in swing House seats across the country, however, have not been eager to talk about Trump‚Äôs economy," they note. Vice President JD Vance acknowledged the fact that Americans are suffering, but blames the Democrats despite Republicans having control of the House, the Senate and the White House. "The unfortunate reality ‚Äî and we‚Äôre starting to see this with our aviation industry ‚Äî we‚Äôre going to find out the hard way with SNAP benefits, the American people are already suffering, and the suffering is going to get a lot worse,‚Äù Vance said. Betty Szretter, a Republican and former Trump supporter who now regrets her vote and told NBC she will vote for a Democrat. blames the president. ‚ÄúI think deep down he wants to help the country with things like food insecurity,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBut now he is busy out of the country and demolishing the White House. I know that is being paid for with private funds, but those could be used to help people.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt all seems very selfish,‚Äù she added. Title: How workers are trying to get ahead of a job market full of uncertainty
URL: https://www.businessinsider.com/workers-proactive-strategies-for-getting-ahead-of-the-job-market-2025-11
Time Published: 2025-11-03T14:35:03Z
Full Content:
Every time Dan publishes a story, you‚Äôll get an alert straight to your inbox! Enter your email By clicking ‚ÄúSign up‚Äù, you agree to receive emails from Business Insider. In addition, you accept Insider‚Äôs Terms of Service and Privacy Policy. Welcome back! Looking for something to watch? We have a new video podcast starring the great Katie Notopoulos and Emily Stewart. "Well Spent" covers how we buy, what we buy, and why we buy. Their first episode examines a doozy of a purchase: a home. Check it out here. In today's big story, people are getting nervous about layoffs. It could be time to start planning ahead. What's on deck: Markets: Looking to invest in the AI data-center boom? There's an ETF for that. Tech: How workers train Tesla's Optimus robot to act like a human. Business: Social media is becoming a lucrative new side hustle for some military personnel. But first, hope for the best but plan for the worst. If this was forwarded to you, sign up here. Halloween has come and gone, but the labor market is still feeling spooky. Many workers see job security as a rarity these days. But instead of waiting for the proverbial axe to drop, some are getting ahead of layoffs in a variety of ways, writes BI's Jacob Zinkula. Sometimes it's as simple as getting a jump start on job hunting while you're still employed. Other people Jacob spoke to diversified their income with a side hustle or picked up a second full-time gig. While the approaches differed, the goal was the same: Don't get caught off-guard if cuts come. That's sound advice regardless of the job market, but it certainly holds true these days. The labor market has remained largely frozen for the past few months, with little to no hiring or firing. The slight thawing we have seen in recent weeks has been due to layoffs. There has also been a rise in rolling layoffs where companies make multiple, small cuts as opposed to a single deep one. The approach is meant to help companies avoid cutting too deeply, but it doesn't do much for employee morale. As if all of this wasn't nightmarish enough, don't forget the threat of AI. Companies seem keen to leverage the tech's efficiencies, which many interpret to mean lower headcounts. Some of you might be dismissive of these layoff preppers. "If you worked that hard on you're regular job, you wouldn't have to worry about getting laid off!" But layoffs aren't always telegraphed, and even in their aftermath, the reasoning isn't always clear. Take Amazon's recent job cuts. When the news was first announced, it was described as part of the company's goal to be leaner in the age of AI. One Amazon executive even encouraged employees in an internal memo to "lean in on AI." But just a few days later, Amazon CEO Andy Jassy said the layoffs weren't AI-driven ‚Äî "not right now at least," he added ‚Äî and were instead about culture. So yes, maybe it doesn't hurt to be a bit proactive. And if you do end up getting bitten by the layoff bug, we've got you covered with what to do next. 1. This ETF could body the AI-data-center boom. The Tema Electrification ETF (VOLT) is poised to win big from the AI spending spree, according to analysts at Ned Davis Research. It's already beating the S&P 500, and analysts think it'll outperform the index by roughly 20% by 2027. 2. Leaving Wall Street for AI. When former Balyasny portfolio manager Barry Duong was under his noncompete period, he decided to learn about AI. Now, Duong leads AI strategy at startup Hebbia and thinks other Wall Streeters should also consider making the move. 3. How an "accidental banker" is running one of Wall Street's biggest deal machines. Houlihan Lokey CEO Scott Adelson told BI how the bank is positioning itself, from going on a hiring spree while rivals hold back to making targeted acquisitions. 1. What it's like to train Tesla's humanoid robot to be‚Ä¶ human. Inside a glass-walled lab, dozens of Tesla workers act out the basic motions of everyday life ‚Äî from wiping a table to lifting a cup ‚Äî in an effort to train Optimus to move like a human. In conversations with BI, five current and former employees revealed what the job requires, including twerking, sprinting, and acting like a gorilla. One worker said that if their movements aren't deemed "human enough," their performance is critiqued. 2. AI, but make it have feelings. Eric Zelikman, a top AI researcher who recently left xAI, is raising $1 billion for his new startup at a $4 billion valuation, according to sources. Humans& will build models that attempt to learn from and empathize with their users. 3. Amazon's rollercoaster week. On Tuesday, mass layoffs shook the Big Tech company. By Thursday, Wall Street was cheering a strong Q3 earnings report. Behind all of this, CEO Andy Jassy has been focused on changing the company's culture and proving its AI chops, BI's Eugene Kim writes. 1. One of the biggest competitions in San Francisco is shockingly low-tech. Getting your ad on billboards (yes, billboards) has become an "insane competition." It's largely thanks to AI startups with cash to burn that are looking to stand out. In some areas, billboard space is sold out for the next year. 2. A soldier's foray into social media stardom. Since becoming a social media star, Sgt. 1st Class Johnny Vargas said he now earns more money online than through the Army. For BI's series on military influencer culture, Vargas said he's on a mission to help other service members cash in, too. 3. The C-suite's best career advice. The truth is that there isn't a clear path when it comes to climbing to the top. It's often dependent on timing, the industry, personal networks, and more. Executives shared with BI the best career advice that's stuck with them. Dan DeFrancesco, deputy executive editor and anchor, in New York. Hallam Bullock, senior editor, in London. Akin Oyedele, deputy editor, in New York. Grace Lett, editor, in New York. Amanda Yen, associate editor, in New York. Jump to

Title: Institutional Bitcoin Demand Cools as Bull Market Roars Elsewhere | US Crypto News
URL: https://beincrypto.com/blackrock-bitcoin-etf-inflows-slow-us-crypto-news/
Time Published: 2025-11-03T14:20:15Z
Full Content:
Written & Edited byLockridge Okoth Welcome to the US Crypto News Morning Briefing‚Äîyour essential rundown of the most important developments in crypto for the day ahead. Grab a coffee because while Wall Street partys on AI-fueled gains, Bitcoin‚Äôs biggest backers are quietly stepping back. Fresh data shows BlackRock‚Äôs Bitcoin ETF inflows have plunged, hinting that institutional enthusiasm may be cooling just as the bull market heats up. The sharp decline in Bitcoin ETF inflow, reported in a recent US Crypto News publication, is raising eyebrows across the crypto market, even as US equities continue their AI-fueled surge. New data from Glassnode shows that institutional demand for Bitcoin has slowed dramatically, contrasting with the growing euphoria in traditional markets led by technology and infrastructure plays. According to Glassnode, BlackRock‚Äôs spot Bitcoin ETF has seen less than 600 BTC in net weekly inflows over the past three weeks. This represents a significant decline from the 10,000 BTC-plus inflows that have historically preceded major rallies in this cycle. ‚ÄúOver the past three weeks, BlackRock‚Äôs spot BTC ETF has seen less than 0.6k BTC in weekly net inflows. This represents a sharp decline from the > 10,000 BTC net inflow per week that preceded each major rally this cycle, signaling a notable slowdown in institutional demand,‚Äù wrote analysts at Glassnode. The slowdown marks one of the weakest periods of institutional accumulation since the ETF‚Äôs launch. The figures suggest that large investors may be taking a breather after months of heavy accumulation. Bitcoin‚Äôs price has struggled to maintain momentum, but has slipped below $110,000, trading at $107,868 as of this writing. ETF flows are now considered a leading indicator of sentiment among institutional investors. Despite the soft inflow data, on-chain analysts spotted movement beneath the surface. Whale Insider reported that BlackRock transferred 1,198 BTC, worth approximately $129 million, to Coinbase, suggesting ongoing portfolio realignment or custody adjustments. JUST IN: BlackRock deposits 1,198 $BTC ($129.09 million) and 15,121 $ETH ($56.1 million) to Coinbase within the last hour. pic.twitter.com/2J8ah3MrCw Such movements do not necessarily indicate selling. However, they highlight how major asset managers are actively managing exposure amid volatile macro conditions. ETF providers often rebalance or consolidate holdings across custodians as liquidity and demand fluctuate. While Bitcoin demand cools, traditional markets are powering higher. Evercore ISI maintains a bullish outlook on US equities, projecting the S&P 500 to reach 7,750 by 2026. The firm reportedly cites strong leadership from AI-driven sectors like tech, communications, and consumer discretionary. Evercore strategist Julian Emanuel said the current bull market remains intact, although he warned of near-term volatility tied to shifts in Fed policy and tariffs. EVERCORE: U.S. BULL MARKET STILL STRONG, BUY STOCKSEvercore ISI advised buying U.S. stocks, saying the S&P 500 could hit 7,750 by end-2026 as key signs of a market top are missing. Analyst Julian Emanuel said gains are being led by AI-driven sectors like tech, communication‚Ä¶ With the VIX near year-to-date lows, Emanuel recommended using SPY strangles as hedges in a ‚Äústill-healthy‚Äù uptrend. ETF analyst Eric Balchunas echoed this optimism, calling it a market that‚Äôs ‚Äúforgotten how to fall.‚Äù He noted that the -3x S&P ETF has reverse-split five times, a sign of how punishing this cycle has been for bears. NEW: Bears Face Extinction in a Market That's Forgotten How to Fall.. The -3x SPX ETF has reverse split 5 times, a crazy data point showing just how brutal this mkt has been for bears. While they'll get their moment (pullbacks are part of life) we also show that long term it pays‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/58BwtcWTGg The diverging trends highlight a key tension in global markets. AI and equity exuberance are absorbing liquidity, while Bitcoin‚Äôs institutional narrative temporarily cools. As macro liquidity tightens and investor enthusiasm tilts toward AI infrastructure, Bitcoin‚Äôs next leg may depend more on when big money returns to the digital frontier than on policy signals. Title: Earnings, Deals and Trade, Set the Tone for the Week
URL: https://www.forbes.com/sites/jjkinahan/2025/11/03/earnings-deals-and-trade-set-the-tone-for-the-week/
Time Published: 2025-11-03T13:51:29Z
Full Content:
ByJJ Kinahan, Senior Contributor. Key Takeaways -Trade talk between US and China helped calm Markets - Tech and Health Care deals over weekend - Earning season continues The trade truce that was established last week between the US and China is having a positive effect on the markets in today‚Äôs premarket trading. We saw the Asian markets with a positive reaction overnight (although Japan was closed for a Holiday) and the S&P500, Nasdaq and the Dow Jones Industrial Average Futures Contracts are all positive in premarket trade today. The major Indices are hoping to build on the momentum of last week and last month. In the month of October, we saw the S&P 500 up approximately 2.5% and the Nasdaq up just under 5%. In what is often a tough month we had an uneven but positive reaction the positive news that we received from Amazon.com on Friday certainly helped us finish on a strong note. As mentioned, we have positive signs in premarket trade, but we also have some deal news that could also help drive markets higher. We had news that Microsoft Corporation announced that they have entered into a contract with IREN Limited, for $9.7 Billion that will allow Microsoft Corporation to have access to NVIDIA Corporation Chips. The five-year contract will include a 20% prepayment and is clearly being viewed positively by the Market. In premarket trade we have both stocks higher, with IREN Limited up by over 20%. We also have a deal in Health Care area, with Kimberly Clark Corporation purchasing Kenvue Corporation which is the parent company of Tylenol. The cash and stock transaction will value the Kenvue franchise at $48.7 Billion. This is a weekend with lots of news coming into Monday, but there are still some other things to keep our eyes on that will move markets and some things we will talk about for the rest of the week. The first thing is to not forget that we are still in the height of earnings season and with that there are some favorites of Retail Traders reporting this week. That starts today with Palantir Technologies. We see the options market is pricing in an expected move of about 2% for the move after earnings on a stock that has doubled this year. We also have Advanced Micro Devices on Tuesday, and all will be waiting to hear more about their recent deals, particularly more about the details on the Oracle Corporation deal. The other major earnings on Monday and Tuesday include Uber Technologies, Shopify Incorporated and Pfizer incorporated The government shutdown continues and besides the human toil and effect of this, we are also seeing companies starting to suffer because of this with the Airlines front and center, as we are starting to see the delay times at airports continue to stack up and companies waiting on approvals for things from the government having to wait while this is settled. We also and news from OPEC+ group this weekend as they announced that they would halt planned production increases at the beginning of 2026. The price of Crude Oil is largely unchanged in premarket trade. We do have some numbers this week, the non-delayed numbers include ISM Services and Consumer Sentiment. Plenty of opportunities this week, as always, stick to your trading plan and long-term goals

Title: Why corporate executives shouldn‚Äôt ignore their own AI upskilling
URL: https://fortune.com/2025/11/03/why-corporate-executives-shouldnt-ignore-own-ai-upskilling-cfo/
Time Published: 2025-11-03T13:08:05Z
Full Content:
Sheryl Estrada is a senior writer at Fortune, where she covers the corporate finance industry, Wall Street, and corporate leadership. She also authors CFO Daily. Good morning. Artificial intelligence is redefining the workplace, and corporate jobs aren‚Äôt excluded from its reach. During a panel session at the Fortune Global Forum in Riyadh last week, Anne Lim O‚ÄôBrien, vice chair and partner at Heidrick & Struggles, said, ‚ÄúProfessional services‚Äîlawyers, accountants, management consultants like myself‚Äîthe ones who actually process, analyze, and deal with a lot of data, those are the skills that can be replaced by AI and agentic AI.‚Äù Hisham Radwan, CEO of Cigna Insurance Saudi Arabia and a fellow panelist, added actuaries to that growing list. ‚ÄúAI is moving so fast that we can‚Äôt control it,‚Äù Radwan said. ‚ÄúBut bottom line‚Äîit‚Äôs an enhancement to our capabilities rather than a replacement.‚Äù As companies shift from the hype phase to the adoption phase of AI, they‚Äôre seeing productivity gains, O‚ÄôBrien said. But she noted that companies must address a critical question: What are they doing with the time AI saves? For leaders, the promise of AI goes far beyond efficiency‚Äîit should free time for strategic thinking and innovation, she said. It‚Äôs also an opportunity to double down on skills like emotional intelligence, which is widely considered one of the core human abilities that AI cannot truly replace, she added. Tech giant Amazon‚Äôs approach is shaking up the corporate landscape. The company announced last week that it will cut roughly 14,000 corporate jobs‚Äîabout 4% of its white-collar workforce, mostly middle managers‚Äîas part of a restructuring aimed at ‚Äúreducing bureaucracy‚Äù and ‚Äúremoving organizational layers.‚Äù The company is offering ‚Äúmost employees‚Äù 90 days to look for a new role internally. For those who can‚Äôt find a new role or choose not to look for one, Amazon will provide severance pay, outplacement services, and health insurance benefits, among other measures, Beth Galetti, senior vice president of People Experience, wrote in the announcement to employees. Amazon CEO Andrew Jassy said last year that he wants the company to operate like ‚Äúthe world‚Äôs largest startup‚Äù and to have the right structure to drive that level of speed and ownership. During the company‚Äôs quarterly earnings call on Thursday, Jassy said the layoffs were about a cultural mismatch, not primarily financial, Fortune reported. ‚ÄúThe announcement that we made a few days ago was not really financially driven, and it‚Äôs not even really AI-driven‚Äînot right now, at least,‚Äù Jassy said of the job cuts. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs culture.‚Äù However, Amazon‚Äôs job cuts follow a company-wide email in June, in which Jassy wrote that those who embrace generative AI and help build Amazon‚Äôs capabilities will have the most impact and assist in reinventing the company. Fortune‚Äôs Eva Roytburg highlights that Galetti mentioned in the company memo that this generation of AI is a ‚Äútransformative technology‚Äù and that the company needs to be organized more leanly‚Äîwith fewer layers and more ownership‚Äîto move as quickly as possible. ‚ÄúThe move may offer an early glimpse of how AI is actually reshaping the labor force: not by immediately displacing the tactile, mundane factory roles everyone expected, but by hollowing out the white-collar ranks that run them,‚Äù Roytburg writes. Gartner analysts estimate that by 2026, one in five organizations could use AI to estimate at least half of their management layers. AI may not necessarily take your job‚Äîbut someone who knows how to use AI better than you might, O‚ÄôBrien warned during the panel session in Riyadh. The takeaway: upskilling and reskilling aren‚Äôt just for those in non-corporate positions‚Äîthey‚Äôre essential at every level of the organization. What‚Äôs helping you keep your AI skills sharp? I‚Äôd love to hear from you‚Äîsend me an email. Sheryl Estradasheryl.estrada@fortune.com Elias Habayeb, CFO of Corebridge Financial, Inc. (NYSE: CRBG), has resigned to accept a senior leadership position with a publicly listed company. Habayeb will remain in his current position until April 24, 2026. Habayeb‚Äôs departure is not the result of any disagreements with the company on any matter relating to its financial statements, internal control over financial reporting, operations, policies or practices. Corebridge is working with an executive recruiting firm to launch a search for a successor. Cassandra Hudson was appointed CFO of Alkami Technology, Inc. (Nasdaq: ALKT), a digital sales and service platform provider, effective November 1. Hudson brings more than 20 years of experience. Most recently, she served as CFO of StackAdapt. Before that, she was CFO of EngageSmart, where she guided the company through a successful IPO in 2021. Earlier in her career, Hudson spent 12 years at Carbonite in a series of finance leadership roles, ultimately serving as chief accounting officer and VP of finance. Boston Consulting Group‚Äôs (BCG) Global M&A Report 2025 shows global deal value rose 10% to $1.9 trillion through Q3, driven by North America, which accounted for 62% of deals ($1.3 trillion, up 26% year over year). Seasoned acquirers‚Äîusing proven playbooks and increasingly, AI‚Äîachieved a two-year average return of +1.0%, while less experienced buyers saw ‚Äì7.5%. Despite challenges like geopolitical tensions and shifting tariffs, many dealmakers continue to move forward, particularly in small- and mid-cap markets, where regional transactions have been more insulated from disruptions, according to BCG. Strategic growth, capability building, and resilience remain key drivers. North America is the top region by value, and technology leads among industries. Leading firms now embed AI throughout diligence, valuation, and integration, accelerating decision-making and risk management. Megadeals are rebounding, with 27 transactions over $10 billion this year (up from 21 last year). Sector standouts include industrials (+77%), tech (+10%), energy (+20%), and health care (+20%). "Stock futures climb as investors await Supreme Court showdown on Trump tariffs and shareholder vote on Musk‚Äôs $1 trillion pay package" is a Fortune report by Jason Ma. From the report: "Markets signaled another positive session as futures rose Sunday night ahead of a big week for President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs and Tesla CEO Elon Musk‚Äôs blockbuster compensation plan. Futures tied to the Dow Jones industrial average rose 107 points, or 0.22%. S&P 500 futures were up 0.28%, and Nasdaq futures added 0.30%. That would add to Friday‚Äôs rally." "The yield on the 10-year Treasury fell 1.8 basis points to 4.083%. The U.S. dollar was up 0.06% against the euro and up 0.16% against the yen." You can read more here. "Successful organizations treat tech debt like financial debt, managing it proactively with a strong digital core, agility and a culture of continuous improvement." ‚ÄîDaniel Kendzior, the global cybersecurity AI reinvention leader for Accenture, writes in a Fortune opinion piece titled, "The haunting consequences of ignoring tech debt in an agentic AI world." ¬© 2025 Fortune Media IP Limited. Title: 5 Things to Know Before the Stock Market Opens
URL: https://www.investopedia.com/5-things-to-know-before-the-stock-market-opens-november-3-2025-11841849
Time Published: 2025-11-03T12:42:01Z
Full Content:
Stock futures are pointing higher to start the week as investors look ahead to another slew of earnings reports; OPEC+ agreed to pause output hikes; China said it would suspend additional rare earth curbs; Kimberly-Clark announced plans to buy Tylenol maker Kenvue; and Berkshire Hathaway's latest quarterly report showed its cash pile climbed to a record high. Here's what you need to know today. Stock futures are on the rise early Monday as investors prepare for a slew of earnings reports due from major technology and pharmaceutical companies this week, including an update from AI investor favorite Palantir (PLTR) after the closing bell today. The three major U.S. stock indexes come into today's session after ending October on a high note. Futures tied to the Dow Jones Industrial Average were up 0.1% recently, while those linked to the S&P 500 and the tech-heavy Nasdaq climbed 0.4% and 0.6%, respectively. Bitcoin was trading below $108,000. Gold futures were slightly higher, at around $4,019 an ounce. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note slid to around 4.08%. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies on Sunday agreed to pause output hikes in the first quarter of 2026 after an increase due in December. The group of oil-producing nations has boosted its output targets since April, but began slowing the pace since October amid worries about a glut of supply. Crude oil futures climbed, then reversed course in early trading. China has agreed to suspend implementing additional rare earth export restrictions, as well as end investigations targeting American companies in the semiconductor supply chain, as part of the trade truce struck by President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping, The White House announced over the weekend. China also said it would consider easing export restrictions on semiconductors made by chip firm Nexperia. Shares of Nvidia (NVDA), Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), and other semiconductor firms are higher in premarket trading. Berkshire Hathaway's (BRK.A, BRK.B) cash stockpile hit yet another high, according to the conglomerate's quarterly update over the weekend. The buildup has fueled speculation that Warren Buffett could be concerned about the market overheating after a series of recent record highs, waiting for better opportunities, or deferring the company's allocation to his successor as he prepares to step down from his role as CEO at the end of the year. Kimberly-Clark (KMB), the maker of Huggies diapers and other consumer brands, agreed to buy Tylenol maker Kenvue (KVUE) in a cash-and-stock deal valued at about $48.7 billion. Kenvue faces a leadership shakeup and growing litigation concerns as the Trump administration has sought to draw links between its Tylenol and autism. Shares of Kenvue are soaring over 20% pre-market, while Kimberly-Clark's shares are down close to 15%.
--------------------------------------------------

Title: Best Altcoins to Buy as Crypto Adoption Is Inevitable for Wall Street, per Bitwise CEO
URL: https://bitcoinist.com/best-altcoins-to-buy-bitwise-ceo-claims-crypto-adoption-inevitable/
Time Published: 2025-11-03T12:38:49Z
Full Content:
Quick Facts: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Bitwise CEO Hunter Horsley believes that within the next 12 months, every Wall Street institution will be involved in crypto. 2Ô∏è‚É£ Massive inflows into products like Bitwise‚Äôs Solana ETF and moves by giants like JP Morgan and BlackRock prove the shift is already underway. 3Ô∏è‚É£ The best altcoins to buy now include $HYPER, $PEPENODE, and $BAN ‚Äì all poised to ride the next big wave. Crypto is hosting the wildest party in town, there is no doubt about it. Bitwise CEO Hunter Horsley recently took to X to claim that within the next 12 months, every Wall Street institution will be doing something in crypto. ‚ÄòSoftware is eating the world. Crypto is going to eat capital markets‚Äô ‚Äì Hunter Horsley Almost every major bank, from Bank of America and BlackRock to Goldman Sachs and HSBC, is knee-deep in one or more crypto-related endeavors, whether that‚Äôs crypto trading and custody, crypto ETPs, crypto-enabled payments, or tokenization. Is Horsley‚Äôs claim a bold one? Sure. Especially considering that DeFi currently represents less than half a percent of traditional finance‚Äôs scope. That said, it‚Äôs worth noting that these crypto-related investment products are still relatively new, and it‚Äôs only fair to give them time to mature rather than immediately comparing them to TradFi. If anything, the massive interest in these new products ‚Äì ETFs being a great example ‚Äì shows that the sky is the limit for crypto. That‚Äôs a clear sign the market is hungry for new-age investment products that give it exposure to high-quality cryptos. What‚Äôs more, a recent Bloomberg report revealed that JP Morgan is all set to accept Bitcoin and Ethereum as loan collateral. This would offer billion-dollar investment parties more flexible financing options, allowing them to retain their crypto holdings and avoid triggering taxable events. And then there‚Äôs BlackRock, one of the biggest asset-management companies in the world, which now boasts over $87B in Bitcoin ETF assets and more than $10B in Ether ETFs ‚Äì proving that crypto is indeed the next big investment opportunity. Don‚Äôt want to miss the crypto gold rush? Ready to ride Wall Street‚Äôs smarts? Below are three top altcoins to buy right now. One of the best crypto presales of 2025, Bitcoin Hyper ($HYPER) has already raised an eye-popping $25.6M+ from early investors. And it‚Äôs worth the hype. That‚Äôs because $HYPER plans to bring Solana-like speeds, low costs, and Web3 compatibility to the Bitcoin blockchain, which has so far been technologically sidelined compared to Ethereum and Solana. It‚Äôll also enable developers to build decentralized applications (dApps) and smart contracts directly on Bitcoin. So, get ready to access DeFi trading apps, DAOs, governance, lending, staking, and gaming on Bitcoin, all thanks to Bitcoin Hyper. Furthermore, a decentralized canonical bridge will facilitate seamless interaction between Bitcoin‚Äôs Layer-1 and Hyper‚Äôs Layer-2 networks. Simply put, it‚Äôll convert your original Bitcoin into wrapped, Layer 2-compatible tokens. Here‚Äôs the kicker: if you want to join the Bitcoin Web3 revolution, now‚Äôs the best time to get in. The project is currently in presale, meaning right now you can buy Bitcoin Hyper for just $0.013215 each ‚Äì and stake it for 46% APY. Check out our guide to buying $HYPER to find out how. And holding onto your tokens until 2026 could earn you a handsome 1,400% ROI, with the token projected to potentially reach $0.20 according to our $HYPER price prediction. To fully understand PEPENODE ($PEPENODE)‚Äôs ground-breaking potential to become the next crypto to explode, consider how it aims to revolutionize the crypto mining segment. Right now, traditional crypto mining is not only super expensive ‚Äì with high GPU, electricity, and maintenance costs ‚Äì but also highly technical, requiring detailed knowledge to set up and operate. First, PEPENODE is extremely affordable, as your only starting cost is the price of your first $PEPENODE token, which, during its current presale, is just $0.0011317 per token. Second, mining on PEPENODE is set to be simple yet engaging. The only challenge lies in experimenting with different combinations of mining nodes, as each will have unique characteristics and compatibilities. Despite being virtual, the mining setup will feel just like the real thing. The dashboard will include familiar elements such as hashrate and other key performance metrics. Interested? Check out our step-by-step guide on how to buy $PEPENODE. And according to our $PEPENODE price prediction, if you catch the trend early and get in now, you could potentially see a 542% ROI by the end of 2026. Comedian ($BAN) launched in October last year and rode the Q4 boom to shoot up over 3,000% in less than a month. It‚Äôs a viral meme coin inspired by the controversial art piece by Maurizio Cattelan, which features nothing more than a banana taped to a wall. This artwork sparked an ongoing debate about modern art vs. contemporary art and whether modern art is borderline stupid, fueling massive investor interest in the $BAN token. Nearly 12 months later, the token now appears ready for another major rally. It‚Äôs currently finding support on a key upward-sloping trendline ‚Äì the same one that triggered a 1,000% rally back in March this year. However, with a strong resistance line overhead, its upside potential will depend on whether it can successfully break past that resistance. That said, even from current levels up to that resistance line, there‚Äôs at least a 50% gain on offer. But if $BAN manages to break beyond that line ‚Äì which is highly likely given that it has tested it four times already (and as we know, the more times a resistance is tested, the weaker it gets) ‚Äì then we could see another 2024-style rally. Join the meme coin mania ‚Äì buy $BAN on MEXC today. Disclaimer: Kindly do thorough first-hand research before investing, as crypto is highly volatile. This article is not financial advice. Title: Gym offers to give Rs 2 crore Porsche in a surprising weight-loss challenge, but how much weight do you actually have to lose?
URL: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/magazines/panache/gym-offers-to-give-rs-2-crore-porsche-in-a-surprising-weight-loss-challenge-but-how-much-weight-do-you-actually-have-to-lose/articleshow/125058967.cms
Time Published: 2025-11-03T12:38:42Z
Full Content:
A gym in China‚Äôs Shandong province has gone viral after launching a bold weight-loss challenge offering a Porsche Panamera worth over Rs 2 crore to anyone who can lose 50 kilograms in three months. Participants must pay a registration fee of 10,000 yuan for training and meals. While the contest has sparked massive online buzz, medical experts warn that such rapid weight loss could cause severe health risks and even prove life-threatening. Even without 10,000 steps a day, young woman loses 27 kg in six months. Title: Top investing tips for both AI bulls and bears
URL: https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-invest-q4-2025-stock-tips-ai-bulls-bears-2025-11
Time Published: 2025-11-03T12:22:47Z
Full Content:
Every time Joe publishes a story, you‚Äôll get an alert straight to your inbox! Enter your email By clicking ‚ÄúSign up‚Äù, you agree to receive emails from Business Insider. In addition, you accept Insider‚Äôs Terms of Service and Privacy Policy. Good morning and welcome to First Trade. Disney pulled all of its channels, including ESPN and ABC, from YouTube TV‚Ä¶ and its stock went up. Is there no justice in the world? Rundown But first, there's two sides to every story. Love Business Insider? Log into Google and make us a preferred source. Was this email forwarded to you? Sign up now Market musings In my years covering markets, I can't recall a time when there's been more polarizing views on the future of stocks. Sure, there's always chatter when indexes are near record highs about what could send it all crashing down. But it feels different now. The arguments are more multi-faceted, and go beyond the traditional "market-wide valuations are too high" takes. Whether it's concerns over AI capex spending, or cries of unprecedented mega-cap tech weightings in indexes, it seems like the bear case has more meat on the bone right now. On the bullish side of the ledger, investors are happy to lean into the narrative that AI spending will eventually lead to transformational profit growth, pushing stocks even higher. They also see Fed rate cuts as rocket fuel for the entire market, since they've historically served as such, especially for economically sensitive sectors. As a card-carrying (but possibly converted) member of the "not a bubble" camp, the huge sell-off in Meta last week got my attention. It showed that investors are ready to start questioning huge AI spending, even if the company's more diversified tech peers didn't absorb the same share-price hit. But we see both sides of the coin here at First Trade, and have compiled investing recommendations specifically for bulls and bears. For bulls If you're a member of this faction, it's likely you see Fed rate cuts as a godsend, because they'll stimulate economic activity. You also probably feel pretty good about inflation, despite it staying persistently above the Fed's target. Well, you're in luck. Bank of America recently recommended the following sector ETFs that are due for a catch-up if the economy booms in the first quarter of 2026: If you're looking to stick with the AI wave, UBS says these three under-the-radar names are poised for outperformance: For bears If you're fearful of an AI-driven meltdown, fret not, BofA has you covered from this angle as well. The firm says these are the two best places to invest for upside protected from US tech exposure: One additional way to continue outperforming during a tech-driven downturn is through the purchase of momentum stocks. The most popular fund for this is iShares MSCI USA Momentum Factor ETF (MTUM). Jason Browne, the founder of Alexis Investment Partners, told BI this past week that the strategy is ideal for when one area of the market ‚Äî like the tech sector ‚Äî enters a lengthy rough patch. With US economic data on ice for the foreseeable future, uncertainty reigns supreme in the market. But now you're armed with some trades to deploy, regardless of where you line up. "If you come at the king, you best not miss." ‚Äî Omar Little from "The Wire" Let's just say I learned this the hard way, and am currently eating crow. Last week, ahead of Amazon's earnings, First Trade wrote about the drastic underperformance of the company's stock over the past five years, relative to the Mag 7 and S&P 500. Well, Andy Jassy must've used it as bulletin-board material, because Amazon promptly crushed earnings and sent its stock spiking 10% (pictured above). The main reason was the stellar performance of AWS, which is also one of the main areas of AI investment. In one fell swoop, Amazon dispatched lingering worries about a core business and assuaged concerns over huge AI spending. The stock still has a long way to go to catch up with peers, but last week was a massive step in the right direction. This chart from Bank of America supports one of the recommendations from the Market Musings section above: buy Chinese stocks if you're afraid of a US tech sell-off. The light blue line ‚Äî which plots Chinese stocks versus government bonds ‚Äî is close to a multi-decade low, suggesting immense catch-up potential. Compare that to the dark blue line, which offers the same ratio for US stocks versus sovereign bonds. It's at multi-decade highs, implying limited relative upside. In this section, a weekly feature on Mondays, we manage a hypothetical portfolio. Current stocks: Amazon, JPMorgan, Microsoft, Nvidia, Tesla Now that's more like it! The First Trade index absolutely crushed it over the last week, and a big part of that was the new addition of Nvidia. Not to mention Amazon spiking 10% on Friday after blockbuster earnings. Those two stocks largely carried our basket of stocks to market-beating performance. What we have here is a perfect example of the electric upside offered by the tech stalwarts that make up the Magnificent 7. These stocks are largely responsible for the stock market's ongoing record-breaking rally, given their massive weightings, and the First Trade index got the same boost as the S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100. When all was said and done, the First Trade index ended the week 6% higher, handily beating the S&P 500's 1% return. Also, after trailing the S&P 500 last week, First Trade is now outperforming it by more than double since this project started. Can we keep the roll going and do even better this week? Let me know at firsttrade@businessinsider.com (1) which stock you'd remove, and (2) which one you'd replace it with. Joe Ciolli, executive editor and anchor, in Chicago. Akin Oyedele, deputy editor, in New York. William Edwards, senior reporter, in New York. Steve Russolillo, chief news editor, in New York. Jump to

Title: Standard Chartered CEO: All Global Transactions Will Move to Blockchain
URL: https://www.coinspeaker.com/blockchain-global-payments-standard-chartered/
Time Published: 2025-11-03T12:15:27Z
Full Content:
¬© 2025 Coinspeaker LTD. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Bill Winters made a forecast at Hong Kong FinTech Week, while praising the city‚Äôs digital asset regulatory leadership. Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters stated on Nov. 3 that he believes all global transactions will eventually settle on blockchains and all money will be digital. Winters made the comments during a panel discussion at Hong Kong FinTech Week. Winters described the anticipated transition as a fundamental restructuring of the financial system, according to CNBC. However, he acknowledged that the industry does not know exactly how this transformation will occur and emphasized the need for continued experimentation. HSBC CEO Georges Elhedery joined Winters on the same panel and expressed optimism about Hong Kong‚Äôs fintech future. Winters praised Hong Kong‚Äôs leadership in digital asset regulation and its willingness to support blockchain experimentation. Other financial leaders, including the CEOs of BlackRock and Robinhood, have recently made similar predictions about the tokenization of traditional assets. Standard Chartered announced a joint venture with Animoca Brands and HKT in February 2025 to pursue a license for issuing an HKD-backed stablecoin. The partnership brings together the bank‚Äôs financial infrastructure, Animoca Brands‚Äô Web3 expertise, and HKT‚Äôs mobile wallet capabilities. Standard Chartered participated in the Hong Kong Monetary Authority‚Äôs stablecoin issuer sandbox, which launched in July 2024. Multiple institutions are competing to build payment settlement networks through stablecoin initiatives, according to a recent stablecoin ‚Äòinfrastructure war‚Äô report. Beyond stablecoins, Standard Chartered launched an integrated spot trading service for Bitcoin BTC $103 153 24h volatility: 1.3% Market cap: $2.06 T Vol. 24h: $110.93 B and Ether ETH $3 347 24h volatility: 6.0% Market cap: $404.72 B Vol. 24h: $66.71 B in July 2025 for institutional clients via its UK branch. The service offers Bitcoin (XBT/USD) and Ether (XET/USD) trading pairs. The bank has expanded its digital asset offerings through partnerships, including StanChart‚Äôs institutional crypto custody services with OKX in Europe. Hong Kong regulators have established multiple sandbox programs and regulatory frameworks to position the city as a global digital asset hub. The government has supported blockchain innovation through licensing regimes and pilot programs for financial institutions. The Hong Kong Blockchain Week started Nov. 3 and will last until Nov. 7. Title: Your Town‚Äôs Local History Books Have a Very Secret and Powerful New Buyer
URL: https://slate.com/technology/2025/11/arcadia-publishing-artificial-intelligence-history-books-authors.html
Time Published: 2025-11-03T10:40:00Z
Full Content:
Enter your email to receive alerts for this author. Sign in or create an account to better manage your email preferences. Are you sure you want to unsubscribe from email alerts for Nitish Pahwa? Sign up for the Slatest to get the most insightful analysis, criticism, and advice out there, delivered to your inbox daily. This piece has been updated with information that came to light after the article went to press. Even if you‚Äôve never heard of Arcadia Publishing, you‚Äôve undoubtedly come upon their books at some point‚Äîdisplayed in a gift shop kiosk, stocked in an airport bookstore or neighborhood library, or even at a CVS. The branding remains distinct across its nearly 17,000-title catalog: a small hardbound or paperback book that catches your eye via large sepia images and titles like Theatres of San Francisco and Central Kentucky Postcards, inscribed in the style of an old-school street sign. No matter where you go across America‚Äîthe mountains of Wyoming, a small town in Indiana, or the swamps of Florida‚Äîyou‚Äôll seemingly find a book from Arcadia about the local history. ‚ÄúThey connect with a lot of historians, or locals who have an interest in history, to publish these picture-heavy books,‚Äù Alex Brown, a Bay Area librarian and two-time author for the Arcadia imprint History Press, told me. ‚ÄúA lot of Arcadia authors are just regular people: older volunteers at historical societies, or retirees who really like local history.‚Äù Brown is a California native who studied Black communities in the North Bay for their master‚Äôs degree and got to apply their intimate knowledge to write 2019‚Äôs Hidden History of Napa Valley and 2020‚Äôs Lost Restaurants of Napa Valley and Their Histories, after a representative from History Press connected with them a few years prior. ‚ÄúMy first book focused on the people with marginalized identities‚Äîpeople of color, immigrants, women‚Äîwho‚Äôd lived there.‚Äù Brown didn‚Äôt hear much from the company after 2020. Then, on July 11, they got an email from out of nowhere: Arcadia Publishing had been ‚Äúpresented with an opportunity to provide content to a major technology company involved in AI development,‚Äù according to the message. Brown was given a deadline of one week to decide whether the books they‚Äôd written for the imprint could be used ‚Äúfor AI training purposes.‚Äù It was an odd request, not only for the hasty deadline, but for the lack of details. The ‚Äúmajor technology company‚Äù went totally unnamed; Arcadia only offered the guarantee that the artificial intelligence firm was a ‚Äútrusted partner‚Äù as determined by a round of ‚Äúserious deliberation.‚Äù The publishing house also made clear that its contracts allowed the company to farm its books out to A.I. models without the writers‚Äô permission, but added that it ‚Äúvalues its relationships with its authors‚Äù and wanted to grant them ‚Äúthe opportunity to opt out in this specific instance.‚Äù The particular instance, between Brown‚Äôs two titles, also wasn‚Äôt clarified. The email added that inaction would be considered endorsement; if Brown didn‚Äôt respond, they would simply receive a $340 check by the end of the year. But if they wanted ‚Äúto opt out of the use and receive no payment,‚Äù they would have to visit a hyperlinked page and follow the instructions. Brown already had a sour A.I. experience: Their two books with History Press had also been included within Library Genesis, the mass set of pirated texts that companies like Anthropic and Meta had illicitly downloaded to train their large language models without requisite author compensation. So Brown was not inclined to give up their work to yet another artificial intelligence enterprise, especially one that didn‚Äôt reveal itself up front. After contacting an Arcadia representative and speaking with their prior editor, Brown found out that their second book with History Press was ‚Äúnot included in this specific data sale.‚Äù So they opted the first book out, turning down the $340 offer.* ‚ÄúTheir contracts, at least at the time, were not negotiable. You basically sign it or you don‚Äôt,‚Äù Brown said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a very different structure from the Big Five publishers. You don‚Äôt get an advance or anything. You just get the royalties.‚Äù Those royalties are based on net sales, and they only make for a substantive amount should the books in question get decent sales, something that‚Äôs harder for a locally focused outfit like History Press and a broadly niche-interest publisher like Arcadia. In a 2022 blog post, the New Jersey‚Äìbased nonprofit Mr. Local History claimed that Arcadia offers ‚Äúone of the lowest royalties paid to authors in the publishing world,‚Äù pointing out that ‚Äúauthors get $1 or less for each book sold‚Äù and are compensated only twice a year, ‚Äúwhereas many other publishers pay monthly or quarterly.‚Äù Such hyperlocal histories are a crucial resource, a way for particular communities to preserve and chronicle their cultures, as well as a means for marketing their regions to tourists and chance visitors. But their audiences are consequentially limited, so Arcadia does not usually approach its authors with hundreds of dollars on offer. In its email to Brown, the publishing house even pointed out that these opportunities for author compensation ‚Äúcould be very limited in the future,‚Äù pointing to summertime court verdicts that recognized the A.I. training process as fair use‚Äîeven with copyright material. Arcadia was offering its authors a favor, while making clear it didn‚Äôt have to, and pointing out that this could be their only chance. And the A.I. ventures have only expanded since then. On Oct. 31, another email with similar language was sent out to a group authors who worked with Belt Publishing, an Arcadia imprint that focuses on the Midwest. Belt had not been involved with the first round of the A.I. deal, as its founder and director Anne Trubek had told me in a July email‚Äîbut as of just last week, ‚ÄúSome Belt titles were included in a 2nd round,‚Äù Trubek wrote to me in a follow-up after this piece went live. The deal was reportedly ‚Äúfinalized last week,‚Äù Trubek posted on Bluesky. Craig Calcaterra, a baseball writer who published Rethinking Fandom: How to Beat the Sports-Industrial Complex at Its Own Game with Belt in 2022, reprinted the email in his Monday-morning newsletter, which included an offer of $355 and an opt-out deadline of Nov. 7. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve gotten some preliminary information through informal channels that the accelerated time table is being pushed by the tech company,‚Äù Calcaretta wrote. ‚ÄúNeedless to say I have opted out of this ‚Äòopportunity.‚Äô I also hereby opt out of ever working with Arcadia/Belt Publishing again.‚Äù Some authors with Pelican Publishing, another Arcadia imprint, were also offered A.I.-deal money and given a Nov. 7 opt-out deadline. Arcadia is hardly the only book publisher to ink such opaque contracts with the A.I. overlords, despite the spirited objections and lawsuits brought by various authors. University and scholarly presses‚Äîwhich have been confronting the fallout from the Trump administration‚Äôs mass grant cancellations, higher printing and shipping costs from tariffs, and industry headwinds‚Äîare providing the model. Taylor & Francis, an academic publisher based in the United Kingdom, signed a $10 million deal with Microsoft last year to share a portion of its catalog for A.I. training, in exchange for annual payments from the tech giant through 2027. Authors were reportedly given no notice and their royalties were measly in turn; Bloomberg quoted one anonymous Taylor & Francis author who claimed to earn only $97 for ceding their book to the training maw. (A T&F spokesman told Bloomberg that the payments were ‚Äúin accordance with the licensing terms and royalty statement periods in their contracts,‚Äù while parent company Informa declared in a press release that ‚Äúthe agreement protects intellectual property rights.‚Äù) Wiley, an over-200-year-old academic publishing house, has already struck multiple A.I. deals for licensing and product integration, offering up its works to inform the output of Perplexity‚Äôs LLM and Amazon Web Services‚Äô chatbot. For the publishers, the arrangements were lucrative. For the authors, the payouts were much less so. In July, Johns Hopkins University Press gave the authors of its 3,000-title catalog an Aug. 31 deadline to opt out of having their works become A.I. training fodder in a new tech partnership. If they opted in, they would receive a little under $100 per work. Like Arcadia, Hopkins Press did not disclose the A.I. company involved or the money it was hoping to earn. It did press the urgency of signing now while writers still had some agency, and reminded them who here really has the power. ‚ÄúIn your contract, you provide us with the rights to go ahead with this kind of licensing,‚Äù Barbara Kline Pope, executive director of Hopkins Press, wrote to her writers. ‚ÄúHowever, we would like you to have the ability to opt out if you so choose.‚Äù The press was not suffering businesswise, she clarified, but it was ‚Äúexploring how our financial model may need to evolve.‚Äù One author who went for the opt-out contract addendum with Johns Hopkins Press shared the resultant language with Inside Higher Ed; it warned that ‚Äúsales and reach‚Äù of their work might suffer due to the A.I.opt-out. Beyond academia, HarperCollins became the first Big Five commercial publisher to seal an A.I. deal in late 2024 with an unnamed company‚Äîallegedly Microsoft, according to anonymous sources. Writers who opt in would earn $2,500 per book for the trouble, which wouldn‚Äôt be deducted from their typical royalties, and HarperCollins itself would also pocket another $2,500 per book. (Microsoft has not commented publicly, but HarperCollins has stated that the deal will ‚Äúallow limited use of select nonfiction backlist titles for training AI models to improve model quality and performance.‚Äù) London-based Bloomsbury Publishing announced in August that it was ‚Äúexploring‚Äù licensing agreements for its Academic and Professional arm, reaching out to those writers and offering just 20 percent of the money the publisher receives from the A.I. licensing deal. (The Society of Authors condemned these terms as ‚Äúnot fair and equitable.‚Äù) One author who‚Äôd contributed a volume to Bloomsbury‚Äôs popular 33 1/3 album-tribute series shared some of the company‚Äôs emails with me on condition of anonymity. Again, no specific partners or terms were mentioned, and the opt-out process required many steps, including an explicitly written reason for choosing not to participate. (This particular author‚Äôs simple, blunt response read, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not interested in licensing my book to Generative AI companies.‚Äù) Recently, Bloomsbury‚Äôs chief publisher celebrated a concrete A.I. deal for a part of its Academic and Professional catalog‚Äîdetails still TBA‚Äîthat apparently drove a revenue increase of 20 percent for that division over the first half of the year. As a publicly traded firm, its stock rose when the chief endorsed the possibility of even more A.I. deals on the table. The legal and regulatory landscape has provided little clarity. If anything, the courts have inadvertently revealed more on how authors have historically been exploited. In June, a federal court ruled that the prominent A.I. startup Anthropic had not committed any misdeeds by using copyright works from nonfiction and fiction writers like Andrea Bartz to train its Claude model‚Äîbut it had violated intellectual property rights by pirating many of those books for training purposes, via unlawful book databases like Library Genesis and Pirate Library Mirror. To halt further litigation around said piracy, the $183 billion Anthropic agreed to pay $1.5 billion to the affected authors and publishers, making for the largest copyright settlement in history‚Äîamounting to about $3,000 per pirated work. Meanwhile, Microsoft and its partner OpenAI are facing so many copyright lawsuits from authors that the cases have been consolidated into a single instance of multidistrict class-action litigation. The argument of training as copyright infringement has managed to advance there as of Monday, thanks to output from ChatGPT that appeared to be mighty similar to George R.R. Martin‚Äôs fantasy works. In the face of a federal administration that seeks to nix all copyright protections against the A.I. sector, legal recourse remains the only potential remedy for authors. This power imbalance creates a cynical opportunity for the A.I. companies: pay the typically underpaid writers for books they were already stealing or planned to steal. A way of laundering legitimacy and skirting costly courtroom battles for pennies on the dollar. The typical Arcadia volume is chock-full of vintage photographs and tends to be less text-focused; History Press, as with the other imprints Arcadia has scooped up over time, allows authors to actually write more. The covers and branding look a touch different, but the subject matter, and the focus, is distinctly Arcadia. ‚ÄúYou have to have a certain number of photos, a nice range of topics, and a bibliography, though they don‚Äôt care if that‚Äôs in the book or on a website somewhere,‚Äù Brown explained. Other than those conditions, Brown was free to frame the project to their liking: ‚ÄúI did not think that I would be able to get one of the Big Five publishers or an academic press to publish a book on marginalized history in Napa County that had nothing to do with wine. History Press was willing to do it.‚Äù It does appear that the text-heavier History Press was the focus of Arcadia‚Äôs A.I. deal‚Äîand it was likely a similar factor with Belt Publishing for the second round. When Brown posted a Bluesky thread in July about the A.I. email, they‚Äôd hoped to hear from other Arcadia writers who‚Äôd received similar messages, but the ones who did reply and speak with Brown had no awareness of the A.I. deal, or whether their current or future works would be involved. Only one other writer, baseball historian and Kane County Cougars author David Malamut, publicly shared his Arcadia A.I. email on the social network, with its offer of $205. (Malamut did not respond to my interview requests.) Stephanie Hoover, an artist and researcher who‚Äôs published three books with History Press, also put out a public ask about the deal on LinkedIn to no avail, even though she‚Äôs long been connected with many Arcadia writers. ‚ÄúI pitched my first book, The Killing of John Sharpless, to History Press in 2012, before Arcadia purchased it,‚Äù Hoover told me. ‚ÄúThey accepted it so fast that I almost thought that they were pulling my leg.‚Äù The issues inherent to a quick deal with a niche business were apparent upfront. ‚ÄúThey offered no advance. The clause that I really should have taken out was the right of first refusal, which boxed me in,‚Äù she explained. Hoover‚Äôs last book with History Press, The Kelayres Massacre, was put out just a few months after Arcadia acquired the publisher. So Hoover didn‚Äôt have much direct experience with Arcadia until the A.I. email‚Äîby which time she‚Äôd worked with bigger publishers: ‚ÄúI actually got an advance, and I actually do get some royalties.‚Äù The smaller earnings from History Press/Arcadia were what soured Hoover and led her to notify them, in 2016, that she would no longer run book ideas by them: ‚ÄúMost of the time, I‚Äôd get these royalty statements like, Nope, nothing this time, nothing this time,‚Äù she said. That pushed her to take the A.I. deal for all three of her titles, equating to $1,020, or $340 per book‚Äîthe same value as Alex Brown‚Äôs offer, but more than the compensation offered to David Malamut. ‚ÄúI looked at my husband and said, ‚ÄòThis will literally be more money than I‚Äôve made on all three books,‚Äô ‚Äù Hoover said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a fan of A.I. I think it‚Äôs a threat to so many industries. But the bottom line was, A.I. is going to cannibalize my books at some point anyway, whether I want it to or not. At least this way I make something.‚Äù Still, it‚Äôs not as though she considers that price tag to be sufficient. ‚ÄúIt took me about six months to research each of the books, and anywhere from three to four months to write them. This is a big chunk of your life, and I did it three times,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs frustrating when you invest that sort of time and labor to make next to nothing. It‚Äôs heartbreaking.‚Äù Michael Burgess, former director of the New York State Office for the Aging under Gov. Eliot Spitzer, had a unique introduction to Arcadia. His self-published local history, 2021‚Äôs Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt in New York, was republished by History Press in 2023 and retitled with a focus on the state capital, Albany. After Burgess got the A.I. email, which also offered the $340 royalty, he wrote an optimistic PSA on LinkedIn touting the ‚Äúunexpected small financial benefit from artificial intelligence,‚Äù noting that Arcadia‚Äôs offer was ‚Äúworth the small royalties I get for about 200 book sales.‚Äù ‚ÄúI get 7 percent of the sale of a $25 book,‚Äù Burgess told me. ‚ÄúI spent all this time writing it. You never get a lot of money.‚Äù The time he put into the book required research that, he believes, A.I. cannot do. ‚ÄúI go to the New York State Library, and I‚Äôm able to look on microfilm at the papers of Franklin Roosevelt as governor,‚Äù Burgess told me. ‚ÄúThe A.I. is not going to go and get microfilm, I can tell you that.‚Äù He likewise mentioned a 1955 Eleanor Roosevelt radio interview he uncovered‚Äîwhich he could access and contextualize because his father was the correspondent. But for Burgess, it even goes beyond research. ‚ÄúI used ChatGPT and put something in about Eleanor Roosevelt, and it said, Eleanor and her husband Theodore Roosevelt,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm resigned to the fact they‚Äôre going to do this. So I‚Äôm glad I can help to give facts about this part of the story, rather than them getting it wrong about Eleanor Roosevelt.‚Äù When I reached out to Arcadia for comment, the publisher had little info to provide in terms of the partnership and its exact terms, but it did reiterate its commitment to the writers. ‚ÄúAny Arcadia licensing arrangements in this area will reflect our position: Authors will have a choice, and all participating authors will be compensated,‚Äù Katie Parry, a publicist and associate publisher at Arcadia, wrote in an email. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll pursue opportunities that align with our position.‚Äù A lot is still unclear, but a few things are apparent: A.I. companies are aggressively reaching out to book publishers to strike deals that will allow them to sidestep the litigation that led to the Anthropic settlement and avoid the heftier payouts. Whichever unnamed firm approached Arcadia, it took a particular interest in the wordier History Press, indicating that generative text remains the lodestar. And if the Theodore/Franklin Roosevelt mix-up is representative of other chatbot hallucinations, that perhaps indicates the need not just for these bots to brush up on history and text, but to ramp up the representation of local history in the mix in order to make the LLMs more universal. If that‚Äôs the goal, at least Alex Brown‚Äôs work will not be involved: On Oct. 7, they signed newly offered addenda to their Arcadia contracts that opts them out of A.I. training offers indefinitely. Yet Arcadia as a whole, much like its fellow publishers, remains open to A.I. business. At least, while they‚Äôre still able to get anything out of the trade. Correction, Nov. 3, 2025: This piece originally misstated that Alex Brown had not received any money from Arcadia prior to the A.I. offer. Both Arcadia and Brown have confirmed that the author has received royalties. This piece has also been updated to clarify Arcadia‚Äôs royalties process. Title: Global Digital Finance unveils results of study on tokenized money market funds
URL: https://www.finextra.com/pressarticle/107787/global-digital-finance-unveils-results-of-study-on-tokenized-money-market-funds
Time Published: 2025-11-03T09:43:00Z
Full Content:
Global Digital Finance (GDF), the leading global digital assets members association, announced the results of a working group reporting on the legal certainty of collateral eligibility and the mobility of Tokenized Money Market Funds (TMMF) in Luxembourg, Ireland, and the UK. 1 03 November 2025 Be the first to comment This content is provided by an external author without editing by Finextra. It expresses the views and opinions of the author. Ireland and Luxembourg host more than 80% of the MMFs and cross-border funds in Europe and English law governs the Credit Support Annex (CSA).The report concludes:‚Ä¢ There is relative legal certainty of TMMFs located in Luxembourg in a digitally native or registered form due to the availability of statutory frameworks to govern such transactions‚Ä¢ Longstanding historical legal interaction between Luxembourg and the UK in respect of financial and investment contractual arrangements, including CSAs, also makes this an attractive place to establish a TMMF where the tokens will be posted as collateral under a CSA governed by English law ‚Ä¢ There is not yet express statutory or judicial authority in Ireland specifically addressing tokenized shares or TMMFs. Legal certainty in respect of ownership and treatment of tokenized shares under Irish law therefore requires an analogy to traditional shares and electronic contracts, rather than being directly established ‚Ä¢ It is reasonable to conclude that Irish courts would treat digitally native TMMF shares in a manner consistent with traditional shares. This alignment reinforces the view that TMMF shares can be accommodated within existing property law principles in Ireland, supporting their recognition and enforceability under Irish legal standards ‚Ä¢ Where an MMF is tokenized using a digitally native TMMF and is located in the UK, there is a low degree of legal uncertainty concerning the legal treatment of ownership and a similarly low level of uncertainty concerning the replication of rights for market participants between the traditional MMF and a digitally native TMMF ‚Ä¢ It is anticipated that further certainty will be available in the UK if the Property (Digital Assets etc.) Bill is enacted and common law precedent is developed as to the implications of the ‚Äúthird category‚Äù of property. Over 70 firms participated in the working group including S&P, Federated Hermes, R3, JP Morgan, Ownera, Finastra, Lloyds Banking Group, Hogan Lovells, LSEG, Archax, Blackrock, State Street, ISDA, EY, Commerzbank, Fireblocks, Northern Trust, Apex Group, Franklin Templeton, and Goldman Sachs.‚ÄúAs a co-chair of this working group, I have been impressed with the collaborative and effective working engagement across traditional financial institutions and fintechs as well as legal and professional services contributors and their firms. The combination of research and assessment findings and the practical sandbox execution of production use cases made this working group a very special and successful achievement,‚Äù said Armin Peter, GDF Executive in Residence who is also a former Global Head of Debt Syndicate EMEA at UBS and a, former GFMA Board Member. Sharon Lewis, Lead Partner for Future of Finance and Co-Chair of Digital Asset & Blockchain Practice, Hogan Lovells said: "There is relative legal certainty of TMMFs located in Luxembourg in a digitally native or registered form, where both Ireland and the UK have a low degree of uncertainty as the courts are likely to treat digitally native TMMF shares in a manner consistent with traditional shares. The cross discipline collaboration involved in this work has been outstanding and it is a credit to the industry participants."As part of the working group 30 of the firms participated in the GDF Industry Sandbox, powered by Ownera, the firm which operates the FinP2P routers that implement the open FinP2P standard to ‚Äúprove‚Äù the production use case for collateral mobility in TMMFs. With no fundamental barriers identified across legal, operational and regulatory dimensions, the sandbox demonstrated that TMMFs can transition from theoretical use cases to a production-ready collateral instrument across six simulations:‚Ä¢ Simulation 1: Simple Bilateral Transfer - Manual Margining of TMMFs ‚Ä¢ Simulation 2: Integrated Margin Calls - Automated Posting via Third-Party Systems‚Ä¢ Simulation 3: Depeg Event and Substitution - Dynamic Portfolio Management‚Ä¢ Simulation 4: Default Scenario - Enforcement and Recovery in Insolvency‚Ä¢ Simulation 5: Funding of TMMF in Triparty‚Ä¢ Simulation 6: From SWIFT to Collateral Settlement in Seconds.‚ÄúHosting the GDF Industry Sandbox was a monumental collaborative effort, bringing together some of the best-in-class market participants, custodians, and technology providers from across the industry. The results highlight what‚Äôs truly possible when we apply FinP2P and its DLT interoperability layer to collateral mobility and optimization,‚Äù said Natasha Benson COO and CFO of Ownera.Amarjit Singh, UK Digital Assets Leader, EY said: "The over 30 TradFi and Fintech firms participating in the sandbox have demonstrated that collateral mobility for TMMFs has arrived. This is an exciting next step in the continued uplift to the future market‚Äôs infrastructure, leveraging digital assets to bring real-world benefit to investors and financial institutions around the globe.‚ÄùLawrence Wintermeyer, GDF Member Board Chair added: ‚ÄúTesting the legal certainty of digital assets and demonstrating real production use cases is a time that has arrived for the global securities industry. This outstanding working group demonstrated it could engage the world‚Äôs best TradFi and digital Financial Market Infrastructure (dMFI) firms to collaborate and demonstrate to the whole of the industry and its regulators that digital finance has truly arrived. I look forward to the US working group kicking off in January 2026.‚Äù
--------------------------------------------------

Title: Standard Chartered CEO believes nearly all global transactions will move to the blockchain 'eventually'
URL: https://www.cnbc.com/2025/11/03/standard-chartered-ceo-believes-nearly-all-global-transactions-will-move-to-the-blockchain-eventually.html
Time Published: 2025-11-03T08:28:20Z
Description: Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters foresees a future in which nearly all global transactions are conducted on a digital blockchain ledger.
