Title: When the wrench comes for the wallet: Why Bitcoin‚Äôs biggest believers are handing over their keys
URL: https://cryptoslate.com/when-the-wrench-comes-for-the-wallet-why-bitcoins-biggest-believers-are-handing-over-their-keys/
Time Published: 2025-11-02T14:00:17Z
Full Content:
Self-custody is under fire as wrench attacks become a real threat for crypto holders, with physical coercion and organized crime targeting those with on-chain wealth. Cover art/illustration via CryptoSlate. Image includes combined content which may include AI-generated content. Welcome to Slate Sunday, CryptoSlate‚Äôs weekly feature showcasing in-depth interviews, expert analysis, and thought-provoking op-eds that go beyond the headlines to explore the ideas and voices shaping the future of crypto. Self‚Äëcustody was once the ultimate badge of credibility in crypto. A declaration of faith in sovereignty over convenience, code over blind trust, and cryptography over legal fine print. But for many of the space‚Äôs earliest and wealthiest adopters, that belief is starting to bend under a different kind of pressure: wrench attacks. In a world now flush with organized crime, doxxing, and $5 wrench attacks, even the most battle‚Äëhardened Bitcoiners are locking away more than their coins; their ideology is going in the vault as well. A decade ago, wrench attack jokes circulated mostly in privacy forums. The meme, coined from a 2015 XKCD comic, encapsulates a brutal truth. You can‚Äôt brute‚Äëforce a passphrase, but you can threaten someone with a $5 wrench until they tell you it. OG Bitcoiner Jameson Lopp, co‚Äëfounder of Casa and maintainer of the ‚ÄúPhysical Bitcoin Attacks‚Äù directory, has spent years documenting cases of wrench attacks where everyday crypto holders are beaten, held hostage, or worse because of their on‚Äëchain visibility. The directory now lists more than 200 verified incidents spanning at least 34 countries. From European traders kidnapped at gunpoint to influencers targeted after posting wealth flexes online. As of October 2025, the directory records 52 wrench attacks this year alone (more than one per week), with overall physical assaults increasing 169% since February. In late October 2025, Russian influencer Sergei Domogatskii was kidnapped in Bali by masked assailants who tased and beat him, forcing him to transfer approximately $4,600 in crypto from his mobile phone to their accounts. This is part of a rising trend of wrench attacks in this region, as Lopp previously told me: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve seen a number of attacks, for example, where Russian citizens who are either vacationing or living in Southeast Asia are getting hit by Russian organized crime. They‚Äôre coming into the country, wrench attacking them, and then trying to get out as quickly as possible, and presumably trying to leverage jurisdictional arbitrage.‚Äù Even veteran cypherpunks are taking notice. In a recent interview on What Bitcoin Did, on‚Äëchain analyst Willy Woo admitted: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not self‚Äëcustodying anymore‚Ä¶ I think you‚Äôll see a lot more people who‚Äôve been in this space a long time doing the same.‚Äù Woo reinforced that smaller holders should absolutely keep control of their own coins, but large balances and public profiles create an entirely different threat model. It‚Äôs not about losing a hardware wallet anymore; it‚Äôs about personal safety. Many others share his view. The Bitcoin Family, known for selling everything to live off Bitcoin, told CNBC in June that they‚Äôve abandoned single‚Äëdevice wallets for a scattered analog‚Äëdigital fortress. They‚Äôve split seed phrases and encrypted data across four continents. Family patriarch Didi Taihuttu said: ‚ÄúEven if someone held me at gunpoint, I can‚Äôt give them more than what‚Äôs on my wallet or my phone. And that‚Äôs not a lot.‚Äù Both Woo and Taihuttu were once among the poster children for full sovereignty. Their quiet retreat marks a broader sentiment shift (one now confirmed by the numbers). Somehow, Wall Street has managed to do what few thought possible: lure long-time Bitcoin whales into its regulated fold. According to a recent Bloomberg article, a new breed of discreet, ultra-wealthy holders is quietly offloading their cold wallets and moving billions into spot ETFs (sometimes without so much as a murmur on the blockchain). Thanks to ‚Äúin-kind transfers,‚Äù these whales can dodge a taxable sale, swapping their BTC directly for ETF shares. BlackRock alone has taken in over $3 billion since July through this channel. Suddenly, what used to be a wild-west game of keys and ledgers is starting to look a lot more like traditional finance. All packaged up with a shiny ticker symbol and plenty of paperwork to go around. ‚ÄúThis terrified me a bit,‚Äù commented Bitcoin advocate and human rights activist Alex Gladstein. For someone who‚Äôs spent his career documenting the way repressive regimes freeze assets and lock citizens out of the global financial system, watching Bitcoin drift toward mainstream financial custody feels like watching the escape hatch slowly close. Why? Because safety, reporting, and inheritance are finally trumping ideology. Srbuhi Avetisyan, research and analytics lead at Owner.One and co‚Äëauthor of Penguin Analytics recently helped analyze 13,500 high‚Äënet‚Äëworth families across 18 countries. She shares: ‚ÄúAt high balances, the risk isn‚Äôt blockchain failure‚Äîit‚Äôs physical coercion and OPSEC drift (lost seeds, single-point wallets). 87% of families keep incomplete asset records, and 99.4% lack a verified digital twin of their holdings. Crypto often disappears at incapacity/death‚Äînot from volatility, but from missing credentials and unclear rights.‚Äù For these families, ETFs and qualified custodians aren‚Äôt about giving in to TradFi. They‚Äôre about ensuring heirs can locate and transfer what might otherwise vanish. Still, not everyone‚Äôs ready to hand the entire stack back to banks. There‚Äôs a rising class of ‚Äúhybrid‚Äù custodians building bridges between full self‚Äësovereignty and institutional protection. Seth for Privacy, vice president of the self‚Äëcustodial app Cake Wallet, says the wrench attacks problem doesn‚Äôt have to end self‚Äëcustody; it just forces it to evolve. He explains: ‚ÄúCrypto has become mainstream, and self-custody solutions have to keep up.‚Äù Beyond leveraging privacy tools, like Silent Payments and Payjoin, where possible, to keep their transactions out of public view, he believes the best protection for high‚Äëprofile individuals is to stop talking about their wealth. That was a point hammered home by Lopp, as well, who told me: ‚ÄúIf you are on any sort of public network and you are flaunting your wealth, that‚Äôs one of the more risky things that you could be doing.‚Äù Seth points to Lopp‚Äôs company, Casa, Unchained, or some newer entrants like Nunchuk and Liana as examples of ‚Äúcollaborative custody.‚Äù These setups enable users to maintain control while distributing risk through multi‚Äësignature arrangements, such as a 2‚Äëof‚Äë3 or 3‚Äëof‚Äë5 scheme, with a fiduciary or geographically separate co‚Äësigner to remove the single point of failure. Anthony Yeung, chief commercial officer at CoinCover, also sees hybrid models as the pragmatic path forward. ‚ÄúComplete independence also comes with risk. If a private key is lost or compromised, the assets are often gone forever. A hybrid model addresses this by combining the best of both worlds: individuals retain direct control and ownership of their assets, while a trusted institution provides a safety net through secure backup and recovery mechanisms.‚Äù He calls this ‚Äúa digital Fort Knox‚Äù: still user‚Äëcontrolled, but institutionalized enough to enable secure backups, key recovery, and even inheritance triggers. Yeung adds: ‚ÄúThey may well be the bridge that brings the next generation of users from web2 to web3.‚Äù Thomas Chen, CEO of Function and managing director at BitGo for six years, agrees, although he emphasizes personalization and risk tolerance. ‚ÄúI think a future for hybrid models ultimately depends on the user‚Äôs risk profile and what they‚Äôre comfortable with.‚Äù Those who self‚Äëcustody gain sovereignty but lose convenience, he says, particularly when they want to pledge assets as collateral, trade at scale, or interact with smart contracts in general. That‚Äôs not the experience that institutional investors want, and it may not be right for HNW individuals either. ETFs and custodial structures allow Bitcoin to act like a financial asset, not just a collectible. For institutions, that‚Äôs non‚Äënegotiable. As Andrew Gibb, CEO of Twinstake institutional-grade, non-custodial staking platform, put it: ‚ÄúThe custody landscape is shifting from the crypto-native ideal of total self-control toward models that match the risk appetite and operational rigor of institutional investors.‚Äù Fiduciary duty, in his view, forbids relying on untested personal key setups. Yet not everyone‚Äôs convinced this convenience is worth the compromise. Tony Yazbeck, co‚Äëfounder of The Bitcoin Way, offers a sharper take: ‚ÄúPeople love to overcomplicate this, but it really comes down to common sense. Some wealthy holders and institutions convince themselves they are safer putting their Bitcoin into ETFs or custodial accounts. They say it protects them from mistakes, inheritance issues, or even physical threats. In reality, it just hands control of the world‚Äôs scarcest asset to someone else and replaces ownership with paperwork.‚Äù Having lived through Lebanon‚Äôs banking collapse, Yazbeck warns that history has proven that third parties fail, exchanges collapse, governments seize assets, and custodians freeze withdrawals. His advice is refreshingly non‚Äëtechnical. ‚ÄúThe risk of losing your Bitcoin because you trusted a middleman is far higher than the risk of losing access to your own keys if you handle them properly. Multisig setups, secure backups, and simple operational discipline solve almost every real self-custody problem.‚Äù But the best defense? Once again, stop attracting attention to yourself. ‚ÄúStay quiet about what you hold and live a normal life.‚Äù His mantra: protect privacy, take responsibility, and never outsource what Bitcoin was invented to make trustless. EY blockchain specialist Yaniv Sofer believes we‚Äôre witnessing a financial re‚Äëtiering rather than an ideological rupture. He explains: ‚ÄúFinancial institutions are accelerating their entry into digital assets use cases, and custody is a critical core capability.‚Äù While some firms buy access through third‚Äëparty providers like Fireblocks and BitGo, others build internal systems to integrate tokenization and payments. Sofer cautions: ‚ÄúHybrid custody models have not yet gained significant traction among financial institutions but remain a topic of interest. Regulatory requirements for qualified custodians continue to favor centralized solutions‚Ä¶ but hybrid models could emerge as a differentiator as the market matures.‚Äù In Avetisyan‚Äôs view, the long‚Äëterm equilibrium is clear. Most founders will run dual rails: core exposure in ETFs or qualified custody for reporting and collateralization, with a smaller self‚Äëcustody satellite for censorship resistance. This dual-rail system, she says, is already shifting how liquidity flows through the crypto economy. As more Bitcoin migrates to custodial wrappers, traditional funding markets gain depth and stability. The flip side? Sovereignty becomes optional, not default. Maybe what‚Äôs happening now isn‚Äôt so much an ideological defeat as a maturation. Bitcoin‚Äôs promise of self‚Äësovereignty remains intact for those who choose to uphold it. As the Bitcoin lead at Sygnum Bank, Pascal Eberle, comments: ‚ÄúThe future of ‚ÄúFreedom Money‚Äù lies in choice ‚Äì investors can opt for full self-custody, institutional-grade protection, or hybrid models that balance both.‚Äù Hybrid custody, institutional wrappers, and ETF liquidity are all symptoms of the same evolution: crypto crossing into the realm of structured finance. For early believers, that can feel like a betrayal, with self-custody becoming sidelined to the margins. As Yazbeck framed it: ‚ÄúThinking you are safer by giving your Bitcoin to someone else is like a rich person surrounding themselves with a military convoy out of paranoia. It looks strong but it is actually weak.‚Äù Yet perhaps this is decentralization in action; a dispersion of risk, trust, and control according to every individual‚Äôs appetite. Each generation of holder must redraw its own line between freedom and fear. In 2025, that line runs straight through the vault door. Christina is a web3 writer, editor, and content manager with a passion for technology and starting important conversations. As an industry OG, she‚Äôs not phased by market volatility and frequently scrimps on Starbucks to BTFD. Follow us on X for your essential dose of daily crypto news and deep dives. Title: How Fintech Is Redefining Retirement Planning For The Private Markets Era
URL: https://www.forbes.com/sites/ilonalimonta-volkova/2025/11/02/how-fintech-is-redefining-retirement-planning-for-the-private-markets-era/
Time Published: 2025-11-02T14:00:00Z
Full Content:
ByIlona Limonta-Volkova, Contributor. Most Americans are preparing for retirement with yesterday‚Äôs tools. The rules of retirement planning are changing, but few have noticed. Financial innovation often promises greater access and equality, yet adoption rarely keeps pace with aspiration. A recent Harris Poll found that nearly 40% of Americans have never heard of private-credit funds, a class of alternative investments that Wall Street is racing to bring to 401(k)s. Only 10% say they want more nontraditional options in their retirement accounts. Yet once investors learn that most U.S. businesses generating over $100 million in annual revenue are privately held, nearly 60% say they would consider investing in them, and 90% would allocate part of their savings to private markets. It is not that Americans do not want these investments. They just do not know they exist. The disconnect between awareness and appetite points to a fundamental problem: the infrastructure to connect regular investors with private credit simply has not existed until recently. For decades, these investments remained locked behind institutional walls, accessible only to pension funds, endowments, and the ultra-wealthy. That is changing as technology platforms modernize an industry that has historically run on spreadsheets and handshakes. "Private credit shouldn‚Äôt be a black box," asserts Nelson Chu, co-founder and president of Percent, a fintech platform democratizing access to private credit markets. His company is one of several working to crack open what has long been an opaque, insider-only market. "By standardizing issuance and surfacing live order books and post-close surveillance, we've opened a historically institutional market to accredited investors with shorter durations, lower minimums, and clearer visibility into risk and cash flows." What Chu describes addresses one of the biggest obstacles to bringing these investments mainstream: transparency. Traditional private credit deals are typically opaque, illiquid, and require enormous capital commitments. Modern platforms are changing the equation by building digital infrastructure that brings efficiency and visibility to previously murky markets. This matters for a simple reason: 401(k) investors have watched their investment options narrow as the number of publicly traded companies has declined. Private markets now represent a vast universe of investment opportunities that most retirement savers cannot touch, even as their pension fund counterparts have loaded up on these assets for years. The irony is hard to miss. The investments deemed suitable for public pension funds are considered too risky or complex for the individuals those pensions serve. Earlier this year, federal agencies were mandated to ease regulations around alternative investments in retirement plans signals momentum toward broader access. Major asset managers, like Apollo and BlackRock, are already positioning themselves to capture a share of the $13 trillion 401(k) market. The race is on. Success will likely not come from regulatory approval alone. It will require building investor confidence through education and infrastructure. Companies like Percent in the U.S. and Germany's Exaloan are demonstrating that private credit can operate with the same transparency and efficiency that investors expect from their brokerage accounts. Exaloan provides data infrastructure and analytics that enable banks and asset managers to originate, assess, and monitor private debt portfolios with institutional-grade transparency. By digitizing loan-level data and standardizing reporting, platforms like these are proving that private credit can operate with the same clarity and efficiency investors expect from their brokerage accounts. "Retail investor appetite for alternative assets has accelerated dramatically," Chu explains. "We're seeing sophisticated investors, business owners, executives, professionals, actively seeking diversification beyond the 60/40 portfolio. They want assets that don't correlate with public markets, are designed to generate cash flow, and offer transparency into what they're investing in." The question is no longer whether these assets will enter 401(k) plans. It is how fast the system can catch up. The technology is in place, and investor appetite is undeniable. What remains is closing the knowledge gap and creating the transparency that builds lasting trust. This has the potential to redefine retirement planning. And for millions of Americans, that shift cannot happen fast enough.
--------------------------------------------------

Title: S&P 500 Q3 2025 Earnings Surge: Magnificent 7 Lead Market Rally
URL: https://www.forbes.com/sites/bill_stone/2025/11/02/sp-500-q3-2025-earnings-surge-magnificent-7-lead-market-rally/
Time Published: 2025-11-02T12:24:46Z
Full Content:
ByBill Stone, Contributor. The third-quarter earnings season begins its second busiest week, with 135 S&P 500 companies scheduled to report. Notable companies scheduled to release earnings include: Palantir (PLTR), Pfizer (PFE), Yum! Brands (YUM), Emerson Electric (EMR), McDonald‚Äôs (MCD), Humana (HUM), and Qualcomm (QCOM). Warren Buffett‚Äôs Berkshire Hathaway (BRK/A, BRK/B) reported better-than-expected earnings on Saturday. A deeper dive and insights into Berkshire Hathaway‚Äôs third-quarter earnings are here. With 64% of companies reporting so far, 83% have beaten consensus earnings estimates. The earnings season preview from last week contains more details about the underlying drivers of earnings. Combining actual results with consensus estimates for companies yet to report, the S&P 500‚Äôs blended earnings growth rate for the quarter is at 10.7% year-over-year, above the expectations of 7.9% at the end of the quarter. The expected earnings growth rates for calendar years 2025 and 2026 increased to 11.2% and 14.0%, respectively. The continuation of the strong earnings season helped lift the S&P 500 last week. The Magnificent 7, consisting of Microsoft (MSFT), Meta Platforms (META), Amazon.com (AMZN), Apple (AAPL), NVIDIA (NVDA), Alphabet (GOOGL), and Tesla (TSLA), outperformed last week. Because these companies are critical drivers of earnings growth and a significant percentage of the S&P 500‚Äôs market capitalization, the Magnificent 7 remained the group to watch this earnings season. Despite the disappointments from Tesla (TSLA) and Meta Platforms (META), the rest of the group picked up the slack. Alphabet (GOOGL), Microsoft (MSFT), and Amazon.com (AMZN) continued to support the thesis that demand for artificial intelligence (AI) is driving robust growth. Meta Platforms (META) posted disappointing headline earnings due to a non-cash tax charge. More importantly, investors were spooked by the announcement of more than $100 billion in planned investments in AI next year. As a positive, third-quarter revenues grew 26% year over year, and their ad business continues to post impressive results, so the underlying business remains robust. NVIDIA (NVDA), the last of the Magnificent 7 to report earnings, is scheduled to report on November 19. According to FactSet data, the positive earnings surprises from companies in the information technology, consumer discretionary, and health care sectors were the most significant contributors to the S&P 500‚Äôs earnings growth rate increase last week. As detailed above, the communication services sector was the largest detractor due to Meta‚Äôs earnings miss. Within technology, Microsoft (MSFT) and Apple (AAPL) were the most significant positive drivers. Amazon.com (AMZN) was the most crucial positive surprise in consumer discretionary, while Eli Lilly (LLY), Merck (MRK), and Gilead Sciences (GILD) were the most notable positive surprises in health care. Sales growth at 7.9% is running well above expectations. Three sectors are on pace for double-digit year-over-year sales growth this quarter: information technology, communication services, and health care. With the government shutdown continuing to drag on, US economic releases should remain relatively sparse. Importantly, the widely watched monthly jobs report is likely to be delayed by the government closure. Instead, the private ADP employment change release on Wednesday and the Challenger job-cut announcement report on Thursday will attract more attention than usual as investors and economists gauge the softness of the US labor market. Third-quarter earnings reports will fill the void during the second busiest reporting week of the season. While a better-than-expected earnings season is all but assured, the individual company reports and any commentary about future earnings expectations remain crucial. As widely anticipated, the Federal Reserve (Fed) delivered a 25 basis point (0.25%) rate cut at its meeting last Wednesday. Fed Chair Powell pushed back harder than expected against the market expectations of another cut at the December meeting, sending the odds to a little less than a 2-in-3 chance. The calendar is chock-full of Fed members speaking this week, so their comments will be closely monitored to gauge better the likelihood of a Fed easing in December. Disclosure: Glenview Trust may hold the stocks mentioned in this article within its recommended investment strategies.

Title: What To Expect in Markets This Week: AMD, Palantir, Pharmaceutical and Tech Earnings; Private-Sector Employment Report
URL: https://www.investopedia.com/what-to-expect-in-markets-this-week-palantir-amd-pharmaceutical-and-tech-earnings-private-sector-employment-report-11838099
Time Published: 2025-11-02T12:00:00Z
Full Content:
Tech firms will likely command the spotlight during this week‚Äôs earnings calendar, though pharmaceuticals and gig economy providers are also likely to be in focus. Artificial intelligence demand will be top of mind for market watchers when chipmakers Advanced Micro Devices, Qualcomm, and Arm Holdings, as well as software provider Palantir, report earnings this week. Results from pharmaceutical firms come amid pressure from the Trump administration to lower prices. Market watchers are likely to pore over private-sector jobs data for October in the absence of the originally scheduled U.S. employment report, which is likely to be delayed again as the government shutdown enters its second month. Read to the bottom for our calendar of key events‚Äîand one more thing. Advanced Micro Devices will report on Tuesday, and investors will likely want to hear more about recent deals like the one signed in October to supply AI chips to Oracle. Other chipmakers are on the corporate earnings calendar this week, including Qualcomm, which last week unveiled two new AI chips for data centers. Chip designer Arm Holdings is also scheduled to report this week. In other tech-related reports, Palantir‚Äôs earnings on Monday come as the software maker‚Äôs shares have more than doubled this year on strong demand for its AI platforms. Cloud network provider Arista Networks is also on the calendar on Tuesday. Novo Nordisk reports on Wednesday, and the maker of Ozempic faces pressure from President Donald Trump over the costs of the weight loss treatment, which he said should run about $150 a month instead of the more than $1,000 it costs now. Other noteworthy pharmaceutical firms to report this week include Amgen, Pfizer, and AstraZeneca, and they come as firms have made deals to lower drug prices in response to Trump's threat of hefty pharmaceutical tariffs. Several key firms in the so-called ‚Äúgig economy‚Äù are also expected to report this week, including ride-sharing app Uber, food delivery service DoorDash, and property-rental app Airbnb. While the Federal Reserve has raised worries over the health of the labor market, the government shutdown is again expected to keep officials guessing over employment levels in the U.S. Originally scheduled for Friday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics' monthly employment report for October is expected to be delayed due to the work stoppage. It would be the second straight monthly jobs report delayed due to the shutdown, which is entering its second month. Data on factor orders, the U.S. trade balance, and job openings are also likely to be delayed due to the shutdown. Market watchers won‚Äôt be totally in the dark when it comes to jobs in the U.S., as the private-sector ADP employment report remains scheduled for release on Wednesday. The closely followed ISM surveys on the manufacturing and services sectors are also scheduled this week, giving investors some indications on employment and pricing in those sectors. The Fed‚Äôs report on consumer credit and the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment survey are also expected this week. Remarks from Philadelphia Fed President Anna Paulson, St. Louis Fed President Alberto Musalem, and New York Fed President John Williams will also be of note after the central bank last week cut interest rates for the second time this year. Quick Links: Recap Last Week‚Äôs Trading | Read Investopedia‚Äôs Latest News Monday, Nov. 3 Tuesday, Nov. 4 Wednesday, Nov. 5 Thursday, Nov. 6 Friday, Nov. 7 The Federal Reserve again cut interest rates last week, potentially leading to reductions in the rates that banks and credit unions pay on high-yield savings account deposits. Investopedia's Sabrina Karl has tips on how savvy savers can lock in better rates for months or years to come.

I don‚Äôt know why people become serial killers nor do I even care. I only know what should be done with them ‚Äì and with extreme prejudice. ‚ÄúWhy are we obsessed with serial killers?‚Äù Maybe because the killer in me is the killer in you‚Ä¶. Disarm, by Billy Corgan So I‚Äôve watched a few of these series below on the central villain, and there is overlap of a kind, like deciphering whether the cult leader( ie, Jeffs ) or the serial killer is actually the worse and more effective evil. Exerting control seems to be a recurring theme. ‚Äì Jeffrey Dahmer ‚Äì Warren Jeffs and the FLDS cult ( polygamy ) ‚Äì Ted Bundy ‚Äì John Wayne Gacy ‚Äì Zodiac These are all dark, and highly disturbing. I include the last entry since per the film, released in 2007 and possibly overlooked then, the alleged murderer was never actually caught or arrested for his crimes. My conclusion‚Ä¶some people are just not wired correctly from the get to. I actually have been a little curious about what the big deal is. Where I live, gang members have tens of bodies under their belts. There‚Äôre also a whole host of famous people who should be called serial killers but aren‚Äôt, like Obama. As far as I can tell, the only difference is that they lack individual notoriety for their crimes, for one reason or the other. The article doesn‚Äôt address this at all, unless I missed it and I would agree that the author‚Äôs reported curiousity may be less ubiquitous than they believe. It seems to me like the fascination with learning how other persons met with a miserable end is a phenomenom driven by news outlets (traditional and novel) hyping up particularly unique cases as a relatively easy sell for views/clicks etc.. The difference in the treatment is just stark. My news is always filled with the more prolific of the twenty or so deaths over the last week, sometimes barely afforded a paragraph because it‚Äôs the same old story over and over. Even when bodies do get found in pieces it‚Äôs not particularly earth-shattering. As far as I can tell, it seems to be that having a hundred known victims can never live up to the hype of leaving three of four bodies in sculpted positions. ‚ÄòSlasher‚Äô enthusiasts, I‚Äôm sure, hardly care to learn how Joe went from selling his body for food to doing his part, keeping morticians securely employed. Mass murderers, spree killers, serial killers are categories, but I guess the category closest to covering officially protected perps would be something like ‚Äústate sponsorsed terrorism‚Äù. US media is obsessed with serial killers (‚Äòwe‚Äô means them), because shocking content attracts audience. It‚Äôs softcore atrocity porn. A polarizing film but one I think captured this well was Oliver Stone‚Äôs ‚ÄúNatural Born Killers‚Äù. It‚Äôs too graphic and psychedelic for some but the way it portrays the media hype and popular fandom around a duo of serial killers was phenomenal in my opinion. Takes the old adage of ‚ÄúIf it bleeds, it leads‚Äù and turned the dial up to eleven to critique the 90‚Äôs era tabloid news like Hard Copy. Not sure if there are any modern equivalents but to me that film still holds up and remains relevant. In an awful comparison, serial killers are tantamount to aces in that you need 5 kills to establish yourself as such. Note to gun nuts intent on doing your worst: Any outcome in the single-digits is pretty much yeah whatever as far as Presstidigitation is concerned. It might not even make the front page of the internet-such is fate. By serial killers, do they mean social murders? Kills more people than any serial killer ever has. On the AI front, this below in today‚Äôs FT reporting the same thing that commenter Rasperry Jam has been saying, that much of AI‚Äôs immediate future is in specialized foundation models using proprietary data. . No archived link yet ‚Äî https://www.ft.com/content/91002071-7874-4cb7-9245-08ca0571c408 The new hot job in AI: forward-deployed engineers OpenAI, Anthropic and Cohere have stepped up hiring for specialists to help businesses adopt their AI models ‚Äò‚Ä¶Anthropic, OpenAI and Cohere are recruiting for so-called forward-deployed engineers, a new job for generative AI companies, as part of a push to generate more revenues by installing specialists within businesses to help them customise their AI models‚Ä¶. ‚Äò‚Ä¶The move comes as businesses across industries from manufacturing to healthcare are increasingly keen to adopt AI tools, but are often unsure how to use the technology and generate a return on investment. ‚ÄúA Fortune 500 bank has completely different needs than a start-up building an AI-native product,‚Äù said Cat de Jong, head of applied AI at Anthropic ‚Ä¶. ‚ÄòWhile FDEs (forward-deployed engineers) represent a relatively small number of AI groups‚Äô workforce, OpenAI said demand for these roles has exceeded its expectations. ‚ÄòThe group used this approach to customise its technology for John Deere, an agricultural machinery manufacturer, to help create more precise farming tools. This resulted in farmers reducing chemical spraying by 60 per cent to 70 per cent. ‚ÄòOpenAI‚Äôs Fournier said: ‚ÄúWe learn what customers in different industries really need, we experiment and innovate together, and then those insights help advance OpenAI‚Äôs research and product offerings based on what works in the real world.‚Äù Me: This is AI coming for McKinsey, Bain, and the like. i.e. Customers used to contract with a management consultancy firm, which then outourced a majority of work to an IT consultancy firm (ITF) that in turn might do 90% of work for 10% of contract value and the MCF took the rest. Any true value lay in which ITF the management consultant firm had the nous to choose. With AI, the ITF ‚Äî in this case, OpenAI, Anthropic, whichever‚Äì disintermediates McKinsey etc. and assigns their role to its own forward development engineers. So if those forward-deployed engineers are working with a Fortune 500 bank or a corporation like John Deere to tailor those AIs to them individually, would it also work out that they would also be funneling those corporation‚Äôs vital information back to Anthropic, OpenAI and Cohere for use as training set data? Yup. One thought, suppose there are better, more efficient AI models than Anthropic or Claude, buying into solution before problem‚Ä¶. Don‚Äôt rule out consulting yet. How about small language modules? Open labs* are raining small language models right now, some under 1B parameters, which is small enough to work (with patience) on any laptop. Most recently, LiquidAI published open-weight small models specialized for retrieval-augmented generation, summarization, information extraction, and mathematics. There has been a lot of recent work in vision and OCR surfacing recently as well. Small models are becoming more capable and efficient not only to encode or translate the text of a page or sign or describe a photo, but correctly read and reproduce sparse tables or describe the actions occurring between two video frames (with bounding boxes). * By open labs I mean those whose corporate future is not dependent on a world where all inference is centralized in a proprietary cloud, and who are not so motivated to hoard their IP or models. OpenAI and Anthropic, contrariwise, are worthless unless they can force the Western world to channel all its mechanical language processing through their machines and their meters. I think of OpenAI and Anthropic much like Uber, as regulatory plays intending to construct a regulatory environment in which the highly moderated service they offer is socially necessary, and alternatives are rendered illegal, unmerchantable, or impossible. Reminder that the ‚Äúanti‚Äù-AI movement is only a shaping operation in the larger war against local computation, and, being mainly funded and operated by US AI services majors, national security goons, and washed-up pundits trying to uphold a lifestyle, should only ever be held with the same absolute suspicion and cynical hostility as any other corporate astroturf. The myth is not entirely wrong for some health conditions. My mother-in-law had polio as an infant. At some point in her seventies and eighties she (and the medical profession discovered that her muscles only had so many contractions in them and that the exercises she had been doing to maintain her strength were weakening her. would it also work out that they would also be funneling those corporation‚Äôs vital information back to Anthropic, OpenAI and Cohere for use as training set data? Typically legal agreements are signed between the model provider and the company purchasing the services that the purchaser‚Äôs proprietary data, code, trade-protected processes ‚Äì anything that falls under IP ‚Äì remains under the control of the purchaser and is not the property of the model provider. What this means in practice is more nuanced: these companies are hiring the FDE‚Äôs as part of a service to create fine-tuned models trained on the customer‚Äôs data and processes, for exclusive use by the purchasing company. I‚Äôve worked on projects like this for my company; we didn‚Äôt have access to the customer‚Äôs IP directly. What we did was brought in the trainer application(s), taught the purchasing customer how to train their model, and provided guidance on how to configure, evaluate and deploy it after it was complete. We also taught them how to prompt/interact with the models based on what they were trying to do. We ‚Äì and likely these other model providers ‚Äì provide the purchasing company with the model trainer because taking the customer‚Äôs IP out of their network is a) probably too much data, I‚Äôm talking in excess of 50 terabytes b) no company‚Äôs security team is going to sign off on that no matter how lucrative/cool the end use case will be. So no, they probably aren‚Äôt taking the customer‚Äôs IP and sending it back to the primary frontier models for training in the way you are describing. They‚Äôre making a smaller version of the frontier model trained on the customer‚Äôs IP, for the customer‚Äôs exclusive use. The FDE are running the training and internal education projects. Sounds like Lean Six Sigma ‚Äúblack belts‚Äù. Maybe if Toyota did AI‚Ä¶.. Do these OpenAI deployed engineers have the business sense, to replace the usual business process redesign ‚Äúhelp‚Äù Do these OpenAI deployed engineers have the business sense, to replace the usual business process redesign ‚Äúhelp‚Äù They don‚Äôt work solo, they are always paired with an ‚Äúecho‚Äù team member (sometimes called a deployment strategist) who is the business/pm/person who interfaces directly with the customer technical and business leads. The FDE takes their orders from the DS; the customer yells at/makes demands of the DS. The DS is responsible for initial technical requirements gathering and ‚Äúphoning home‚Äù to the company when business facets change (expansion, contraction, new opportunities, etc). They aren‚Äôt there to fully alter the purchasing customer‚Äôs business processes but to help the customer achieve their goals with their purchase of the AI services. So it is more of an on-site service partnership than an outside consultant. I lead the deployment strategist team at my company. The ‚Äúforwards deployed‚Äù vocabulary is very militaristic. This strategy of embedding technical staff in the client on an open-ended consulting / brain-siphoning engagement is held up as the secret of Palantir‚Äôs ‚Äúsuccess‚Äù. I wonder if the buzzword comes from them too‚Ä¶. Anyway, we‚Äôre doing exactly this with our AI Fintech, building a very niche model and, yes, hiring forward deployed engineers for its deployment. Even amateurs know that measuring pulse after waking up is how one can gauge change over time, and that it gets lower as you get in shape. These results challenge a long-held belief, once repeated by US President Donald Trump, that the human body is like a battery with a limited energy supply and that exercise only depletes it. Why Do Spiders Decorate Their Webs? A New Piece of the Puzzle Nautilus ~~~~~~~~~~~ I find black widow webs to be the most fascinating, almost looks as if the 8 legged one was on an acid trip during construction of. So intricate and chaotic-but with a purpose. Then there was the time NASA fed various psychotropics to spiders and photographed the results. See: https://rarehistoricalphotos.com/nasa-spiders-drugs-experiment/ Here‚Äôs a video that introduced me to that research https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bZoZhM0E8Ow I work in this area and this is my experience. Large companies (and some not so large) are extremely paranoid about allowing the AI companies to use their vital information for training. The major AI players all sell private instances where users are assured that no one outside of their company can use their data for training or analyze the custom models. They put language in contracts and audits are conducted by 3rd parties to verify these claims. Its above my pay grade to determine what they are really doing behind the scenes, but given the way the contracts are written it would be a major scandal if they ever got caught cheating. A big worry to many is the user sending private information to the models running in public instances which do not have these guarantees. My employer blocks these sites, and we‚Äôre all told to use the private version. A second worry that is coming on strong is the use of Chinese models like DeepSeek and Qwen (even privately maintained versions using open source) . More companies are adopting policies where these are forbidden because, I assume, the Chinese cannot be trusted. One company described it as ‚Äúgeopolitical models are forbidden‚Äù. Re: Scientists just shattered a major exercise myth This is not new. back in the 70‚Äôs a friend gave me the ‚Äúusing up extra heartbeats‚Äù thing and I pointed out that: 3 mile run at 160 beats per min 160*20 = 3200 beats warm up cool down and other activity 120 beats per min 120*40 = 4800 beats resting pulse 50 for the rest of the day 23*60*50 = 69000 beats total 3200 + 4800 +69000 = 77000 beats per day him resting pulse 72*24*60 = 103689 beats per day (this assumes that during every day activity, his pulse is the same amount above resting pulse as mine) he started taking the stairs yeah this is some seriously auld news. It‚Äôs good to get it out there anyway as lots of the kids these days are all weights and no cardio. All weights and no cardio is also auld news, and no legs day too. ‚ÄòMassimo @Rainmaker1973 Students in China are encouraged to rest and nap during school.‚Äô If those kids are doing a 12 hour day, then this is a vital necessity. I learned the most from my own studies after I came home from school and from the time I spent at the public library and in my room attempting to write the most convincing essay I could for a homework assignment. Once I reached an age of double digits, I estimate that many, though not all days, I may have spent more than 12 hours per day studying when I add my study at home with the time spent in the classroom. I also greatly value the time I spent learning to play a musical instrument, or wandering in nature and in museums or attending the Summer Shakespeare plays and orchestral concerts my parents brought me and my siblings to. I believe schools and parents should foster a love for learning, endless curiosity, imagination, and questioning the ‚Äòright answer‚Äô in a way I did not see or sense in the schooling of my own children. The speeches that night reflected the despondent mood inside the U.S. attorney‚Äôs office in Washington, as the lawyers who were quitting urged those staying behind to forge ahead in uncertain times. Do what‚Äôs right, they said. Speak truth to power. Uphold the rule of law. But as the hour grew later ‚Äî and the bar tab bigger ‚Äî the politics that have buffeted the office for months suddenly intruded on the evening, people who were there recounted later. In a quiet corner, away from the charcuterie and veggie dip, Jonathan Hornok, a top aide to Jeanine Pirro, the Trump appointee picked to run the office, was firing Jon Hooks, a senior prosecutor who had worked there for nearly 20 years. That a respected supervisor with a long career could be stripped of his job in the middle of a farewell party for his colleagues captured something of the Darwinian tumult that has wracked the prosecutors‚Äô office since President Trump returned to the White House and set about remaking the Justice Department in his image. Title: Reddit‚Äôs CEO Debuts As A Billionaire 20 Years After Cofounding The Company
URL: https://www.forbes.com/sites/monicahunter-hart/2025/11/01/reddits-ceo-debuts-as-a-steve-huffman-billionaire-20-years-after-cofounding-the-company/
Time Published: 2025-11-02T11:30:00Z
Full Content:
ByMonica Hunter-Hart, Forbes Staff. Reddit has hit its stride. After trudging through 19 years of almost entirely losing money, the platform recorded its first quarterly profit as a public company a year ago‚Äîand just posted its most lucrative financials yet. The company announced a net income of $163 million on Thursday, marking five consecutive quarters of profitability, about a year and a half after going public. The market rewarded the company. Reddit‚Äôs stock closed at $208.95 on Friday, up 7.5% from the previous day and up 75% year over year. It was enough to bump the fortune of cofounder and CEO Steve Huffman up to $1.2 billion. ‚ÄúQ3 was a strong quarter,‚Äù Huffman said on Thursday‚Äôs earnings call, in which he lauded Reddit as being ‚Äúfor humans by humans‚Äù and seemed to take a subtle dig at AI slop (the low-quality AI content clogging corners of the internet): ‚ÄúReddit is in a unique position; we‚Äôre not trying to be the next anything. We‚Äôre focused on being the best version of ourselves and what the internet needs most: a place where people can connect on almost any topic and find genuinely useful information.‚Äù Authentic human recommendations are a hot commodity these days. As bots and sponsored content crowd the internet, Reddit is often seen as a more reliable source of information, and its popularity has exploded in the past couple of years. Daily active users have approximately doubled since the summer of 2023. Google searches increasingly surface links to Reddit: Organic search to the platform is up over 560% from two years ago, per data from digital marketing firm Semrush. Given that Facebook, Twitter (now X) and LinkedIn long ago minted a class of early-2000s social media billionaires, it may seem surprising that Huffman is so late to join that club. After all, Reddit was the world‚Äôs seventh-most visited website in September, according to Similarweb, ahead of LinkedIn, TikTok and Netflix. But that‚Äôs because Huffman, now 41, unloaded his founder‚Äôs stake in the then startup in 2006. About a year after launching the company in June 2005, he and his partner Alexis Ohanian‚Äînow a venture capitalist married to tennis icon Serena Williams‚Äîsold out to Cond√© Nast for just $10 million. It seemed an enormous sum for them at the time, the pair has said. Without any plans for monetization, and overwhelmed with running the exploding platform with just a few employees, they viewed the acquisition as a rescue. Perhaps in the short term, but long term, they left massive sums on the table. By 2014, the company was valued at $500 million. Ohanian, who joined Reddit‚Äôs board in 2014 but left in 2020, has said he did reacquire some shares while on the board, but likely gets most of his fortune from his many startup investments. Huffman, on the other hand, appears to be Reddit‚Äôs biggest individual shareholder these days. That‚Äôs because Reddit poached him back in 2015 to help navigate a streak of operational crises. His pay-for-performance compensation package has since allowed him to amass 3.1 million shares, or a 2.3% stake in the company. The rest of his fortune lies in Reddit stock options and $190 million in cash and other investments, Forbes estimates. Huffman declined to comment for this story. While generous stock awards are common among the billionaire CEO set‚ÄîTesla investors are even weighing whether to approve a $1 trillion compensation package for Elon Musk this week‚Äîit‚Äôs rare for an executive to build up such a significant stake essentially from scratch. In its 2024 IPO document, the company explained that it had massively increased the compensation of Huffman and COO Jen Wong the previous year because their packages had not been ‚Äúproviding the incentive initially intended‚Äù; Huffman‚Äôs ballooned to $193.2 million in 2023. It‚Äôs easy to argue that he‚Äôs earned his payday. When he became CEO in 2015, Reddit was in a state of emergency. The company was moderating content with an ultra-light touch, but it was becoming clear that some ‚Äúsubreddit‚Äù communities were overwhelmed with toxicity and harassment. When Reddit fired a popular employee who had been the company‚Äôs main contact with its volunteer moderators, moderators protested by shutting down their subreddits in what became known as the ‚ÄúGreat Reddit Blackout.‚Äù A week later, Huffman took over. ‚ÄúIt was 10 years into Reddit of ‚Äòwe don‚Äôt ban things,‚Äô‚Äù he recently told ‚ÄúThe Best One Yet‚Äù podcast. ‚ÄúI think that was one of the things that only a founder can do, because the existing team at Reddit was so scared. This is what they told me: They were scared of changing anything, because they thought they‚Äôd ruin Reddit.‚Äù Huffman began by implementing the platform‚Äôs first content policy, which included prohibitions on spam, bullying, inciting violence and illegal activity. His team quickly banned a collection of subreddits, including some devoted to animated child pornography and a network of racist subs promoting ‚Äúa proper society that lacks the negro plague.‚Äù Reddit began ‚Äúquarantining‚Äù subs it deemed licit but especially offensive, requiring users to opt in before viewing their content. One example: r/PicsOfDeadKids, which was fully banned a few years later, as sometimes happens to quarantined subs. The goal was to make the space not only more pleasant for users, but also more attractive for advertisers. (Reddit does not run promotions on quarantined content.) Huffman and his team fixated early on advertising as the best initial monetization strategy for Reddit, in part because it could help them keep the platform free. ‚ÄúHe built the company‚Äôs advertising business from the ground up,‚Äù says Morningstar analyst Malik Ahmed Khan. One of the challenges has been helping brands target their ads without compromising Reddit‚Äôs pivotal user anonymity. Unlike platforms like Meta and Google‚Äîwhich allow promoters to personalize ads based on demographic data and broader tracking across the internet‚ÄîReddit requires brands to use context clues. If a user joins a parenting subreddit or upvotes posts about pregnancy, for example, they may be more likely to see promotions for baby products. So far, it‚Äôs working. Advertising brought in $549 million last quarter, 94% of Reddit‚Äôs revenue. The company was generating only around $12 to $15 million in total sales when Huffman joined. New challenges lie ahead. Reddit is at the nexus of many of today‚Äôs hot-button debates, from the ethics around training AI models on user data to compromises between free speech and content moderation to the viability of text-based content in an online culture that‚Äôs increasingly focused on video. Huffman appears unfazed: ‚ÄúNo matter what you‚Äôre going through, someone on Reddit has already been there, done that, and shared the story,‚Äù he said Thursday. ‚ÄúThe best pitch for Reddit is Reddit‚Äôs content.‚Äù The son of divorced parents, Huffman grew up in a small town in Virginia near Washington, D.C. Starting and running his own business ‚Äúalways seemed like a possibility,‚Äù he once said, thanks in part to his father‚Äôs wild imagination for ventures (he was an engineer at GM) and his stepdad‚Äôs financial savviness (he was chief marketing officer at Unisys). He learned how to program computers when he was young and leveraged the hobby into a computer science degree at the University of Virginia, where he met Ohanian. By the end of their senior year, the pair knew they wanted to start some sort of company together. It was just the concept that needed tweaking. Huffman‚Äôs first idea was software for ordering food on a phone. The task sounds quaint and obvious now, but this was before the app era‚Äîand the newly formed startup accelerator Y Combinator rejected their pitch, termed ‚ÄúMy Mobile Menu.‚Äù Y Combinator cofounder Paul Graham was nevertheless impressed enough with the duo that he asked them to submit another idea. Their second pitch was accepted. With a $12,000 grant in hand, they spent a few weeks designing Reddit before launching it shortly after their graduation, when Huffman was 21. Then came snowballing user growth, 16-hour workdays and the eventual sale to Cond√© Nast. Huffman stayed on as acting CEO until 2009, when he left to cofound another company: the travel search engine Hipmunk. Concur acquired Hipmunk in 2016 for an undisclosed sum and shut it down in 2020. Meanwhile, Cond√© Nast had spun out Reddit again and raised funds from outside investors like future OpenAI cofounder Sam Altman, but was having trouble monetizing the business. That‚Äôs when Huffman stepped back in. In addition to building ad revenue, Huffman‚Äôs early projects included a site redesign and the creation of a mobile app. The platform, which had 12 million daily users when he rejoined, now has 116 million. Reddit has historically been a U.S.-centric site, but it recently implemented translation capabilities for 30 languages so that users can easily read and contribute in their non-native tongues. That‚Äôs led to a 31% bump in international daily users over the past year. These days, Reddit‚Äôs second biggest source of revenue is licensing its content to train AI models. The platform used to allow free and open access to its application programming interface (API), where developers interact with all of the site‚Äôs data. But Reddit started charging for its API in 2023. It now works to block unknown bots from crawling the site, and is suing a handful of AI companies‚Äîincluding the search engine Perplexity‚Äîfor allegedly scraping its data without permission. A select few have paid for permission. Huffman signed licensing deals with Google and OpenAI last year for a reported $60 million and $70 million, respectively. The site‚Äôs enormous collection of real-time, human-generated content has proven to be extremely valuable: Reddit was the most-cited source for Google‚Äôs AI Overview citations, and the second-most for ChatGPT‚Äôs, between August 2024 and June 2025, per the AI analytics platform Profound. Given Reddit‚Äôs centrality to their models, those fees could be seen as quite low. The $60 million Google reportedly paid is just 0.07% of the more than $90 billion that its parent company Alphabet (market cap: $3.4 trillion) expects to spend on AI infrastructure this year. ‚ÄúThose price tags set a low watermark,‚Äù says Colin Sebastian, senior research analyst at Baird. ‚ÄúAs Reddit has more negotiating leverage, as the power of their content becomes more clear to the models, then I think the next deals should likely be priced higher than that.‚Äù And there‚Äôs always the risk that Reddit, in propping up AI chatbots, could diminish its own relevance. As something of a hedge, Huffman launched ‚ÄúReddit Answers‚Äù in December, later telling investors that he wants the platform to become a ‚Äúgo-to search engine.‚Äù A search query into ‚ÄúReddit Answers‚Äù returns a list of quoted recommendations from real users (with links to the original comments), collated by AI. Huffman has acknowledged that Google search traffic to Reddit has at times been challenged by the rise of AI but again is confident in its future. ‚ÄúPart of what helps them balance on the tightrope is that I think the language models want Reddit to survive,‚Äù says Sebastian. ‚ÄúRealistically, these models need a constant flow of authentic, human-generated content, and that‚Äôs hard to find. It can‚Äôt just be synthetic data. So there‚Äôs almost a perverse incentive for Google and Open AI to keep Reddit as a robust app for users.‚Äù To personally test that Reddit user experience, Huffman spends a fair amount of time on the platform himself. He‚Äôs published over 1,000 posts and comments; he hosts AMAs (‚ÄúAsk Me Anything‚Äù sessions). Prior to the earnings announcement, his last activity was an Oct. 3 comment in response to a user celebrating that the 117 Reddit shares they‚Äôd bought at the IPO had since gone up more than 500% in value. Huffman replied with a smiley face. This story was updated at 12 p.m. on Sunday after Reddit replied with some additional context including the fact that Q3 2024 was the company‚Äôs third profitable quarter. The other two profitable quarters were when the company was private.
--------------------------------------------------

Title: Here's What We Learned From Big Tech Earnings Last Week
URL: https://www.investopedia.com/here-is-what-we-learned-from-big-tech-earnings-last-week-11841183
Time Published: 2025-11-02T11:00:00Z
Full Content:
Earnings season kicked into high gear last week when five of the Magnificent Seven members with a combined market value of over $15 trillion reported results. The tech titans‚ÄîApple (AAPL), Microsoft (MSFT), Alphabet (GOOG), Amazon (AMZN), and Meta (META)‚Äîreported better-than-expected results across the board, and forecast their massive investments in artificial intelligence will grow in the coming year. Below, we take a closer look at some of the key takeaways from this round of big tech earnings. These tech giants account for a sizable share of the U.S. stock market, making their quarterly earnings some of the most highly anticipated and consequential events on Wall Street. Their investments in artificial intelligence have also been a boon to the U.S. economy over the last year. One thing made clear in last week's earnings calls, was that the hyperscalers‚Äô AI investments are showing no signs of a pullback. Amazon on Thursday raised its full-year capital expenditures forecast and said that investments will increase next year. Alphabet also bumped up its capex guidance for the third time this year and forecast another ‚Äúsignificant‚Äù increase next year. Microsoft didn‚Äôt share a quarterly or full-year capex estimate, but CFO Amy Hood said investments will grow even faster in fiscal year 2026 than in 2025. Executives stressed that, despite their massive investments up to this point, they expect demand will continue to outstrip supply into next year. Microsoft‚Äôs cloud computing platform, Azure, likely bore the brunt of its capacity constraints, according to Hood, who said the company has been forced to prioritize other core business offerings. She, like Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg, also said that their internal AI teams need more computing capacity. Citi analysts in a note on Thursday said they expect cloud data center capex to grow 24% in 2026, which should be a boon to semiconductor makers like Nvidia (NVDA), Broadcom (AVGO), and Advanced Micro Devices (AMD). Spending on data centers is all well and good with Wall Street, as long as investors perceive rising profits will make it worthwhile. Meta shares tanked on Thursday after the company posted earnings that missed estimates due to a one-time tax charge, and raised the low end of its full-year capex guidance. Meta also said it expects its capex growth will accelerate next year. "The real focus coming out of earnings is Meta's updated view on 2026 capex and expenses as the company looks to build out an industry-leading amount of compute," JPMorgan analysts told clients in a note Thursday. "The costs for Meta are outsized relative to Google and Amazon, as those companies are larger and both have cloud businesses that provide an immediate path to Gen AI monetization, unlike for Meta,‚Äù they said. Higher operating costs added to Wall Street‚Äôs concerns about Meta‚Äôs AI spending. Total expenses rose 32% year-over-year in the third quarter, compared to 12% in the previous quarter, and are expected to grow even faster next year. Employee compensation was one of the largest contributors to rising expenses. Meta went on an AI hiring spree this year, making headlines for poaching top talent with eye-watering pay packages. That's added more pressure on Meta to find ways to cut costs. Recent reports of layoffs, including in its AI division, could point to some signs of strain in Meta's efforts to keep its spending in check. In the first inning of the AI craze on Wall Street, Alphabet was often looked at as a laggard in the space. Its Bard chatbot flubbed its first public demonstration, and analysts worried that the rising popularity of chatbots from startups like OpenAI, Anthropic, and Perplexity, could spell major disruption for Google‚Äôs core search business. However, Alphabet's strong quarterly results‚Äîthanks in part to AI search features‚Äîwould counter that narrative. According to executives, Google‚Äôs AI search features, AI Overviews and AI Mode, are helping to increase search query volume, the opposite of what Wall Street expected. Google‚Äôs search revenue growth has accelerated throughout the year, rising from 10% to 12% in the second quarter, and then to 15% in the third. Executives added that Google is monetizing AI search queries at about the same rate as traditional search. ‚ÄúSearch acceleration (paid clicks up 7% vs 4% in 2Q) despite OpenAI's strong usage growth suggests AI is expanding the overall ‚Äòinformation‚Äô opportunity, driving higher query volume and improving monetization,‚Äù wrote Bank of America analysts in a note on Thursday. Some investors have become concerned in recent months that the AI boom is being fueled by a handful of companies striking very large deals. For example, OpenAI accounted for nearly all of Oracle‚Äôs (ORCL) massive cloud computing backlog in the most recent quarter, and Nvidia said in its most recent earnings report that two direct customers accounted for almost 40% of its quarterly sales. But Microsoft executives sought to soothe worries about concentration risks during Wednesday‚Äôs earnings call. When asked about the breadth of contracts contributing to Microsoft‚Äôs record backlog, which grew 51% to $392 billion, CFO Amy Hood said, ‚Äúit covers numerous products. It covers customers of all sizes." CEO Satya Nadella also suggested he sees broadening demand related to AI over time, telling analysts, ‚Äúconcentration risk gets mitigated by being thoughtful about how you really ensure the build is for the broad customer base.‚Äù The wider enterprise adoption cycle, he said, "is just starting."
--------------------------------------------------

Title: Hotels catering for families with autistic children: ‚ÄòNobody looks or stares at you‚Äô
URL: https://www.irishtimes.com/life-style/travel/2025/11/02/hotels-catering-for-families-with-autistic-children-nobody-looks-or-stares-at-you/
Time Published: 2025-11-02T05:00:00Z
Full Content:
When Melanie* travelled abroad in July for a family holiday to Mallorca, Spain, with her six-year-old son Luke*, she found Dublin Airport stressful. Originally from Slovakia, Melanie, who works in finance, and her Irish-born husband have younger children ‚Äì two-year-old twins ‚Äì but Luke has profound autism and finds airports challenging. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre always worried there will be delays. You‚Äôre worried the plane could be sitting on the tarmacadam for three hours. If I have to keep him on a plane for five hours, he will probably walk off the plane. It‚Äôs too much,‚Äù she says. Luke has limited verbal skills and, in common with many autistic children, a tendency to abscond. ‚ÄúHe runs away if he feels like it. One year when we were abroad we had to move chairs and luggage to block the door. The same goes for balconies.‚Äù Dining on holidays is difficult. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs very limited with his diet. He will eat chips or bologna sauce but the one I make because that‚Äôs the one he knows,‚Äù Melanie says. ‚ÄúSo there‚Äôs anxiety around food because the food needs to be always the same. If it‚Äôs too much for him, he will lie down on the floor. It doesn‚Äôt matter where you are, he will just lie down. For us, it‚Äôs much easier to stay in Ireland.‚Äù For some families with autistic children, going on a break can feel harder than being at home. Lack of predictability, absence of routine and the anxieties and stress that may come with meltdowns in public settings can result in families avoiding holidays altogether. [ Why neurodivergent people are now coveted as highly skilled workers ] But as awareness has improved ‚Äì it‚Äôs estimated one in 20 children in school today has an autism diagnosis ‚Äì more hotels are retraining staff and improving facilities to cater to families with diverse needs. Adam Harris, of the autism charity AsIAm, which is working with hotels on training and awareness, says: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs an important momentum gathering. Contributing to that is our autism-friendly town initiative. Clonakilty, Maynooth, Drumcondra, Killarney and Waterford city have achieved the standard. Dublin city is working towards it. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs huge momentum and hotels are at the table in that regard. We‚Äôre in the process of doing accreditation with the whole iNua group,‚Äù which is Ireland‚Äôs largest regional hotel group, ‚Äúso that‚Äôs exciting.‚Äù In Dublin, the Ashling Hotel on Parkgate Street, situated near the Zoo in the Phoenix Park and close to hospitals including St James‚Äôs, has 11 family rooms. Since 2023, one of these has been transformed into a sensory room, which is kitted out with mood cubes, weighted blankets, vibrating pillows and low levels of lighting. Ciara Barry of the Ashling says: ‚ÄúSome autistic people are sensitive to light, others to noise, others to touch. They‚Äôre able to sit down and just hug the pillow and it calms their nervous system.‚Äù Ashling staff have also received autism awareness training and the hotel endeavours to keep the same managers on rotation to welcome returning autistic children so they see a face they know. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre not just upgrades that we‚Äôve done, they‚Äôre meaningful experiences for people under sometimes tough circumstances,‚Äù Barry says. The room rate (from around ‚Ç¨260 for a family room per night) is the same as for other family rooms in the hotel, an important factor given it is estimated that it costs an additional ‚Ç¨28,000 a year to raise an autistic child. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt something we wanted to financially benefit from. We just wanted to put something out into the community that‚Äôs needed,‚Äù she says. In developing their facilities, the Ashling took inspiration from other hotels around the country. ‚ÄúWe were the first hotel in Dublin, but I linked up with the Pillo hotel in Meath ‚Äì they were one of the first to implement a sensory bedroom ‚Äì and the Radisson in Sligo have also done it,‚Äù Barry says. [ We need a more nuanced conversation about autism ] The hotel also worked with Keith O‚ÄôGrady from Sensory House Ireland, which specialises in designing playrooms featuring everything from memory-foam bean bags to weighted teddy bears, lighted bubble tubes and projectors. These help to capture and regulate attention spans O‚ÄôGrady says: ‚ÄúUltimately you‚Äôre creating a space for calming within spaces like hotels, which can be over-stimulating, or anywhere with high footfall. We‚Äôve done shopping centres, hospitals, the Curragh Racecourse, secondary schools like Blackrock College. ‚ÄúThe most important things are to block out natural light and sound. People can be dysregulated by sunbeams hitting their eyes and fluorescent lighting can have the same effect. ‚ÄúThe easiest way to explain to people is you‚Äôre trying to emulate the feeling of going into a spa. A relaxing environment with nice ambient lighting ‚Äì that‚Äôs the effect you‚Äôre trying to create. You‚Äôre hopefully giving a space that they can go into, block out stimuli, and it gives them time to re-regulate themselves.‚Äù When it works, he says, families build trust with the hotels and come back time and again. ‚ÄúIn the Ashling, people are coming back specifically to go to that hotel because they have that sensory bedroom.‚Äù It benefits all the family too, not just the autistic child, he says. ‚ÄúIf families have a get-together, there might be only one autistic kid within the family, and it‚Äôs so they can go to that hotel, everyone can have a good time and it‚Äôs inclusive for everyone, the autistic person and not.‚Äù In Clonakilty, Co Cork, the Park Hotel and Fernhill House have evolved their offerings for neurodiverse guests. Irene O‚ÄôCallaghan, of the Park, says: ‚ÄúWe have sensory packs: the idea being that they have something to touch, something to smell and something to squeeze.‚Äù As soon as you mention that your child is autistic, it‚Äôs like ‚Äòno problem‚Äô. Nobody looks at you or stares at you Because routine and predictability can be important, the hotel offers a picture guide of what to expect when guests are visiting for the first time. With staff trained in autism awareness, the hotel tries to anticipate issues before any arise. ‚ÄúDuring the week we had a lady whose child liked a specific kind of pancake. She told us that in advance so we were able to get them in. That really helps,‚Äù she says. In addition to family rooms, the Park has 20 apartments and six units that are fully self-catering. ‚ÄúWe would have kids who would be flight risks,‚Äù O‚ÄôCallaghan says. ‚ÄúIn our apartments we have put additional locks on the inside, so we‚Äôve those extra little mechanisms.‚Äù While not overtly geared towards those families, Center Parcs is a popular destination for parents with neurodiverse children ‚Äì their self-catering lodges set across 400 acres in Longford Forest offer a soothing, low-stimulation environment. ‚ÄúI know many people say Center Parcs is very expensive, but my boy loves it,‚Äù Melanie says. ‚ÄúIn the kitchen, I can make his meals. He learned to swim in Center Parcs because they have a slide where, to let you on, you have to be able to swim without a swimming aid. So he actually learned to swim from one side of the pool to the other so he could go down the slide. It was amazing. I never thought he would be able to swim. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs huge supervision there. As soon as you mention that your child is autistic, it‚Äôs like ‚Äòno problem‚Äô. Nobody looks at you or stares at you.‚Äù For Etain*, an IT professional based in Dublin, who has four-year-old twin sons who are autistic, ‚Äúthe challenges come sideways at you‚Äù. Her twins were diagnosed in May, after they had started at preschool. ‚ÄúWe just thought, ‚ÄòOh my God, twins are complete chaos‚Äô. It took us a while to come around to the idea that our perfect little men might have been a bit different. ‚ÄúWhat we realised through that process was that we‚Äôd set up our life around the boys. Everything inside our bubble suited the boys. We had a nice routine. It was only when you went into the outside world that things got tricky.‚Äù The boys have differing needs and challenges. Noise can be a trigger: the white noise of hand-driers in public toilets or crying babies; big crowds another. When the family gets an invitation to go somewhere, Etain thinks long and hard about what‚Äôs best. ‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs not something the boys are going to enjoy, we‚Äôre not just going to go so we have an Instagrammable photo.‚Äù She gravitates towards holiday homes in autism-friendly towns, where a minimum of 25 per cent of businesses in the town have undergone autism awareness training. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs definitely a plus,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIt means you‚Äôre more likely to get a warm welcome from local businesses. If a child is finding a situation stressful, it means they don‚Äôt look at that child as a ‚Äòbold child‚Äô.‚Äù When we speak, Etain is packing the car for Clonakilty for a family trip. ‚ÄúClonakilty has a model railway village, which is a huge hit with our boys who love trains.‚Äù In their Airbnb, ‚Äúthe boys can see the sea from the garden. The garden is enclosed. I just love the freedom of them running around.‚Äù Having last visited at Easter, the twins have been excited about the upcoming trip for months. ‚ÄúThe boys have had a 60-day countdown on the calendar on the fridge,‚Äù she says. Etain is willing to stay in a hotel with her sons, but it‚Äôs rarely her first choice. What would make a difference? ‚ÄúWhat hotels need to realise is parents don‚Äôt want to bring chaos. You‚Äôre not expecting people to roll out the red carpet, but small gestures like having quiet spaces or being accommodating if someone asks for a larger room, or getting your same table in the breakfast room ‚Äì all those things make a difference. ‚ÄúIn the La Mon outside Belfast, we get the same room every time we go. The hotel is spacious with a lovely quiet pool area and very warm, welcoming staff who remember the boys every time we visit, which is why we always go back.‚Äù Friendly staff, quiet spaces, a dedication to people‚Äôs needs: what‚Äôs not to like? Harris hopes more businesses will incorporate inclusive design and autism awareness training once they realise it‚Äôs an approach that makes sense for all. ‚ÄúWho doesn‚Äôt like clear communication? Who doesn‚Äôt like having predictability about what the experience is going to be like? Who doesn‚Äôt want to feel welcomed and not judged?‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúWhat is essential for an autistic family coming on holiday can actually be good for everybody.‚Äù *Some names have been changed. ¬© 2025 The Irish Times DAC
--------------------------------------------------
