Title: 3 Signs That Institutions Continue To Drive Crypto Adoption
URL: https://www.forbes.com/sites/digital-assets/2025/11/01/3-signs-that-institutions-continue-to-drive-crypto-adoption/
Time Published: 2025-11-01T20:24:29Z
Full Content:
BySean Stein Smith, Contributor. Despite the price of bitcoin still making headlines, states issuing dollar-backed stablecoins, and payments use cases dominating the conversation, there are substantial other headlines that investors might have missed in this flurry of activity. Particularly with the end of 2025 approaching, and with that the increased importance and focus of tax-related conversations, investors and advocates need to be especially vigilant to analyze institutional developments as well as what these deployments might mean for the wider marketplace. Another reason why certain investors and advocates might have overlooked the headlines below is the renewed focus that crypto hacks and breaches have brought to bear on the weaknesses that still exist within the marketplace. Be it the Bybit hack that exposed the dangers of institutionally backed hacking efforts, the debut of the film Code Is Law that examined the elements of the crypto landscape that believe regulatory safeguards are optional, or the billions lost through less spectacular hacking attempts the focus has rightly returned to cybersecurity, risks around client data, and the lack of insurance solutions for crypto products. In short, the tail end of 2025 has had a bevy of headlines (good and bad), policy updates and developments that have the potential to obscure just how widespread institutional adoption has become. Let‚Äôs take a look at some of those, as well as what the implications might be for investors and advocates alike. According to several sources, Mastercard is in late-stage talks to acquire stablecoin infrastructure platform Zerohash for nearly $2 billion, and while this specific acquisition is not finalized as of this writing, it is indicative of how payment processing giants are prioritizing stablecoins and on-chain payments. Stablecoins have been in the spotlight recently, with a number of recent wins on the policy front as well as the deployment of stablecoin/stabletoken solutions by several major TradFi institutions. With adjusted annual volume of approximately $9 trillion, taking into account bot-based trading and other potentially artificially inflated trading activity, the sheer size of the stablecoin payment space is appealing to the payment processing space. Even as margins continue to face headwinds from a competitive and legislative point of view, stablecoins have the potential to open up an almost entirely new market for payment processors to expand. Bringing together the familiarity and security that customers have come to expect from household names such as Mastercard with the crypto-native improvements delivered via stablecoins is looking like the ‚Äúkiller-app‚Äù that crypto has been looking for. Another payment processing giant, Visa, is also expanding its product and service offerings focusing on stablecoin utilization and payments running on four unique blockchains. Visa CEO Ryan McInerney reiterated the firms commitment. As these new services come online, Visa will have added support for four stablecoins running on four blockchains that will be able to converted into 25 fiat currencies. This announcement expands the support that Visa already provides to other stablecoins including USDC, Euro Coin (EURC), PayPal USD (PYUSD) on multiple blockchains. According to Visa the firm has facilitated $140 billion worth of stablecoin flows since 2020, further cementing the reality that stablecoins have 1) grown rapidly in terms of institutional usage, 2) taken center stage as the ‚Äúevery day‚Äù crypto use case, and 3) delivers quantifiable benefits to organizations involved in the transactions. This announcement is the foundational layer for other forthcoming efforts that will allow more banks and TradFi institutions to provide stablecoin related services, including the eventual ability of banks to mint and burn native stablecoins on the Visa tokenized asset platform. Visa continues to move to integrate TradFi banking products and services with the crypto-native space, and is another example of stablecoins are leading the effort to bring crypto to the mainstream via stablecoins. The global asset management giant Blackrock has certainly made its presence known in the crypto marketplace, with its leading spot bitcoin ETF having attracted over $100 billion in assets. Additionally, a recent announcement that Securitize (a Blackrock-backed tokenization firm) will be going public via a SPAC deal valued at $1.25 billion cements. The fact that the merger will occur with an affiliate of Cantor Fitzgerald, itself a longtime service provider to Tether and the USDT token, cements the pivot of Wall Street to the tokenized ecosystem. Since Securitize operated in the real-world-asset tokenization space, a sector that Blackrock CEO Larry Fink has forecasted could hit a size of $10 trillion, the implications of this merger are significant. Tokenization or RWA is a pivotal part of the forecasted growth of DeFi systems, DAOs, and other blockchain-based applications built for enterprise use. Given the scope and scale of support provided by both Blackrock and Cantor Fitzgerald the effect of this listing are sure to be felt across the space. Crypto makes headlines on a daily basis, but sometimes the most significant ones can fly under the radar; those are the ones investors should be sure to watch.
--------------------------------------------------

Title: NVIDIA (NVDA) CEO Is Confident Chinese Military Won‚Äôt Use His GPUs, Says Jim Cramer
URL: https://finance.yahoo.com/news/nvidia-nvda-ceo-confident-chinese-193012586.html
Time Published: 2025-11-01T19:30:12Z
Description: We recently published 10 Stocks on Jim Cramer‚Äôs Radar. NVIDIA Corporation (NASDAQ:NVDA) is one of the stocks Jim Cramer recently discussed. NVIDIA...
--------------------------------------------------

Title: Mamdani‚Äôs God Squad: The clerics, activists and political operatives who have his back
URL: https://www.foxnews.com/politics/mamdanis-god-squad-clerics-activists-political-operatives-who-have-his-back
Time Published: 2025-11-01T18:37:34Z
Full Content:
Fox News' Bill Hemmer breaks down the latest on key races to watch nationwide, including the New York City mayoral election and the gubernatorial races in Virginia and New Jersey. When New York mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani stepped to the microphone outside the Islamic Cultural Center of the Bronx last week near Yankee Stadium, his voice broke as he spoke about "the memory of my aunt who stopped taking the subway after Sept. 11 because she did not feel safe." Behind him, a Yemeni-American educator in sunglasses named Debbie Almontaser nodded. Almost two decades ago, in 2007, she was forced to resign as principal of a city school after defending a T-shirt with the slogan "Intifada NYC." City officials viewed it as a call to violence. She said it was benign. Her case became a rallying cry for Muslim American activists who cast her as a victim of "Islamophobia." FBI AGENTS FROM '93 WTC ATTACK BLAST MAMDANI FOR EMBRACING RADICAL IMAM Now, Almontaser was back, this time as a senior advisor to Emgage Action and a board member of Yemeni American Merchants Association Action, two of 110 political nonprofits, community groups and political action committees backing Mamdani as he alleges "Islamophobia" against him. Recently, when critics questioned Mamdani‚Äôs ties to hardline Brooklyn Imam Siraj Wahhaj, she sprang to action, helping to organize a protest to defend Wahhaj. That rapid, coordinated response captured the modus operandi of a network of political operatives and clerics intertwined with the shared mission of catapulting Mamdani into the mayor‚Äôs office. Mamdani‚Äôs background diverges from many of his co-religionists. In an interview, he said he is a Khoja Shia Muslim, part of a small, relatively liberal sect with roots in India. Many of his New York-area allies are religiously strict Sunni Muslims who practice more conservative interpretations of the faith. But they find common ground in politics. "It‚Äôs a sophisticated fusion of religion, politics and identity," said Mansour Al-Hadj, a Washington-based researcher on Muslim political movements and extremism. "The same networks that once focused on community services are now mobilizing voters and producing candidates. This is how political Islam adapts inside democracy." Mansour Al-Hadj, a Washington, D.C.,-based researcher on Muslim political movements and extremism, warns of radical forces backing Zohran Mamdani's bid to be mayor of New York City. (Mansour Al-Hadj) Mamdani‚Äôs God Squad includes about a few dozen key players who specialize in painting any critique as an attack on their faith, accusing critics of Islamophobia even as many of them have engaged in strident rhetoric against the U.S., Israel and capitalism. The Original Imam: America is "filthy and sick" Mamdani set off a firestorm Oct. 7 when he walked into Masjid At-Taqwa in Brooklyn and later posted a photo of himself beaming beside the mosque‚Äôs imam, or prayer leader, Wahhaj. Zohran Mamdani meets Imam Siraj Wahhaj and Yusef Abdus Salaam Oct. 17, 2025. (@ZohranKMamdani/X) The imam‚Äôs checkered past goes back decades. In a 1992 talk, he said American Muslims should elect an "emir" rather than choose between George Bush and Bill Clinton. Soon after, he served as a character witness in the trial of Sheikh Omar Abdel-Rahman, the so-called "Blind Sheikh" convicted for plotting the 1993 World Trade Center bombing that killed six people. "You know what this country is?" Wahhaj said in 1995. "It‚Äôs a garbage can. Filthy. Filthy and sick." In 2018, three of Wahhaj's children were arrested after authorities found 11 malnourished children in a New Mexico compound tied to his family; a grandchild had died in what authorities described as an attempted exorcism. He told local news reporters, "Whatever they did wrong ‚Ä¶ it's not acceptable to us." The Youth Imam: Resist "by any means necessary" In New York, the Muslim American Society recently signed on to a letter to challenge "unmistakably Islamophobic, anti-Black, and xenophobic" attacks on Mamdani. Signatories included CAIR National, the Council on American-Islamic Relations‚Äô New York chapter, Islamic Circle of North America‚Äôs New York chapter, the Islamic Center of Five Towns, Muslim American Society of New York, Muslim Community Network, Rockaway Islamic Center and a "Syosset Muslim Community." Members of the Muslim American Society have long been quick to accuse others of Islamophobia even as they unabashedly call for violence against their perceived enemies. At an Eid celebration earlier this year, a cleric at the Muslim American Society cast Muslims as victims worldwide. Mohammad Badawi, youth director at the Muslim American Society, declared the local community‚Äôs joy would only be complete when Muslims are "victorious worldwide," adding they would celebrate "after the destruction of the illegitimate Zionist occupiers," Israel. He regularly organizes anti-Israel protests in a campaign against "injustice and oppression." At one protest, Badawi urged youth to "fight back" against injustices "by any means necessary." Abdullah Akl, a charismatic organizer with the Muslim American Society Youth Center, leads many protests under the banner of "Within Our Lifetime," with founder Nerdeen Kiswani. Mamdani joined them before his run for mayor. Akl calls the street protests "sacred activism," a mix of faith and resistance that will "free Palestine." Since the Oct. 7, 2023, Hamas attack on Israel, the Muslim American Society Youth Center has organized prayer protests on Wall Street outside the New York Stock Exchange and street protests for "Nakba Day," calling the day Israel was created a "catastrophe," and youth-led demonstrations outside BlackRock. Akl turned a subway car into a protest zone with chants of "Globalize the intifada‚Ä¶ There is only one solution: intifada revolution." When the New York Police Department arrested Akl and other activists, the Council on American-Islamic Relation‚Äôs New York chapter sent out a press release demanding their release. During the Oct. 7 protests this year against Israel, Akl shouted, "We did not act enough! We will show up, stronger than we did the first Oct. 7." In response to criticism, he posted a message on social media, doubling down and saying, "Saying we didn‚Äôt act enough to stop a full blown genocide against palestinians [sic] is incitement?? Saying we need to be louder and protest more and continue to speak up for gaza [sic] is a crime? Zionist tears once again for the most documented genocide in modern history." For decades, Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR) has served as an aggressive and litigious watchdog for a host of Muslim figures and causes, often at the forefront of fighting legitimate bigotry. But CAIR has also courted controversy. Federal prosecutors named CAIR an unindicted co-conspirator in a federal terrorism-financing case against the Holy Land Foundation, a nonprofit based in Texas. In 2008, five Holy Land leaders were convicted of funneling $12.4 million to Hamas. Ultimately, no CAIR officials were charged in the case. Years ago, Mamdani recorded rap lyrics celebrating the "Holy Land Five," urging listeners, "My love to the Holy Land Five. You better look ‚Äòem up." Basim Elkarra, executive director of the Council on American-Islamic Relations California chapter and one of the founders of a new 501(c)(4) nonprofit, CAIR Action Inc., now seems to be pursuing a new and entirely legal means of financing causes, taking a page from the powerful pro-Israel political action committee AIPAC. He told a meeting of the Islamic Circle of North America, "AIPAC has had the run for 60 years, but it is over now. "We will teach these folks a lesson ‚Ä¶ we are coming." In another speech, he said, "The game has changed. AIPAC has been around since 1961‚Ä¶and now they have a formidable foe!" This summer, Mehdi Hasan, a former host at Qatar‚Äôs Al Jazeera TV network, sat down with Mamdani for a sympathetic interview. As the campaign heated up, Hasan became a full-time defender on social media, swatting at critics and framing Mamdani as the right kind of provocateur, a "once in a generation political talent." Mehdi Hasan speaks onstage during the Crooked Media ‚Äî Lovett or Leave It: Live on Tour, April 25, 2024, in Washington, D.C. (Paul Morigi/Getty Images for Crooked Media) Hasan‚Äôs own record includes sermons likening non-Muslims to "animals" and comparing gay people to "sexual deviants." He has said his views have become more progressive since then. After a series of plane crashes earlier this year, Hasan wrote on social media, "Make American Planes Crash Again." He deleted the message amid criticism and said, "I deleted this sarcastic quote-tweet because MAGA and Islamophobic folks are clipping it out of context and trying to ridiculously suggest I‚Äôm inciting violence. I was obviously mocking the MAGA slogan ‚ÄòMake America‚Ä¶ Again‚Äô slogan and highlighting the shocking number of plane crashes under Trump and the FAA cuts. But this tweet was in poor taste, poorly worded, and has allowed people in bad faith to call me a terrorist‚Ä¶" Yasir Qadhi, a high-profile American imam and founder of the AlMaghrib Institute and MuslimMatters.com, selling the puritanical Salafi interpretation of Islam, literally wrote the book on "Understanding Salafism." Recently, he posted a two-part thread on X endorsing the idea of Mamdani‚Äôs win as a "civilizational victory." Yasir Qadhi, a high-profile American imam and founder of the AlMaghrib Institute and MuslimMatters.com, has encouraged support for Mamdani for his "courageous stand against Zionism," among other things. (Getty Images) He urged Muslim Americans to move beyond "naive" religious critiques of politicians who are more socially progressive than they are comfortable. Meanwhile, Qadhi once mocked European Jews as "white, crooked nose, blonde hairs" and "not a Semitic people." In the same lecture, he recommended a book, "The Hoax of the Holocaust." Most recently, he has backed the controversial Muslim housing development outside Dallas, "EPIC City." He noted in his Instagram post, "open to non-Americans as well." He touted some of its features, writing, "Islamic schools, college, masjid." Imam Khalid Latif is a popular chaplain at the Islamic Center of New York City, a $22 million project to build a hub and "our own space" on Sixth Avenue for young Muslim professionals. He endorsed Mamdani earlier this year and has been an ardent supporter. He has called him "a bearer of compassion in a time where it is far too rare." Imam Khalid Latif, shown here speaking at Lincoln Center in 2022, is the chaplain at the Islamic Center of New York City. He endorsed Mamdani earlier this year. (Alexi Rosenfeld/Getty Images) In 2012, Latif led a pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia that included Omar Mateen, who would later murder 49 people at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, the deadliest anti-LGBTQ attack in U.S. history. He has denied radicalizing Mateen, and he hasn‚Äôt faced the same type of allegations that surround other imams. After the backlash to Mamdani‚Äôs meeting with Wahhaj, he posted, "Happy birthday to my brother Zohran‚Ä¶ Keep showing them who we are by showing them who you are." He invoked the divine to bless Mamdani‚Äôs mission, revealing the fusion of religion and politics for the Mamdani God Squad: "May your 34th year be one of clarity, courage, and closeness ‚Äî to your purpose, your people, and your Creator," ending with the Arabic word for amen, "Ameen." On Monday, Latif posted a sassy video from the Muslim Democratic Club of New York, saying, "The name is Mamdani, M-a-m-d-a-n-i," with Latif mouthing the part where the narration turns to, "You should learn how to say it." That day, Latif delivered a speech to support Mamdani, pivoting to allege Mamdani was now a victim of "anti-Black racism," saying, "Anti-Muslim sentiment is always" a symbol of "anti-Black racism." In a glowing portrait, The New York Times called Palestinian American political organizer Linda Sarsour a "Brooklyn home girl in a hijab." Over almost a decade, she has been a political mentor to Mamdani, inviting him into the Muslim Democratic Club of New York, which she co-founded. She later endorsed his race for the New York General Assembly, which he won. Activist Linda Sarsour speaks earlier this year at the Lights for Liberty vigil held in protest of the Trump administration's ICE actions. (Erik McGregor/LightRocket via Getty Images) All the while, she has been a polarizing figure, once saying about two critics, author and ex-Muslim Ayaan Hirsi Ali and activist Brigitte Gabriel, "I wish I could take their vagina away - they don‚Äôt deserve to be women." Ali is a survivor of female genital mutilation, a practice that involves cutting the clitoris of a young girl with the idea that it will inhibit sexual promiscuity. As a co-founder of the Women‚Äôs March, Sarsour stepped down amid criticism of alleged antisemitism and not welcoming Jewish feminists who support the state of Israel, or "Zionists." At a rally on Sunday night with Sen. Bernie Sanders and Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Imam Latif told 13,000 people, "This is our city. This is our moment." Some Muslims beg to differ. "It‚Äôs not our moment," said Al-Hadj. "Across the boroughs, the Mamdani God Squad is banging a drumbeat of grievance after grievance, from Staten Island to Brooklyn, Manhattan, Queens and Long Island," he said. "Across the city‚Äôs Muslim institutions, you hear the same drumbeat: They smeared us. They silenced us. They fear us. "In that rising volume, something is lost: Muslim pluralism. The God Squad does not speak for every Muslim in New York ‚Äî nor for every Shia, every Sunni, every immigrant family, or every second-generation kid trying to thread faith and freedom. It speaks for a coalition committed to illiberal ends, with socialist capture of city politics on the one hand and puritanical religious rhetoric on the other. They insist that to oppose them is to betray the community, so they actually push their own tyranny." Win or lose next week, Al-Hadj said, the Mamdani God Squad had actualized the words that had gotten Almontaser into so much trouble years ago: "Intifada NYC." Asra Q. Nomani is the author of "Woke Army: The Left-Green Alliance That Is Undermining America‚Äôs Freedom," and the founder of the Pearl Project, a nonprofit journalism initiative. Title: ‡≤Ö‡≤Ç‡≤§‡≤æ‡≤∞‡≤æ‡≤∑‡≥ç‡≤ü‡≥ç‡≤∞‡≥Ä‡≤Ø ‡≤¨‡≥ç‡≤Ø‡≤æ‡≤Ç‡≤ï‡≥ç‚Äå‡≤ó‡≤≥‡≤ø‡≤ó‡≥Ü 4400 ‡≤ï‡≥ã‡≤ü‡≤ø ‡≤µ‡≤Ç‡≤ö‡≤®‡≥Ü ‡≤Æ‡≤æ‡≤°‡≤ø‡≤¶ ‡≤≠‡≤æ‡≤∞‡≤§‡≥Ä‡≤Ø ‡≤Æ‡≥Ç‡≤≤‡≤¶ ‡≤â‡≤¶‡≥ç‡≤Ø‡≤Æ‡≤ø, ‡≤Ø‡≤æ‡≤∞‡≥Ä‡≤§ ‡≤¨‡≤Ç‡≤ï‡≤ø‡≤Æ‡≥ç‚Äå ‡≤¨‡≥ç‡≤∞‡≤π‡≥ç‡≤Æ‡≤≠‡≤ü‡≥ç‚Äå?

Time Published: 2025-11-01T17:15:47Z
Full Content:
‡≤®‡≤µ‡≤¶‡≥Ü‡≤π‡≤≤‡≤ø (‡≤®.1): ‡≤Ö‡≤Æ‡≥Ü‡≤∞‡≤ø‡≤ï‡≤¶ ‡≤ï‡≤Ç‡≤™‡≤®‡≤ø ‡≤¨‡≥ç‡≤≤‡≥ç‡≤Ø‡≤æ‡≤ï‡≥ç‚Äå‡≤∞‡≤æ‡≤ï‡≥ç‚Äå‡≤® ‡≤ñ‡≤æ‡≤∏‡≤ó‡≤ø ‡≤ï‡≥ç‡≤∞‡≥Ü‡≤°‡≤ø‡≤ü‡≥ç ‡≤ò‡≤ü‡≤ï‡≤µ‡≤æ‡≤¶ ‡≤é‡≤∏‡≤ó‡≤ø‡≤¶‡≥ç‡≤¶‡≤æ‡≤∞‡≥Ü ‡≤é‡≤Ç‡≤¶‡≥Å ‡≤Ü‡≤∞‡≥ã‡≤™‡≤ø‡≤∏‡≤≤‡≤æ‡≤ó‡≤ø‡≤¶‡≥Ü. ‡≤µ‡≤æ‡≤≤‡≥ç ‡≤∏‡≥ç‡≤ü‡≥ç‡≤∞‡≥Ä‡≤ü‡≥ç ‡≤ú‡≤∞‡≥ç‡≤®‡≤≤‡≥ç‚Äå‡≤® ‡≤µ‡≤∞‡≤¶‡≤ø‡≤Ø ‡≤™‡≥ç‡≤∞‡≤ï‡≤æ‡≤∞, ‡≤¨‡≤Ç‡≤ï‡≤ø‡≤Æ‡≥ç $385 ‡≤Æ‡≤ø‡≤≤‡≤ø‡≤Ø‡≤®‡≥ç (‡≤∞‡≥Ç.3,418 ‡≤ï‡≥ã‡≤ü‡≤ø) ‡≤∞‡≤ø‡≤Ç‡≤¶ $430 ‡≤Æ‡≤ø‡≤≤‡≤ø‡≤Ø‡≤®‡≥ç (‡≤∞‡≥Ç.3,817 ‡≤ï‡≥ã‡≤ü‡≤ø) ‡≤ó‡≥Ü ‡≤è‡≤∞‡≤ø‡≤ï‡≥Ü‡≤Ø‡≤æ‡≤ó‡≤ø‡≤¶‡≥Ü. BNP ‡≤™‡≤∞‡≤ø‡≤¨‡≤æ‡≤∏‡≥ç ‡≤®‡≤ø‡≤¨‡≤Ç‡≤ß‡≤®‡≥Ü‡≤ó‡≤≥‡≤≤‡≥ç‡≤≤‡≤ø $220 ‡≤Æ‡≤ø‡≤≤‡≤ø‡≤Ø‡≤®‡≥ç (‡≤∞‡≥Ç.1,953 ‡≤ï‡≥ã‡≤ü‡≤ø) ‡≤Æ‡≥Ä‡≤∏‡≤≤‡≤ø‡≤ü‡≥ç‡≤ü‡≤ø‡≤¶‡≥Ü. ‡≤¨‡≥ç‡≤∞‡≤π‡≥ç‡≤Æ‡≤≠‡≤ü‡≥ç ‡≤Ö‡≤µ‡≤∞ Title: U.S. Health Insurers Face Headwinds as Q3 Earnings Reveal Mounting Cost Pressures
URL: https://www.edgen.tech/news/stock/us-health-insurers-face-headwinds-as-q3-earnings-reveal-mounting-cost-pressures
Time Published: 2025-11-01T09:01:14Z
Full Content:
U.S. health insurers experienced a challenging third quarter, reporting increased medical costs and significant policy-related pressures, which led to a notable decline in share prices across the sector. U.S. health insurance companies encountered substantial financial headwinds in the third quarter, reporting results marked by escalating medical costs and the looming impact of legislative changes. The sector's performance lagged the broader market, with several major players experiencing significant stock price depreciation. The third-quarter earnings season, which commenced on October 21, unveiled a consistent theme of increased cost pressures across the health insurance industry. A primary driver of these rising expenses has been the government-subsidized Medicaid and Medicare Advantage plans, where UnitedHealth Group Inc. (UNH), the nation's largest insurer, specifically highlighted heightened acuity levels among its Medicaid enrollees following the resumption of state-led procedural disenrollment in March 2023. Centene Corporation (NYSE: CNC) reported a substantial $6.6 billion third-quarter loss, a stark contrast to its $713 million profit in the same period last year. This loss was largely attributed to escalating healthcare costs and a $6.7 billion non-cash goodwill impairment. The impairment was a consequence of a sustained decline in Centene's stock price throughout 2025 and the anticipated financial repercussions of the "One Big Beautiful Bill," which forecasts $1 trillion in cuts to Medicaid and Affordable Care Act (ACA) subsidies over the next decade. Centene's health benefits ratio (HBR), the proportion of premiums spent on medical care, climbed to 92.7%, up from 89.2% a year prior, underscoring the rising cost burden. Market reactions to these results were swift and negative. Since October 20, Elevance Health Inc. (ELV) shares fell 9.1%, UnitedHealth Group Inc. (UNH) declined 5.4%, and The Cigna Group (CI) dropped 19.5%. The most pronounced decrease among major managed care insurers was recorded by Molina Healthcare, Inc. (MOH), which saw its stock price decrease by 23.5%. These declines surpassed those of the broader market, with the S&P 500 falling 2.47% and the S&P Insurance Index decreasing 2.15% over the same period. The adverse market reaction reflects investor concerns over several interconnected factors. Primarily, the rising medical expense ratios indicate a squeeze on profitability, particularly as insurers grapple with sicker patient populations in government-funded programs. The "One Big Beautiful Bill" has introduced significant political uncertainty and financial risk, with projections suggesting it could eliminate health coverage for nearly 12 million Americans. This directly impacts insurers like Centene, which manage Medicaid plans for over 12 million low-income individuals. Furthermore, issues are not confined solely to Medicaid. UnitedHealth also noted the expected impact of changes within the ACA markets. The company anticipates that rate increases exceeding 25% and targeted service area reductions could lead to a decrease of approximately two-thirds in its Obamacare customer base, potentially forcing over one million enrollees to seek alternative coverage. These aggressive actions, while aimed at improving margins in the employer and individual segment by 2026, suggest ongoing struggles to achieve targeted profitability levels. The sector's performance in the third quarter highlights a challenging operating environment exacerbated by both fundamental cost pressures and a shifting regulatory landscape. The substantial goodwill impairment reported by Centene underscores the market's re-evaluation of long-term prospects in light of evolving healthcare policy. The company's valuation review specifically cited the expected financial impact of the "One Big Beautiful Bill" as a key factor. The broader market implications are significant. As insurers face increased costs and legislative changes that could reduce their customer base and subsidies, the sustainability of current business models, particularly within government-sponsored programs, comes into question. The aggressive rate hikes by UnitedHealthcare in the ACA marketplace indicate an industry-wide effort to adapt to these new realities, potentially at the expense of market share. While specific analyst quotes were not provided in the briefing, the collective sentiment from company executives and market movements suggests a cautious outlook. UnitedHealthcare chief executive Tim Noel indicated that the company's submitted rate filings reflect the 2025 morbidity and experience, including average rate increases of over 25%, as a necessary measure to improve margins. The acknowledgment that these margins are still projected to remain below the targeted 7‚Äì9% range for 2026 further underscores the persistent challenges. Investors will closely monitor several key factors in the coming quarters. The full implementation and impact of the "One Big Beautiful Bill" and its projected cuts to Medicaid and ACA subsidies will be a critical determinant for sector profitability. The ability of insurers to manage medical costs effectively, particularly within Medicaid and Medicare Advantage, will remain paramount. Furthermore, the strategies employed by major players like UnitedHealthcare to navigate the ACA landscape, including the potential for significant enrollee shifts, will provide insights into the sector's adaptability. The interplay of legislative policy, evolving patient demographics, and cost containment efforts will define the trajectory for U.S. health insurers in the near to medium term. ## Market Snapshot: Geopolitical Tensions and Corporate Catalysts Drive Divergent Performances U.S. equities experienced a mixed trading session, characterized by significant movements in specific sectors driven by renewed geopolitical concerns, strategic corporate developments, and varied earnings performances. ## The Event in Detail ### Rare Earths and Trade Tensions Reshape Valuations **MP Materials (MP)** shares advanced 13% after former President Trump's comments on China's dominance in rare earth minerals reignited discussions about U.S. industrial policy and critical mineral supply chains. This follows earlier speculation where **MP** saw a 431% gain year-to-date, partly due to a Defense Department deal. In contrast, the "Magnificent Seven" technology stocks collectively experienced declines, with each falling more than 1%. This downturn was largely attributed to President Trump's renewed threats of tariffs against China, sparking fears of a revived trade war. **Tesla (TSLA)** shares notably slumped 7%, leading losses among the group, while **Apple (AAPL)**, **Alphabet (GOOGL)**, and **Microsoft (MSFT)** also saw declines, with **Apple** falling 4.8%. Analyst Dan Ives of Wedbush cut price targets for **Tesla** to $315 from $550 and **Apple** by $75 to $250, describing tariffs as a "complete disaster" for the tech giant, potentially necessitating price increases for U.S. iPhones. Chinese technology stocks also felt the impact of tariff threats, with **Alibaba (BABA)** and **Baidu (BIDU)** shares each falling more than 6%. Other key Chinese stocks traded in the U.S., such as **PDD (PDD)**, **JD.com (JD)**, **NetEase (NTES)**, **Tencent Music Entertainment (TME)**, and **XPeng (XPEV)**, also saw declines. ### Corporate Developments Spur Individual Stock Movements **Rocket Lab (RKLB)** stock rose 5% following the announcement of a direct contract for two dedicated Electron launches with the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (**JAXA**). These missions, scheduled for December 2025 and 2026, will deploy various satellites for JAXA's Innovative Satellite Technology Demonstration Program, reinforcing **Rocket Lab**'s position as a key launch provider in the Japanese space industry. **Protagonist Therapeutics (PTGX)** shares rallied 34% amidst reports of advanced acquisition talks with **Johnson & Johnson (JNJ)**. The potential deal, valued at up to $3.3 billion, aims to bolster **J&J**'s autoimmune disease pipeline with assets like icotrokinra and rusfertide. **J&J**, which already holds approximately 4% of **Protagonist**'s shares and exclusive rights to commercialize icotrokinra, views the acquisition as strategic for long-term growth. **Applied Digital (APLD)** shares surged 19% after the company reported an 84% increase in fiscal first-quarter revenue, reaching $64.2 million. The revenue growth was primarily driven by tenant fit-out services for its HPC Hosting Business and performance improvements in its Data Center Business. Despite an increase in net loss, the company's first 100 MW facility at Polaris Forge 1 remains on track for Q4 2025 operation. **Doximity (DOCS)** shares tumbled 7% after JPMorgan downgraded the stock to "Underweight" from "Neutral," citing valuation concerns and uncertainties regarding digital pharma advertising trends. Despite strong business fundamentals, including reaching over 80% of U.S. physicians, the stock's trading at 36x forward EV/EBITDA, significantly above the 23x median for comparable companies, prompted the downgrade. **Mosaic (MOS)** stock dropped more than 9% following the fertilizer producer's report of disappointing preliminary third-quarter volumes, particularly in its phosphate segment. Unexpected mechanical issues and utility interruptions at key facilities led to production shortfalls. **Levi Strauss (LEVI)** shares fell more than 11% after the company issued weaker-than-expected earnings guidance for the fourth quarter. Despite beating revenue expectations for the prior quarter, the company projected a 1% to 2% decline in FY25 revenue and adjusted earnings below analyst estimates, attributing the cautious outlook to "complex macros" including tariffs and potential impacts on consumer demand. ## Analysis of Market Reaction The market's reaction underscored a bifurcated landscape. Geopolitical rhetoric heavily influenced sectors tied to international trade and critical resources, creating both opportunities for domestic producers like **MP Materials** and significant headwinds for global technology players and Chinese-linked companies. The renewed tariff threats highlighted the sensitivity of multinational corporations to trade policy shifts, leading to substantial repricing of major tech firms. Meanwhile, sector-specific catalysts like M&A speculation (e.g., **Protagonist Therapeutics**) and strong revenue growth (e.g., **Applied Digital**) continued to drive idiosyncratic gains, while revised guidance and valuation concerns (e.g., **Doximity**, **Mosaic**, **Levi Strauss**) exerted downward pressure on individual equities. ## Broader Context & Implications The current environment reflects a persistent sensitivity to U.S.-China relations, a theme that has historically injected volatility into global markets. The declines in the "Magnificent Seven" stocks, collectively shedding over $2 trillion in market value since their late 2024 peak, illustrate the significant impact of trade tensions on highly capitalized tech firms. **Apple's** 9.25% fall represented the sharpest decline among the group, indicating the direct and substantial exposure of companies with extensive supply chains in China. Conversely, the rise in **MP Materials** underscores the strategic importance and investment appeal of critical mineral independence amidst escalating geopolitical competition. ## Expert Commentary Dan Ives of Wedbush articulated the gravity of the trade situation, stating that tariffs represent a "**complete disaster**" for tech giants like **Apple**, which may need to "raise U.S. iPhone prices to protect its lofty margins." Sir Peter Beck, CEO of **Rocket Lab**, emphasized the global significance of their launch capabilities, noting the **JAXA** contract as a demonstration of "Electron's global importance ‚Äì supporting the growth of Japan's space industry with launch on a U.S. rocket from a New Zealand launch site." ## Looking Ahead Investors will closely monitor developments in U.S.-China trade relations, as further tariff announcements or escalations could continue to impact technology and import-reliant sectors. Upcoming economic data releases and corporate earnings reports will also provide further clarity on consumer demand and operational resilience in a challenging macro environment. The biopharmaceutical sector may see continued M&A activity as larger players seek to bolster pipelines, offering potential upside for clinical-stage companies. ## Market Overview U.S. equities experienced notable upward movements during midday trading, with several companies reporting substantial gains driven by a combination of strong financial results, strategic corporate restructuring, and geopolitical developments. Investor sentiment was generally bullish, particularly towards companies demonstrating solid operational performance and clear growth strategies. ## The Event in Detail **Nova Minerals (NVA)**, a materials exploration company, saw its stock price surge by over 100% on Tuesday, October 14, 2025, reaching as high as **$69.67** for its American Depositary Receipts (ADR), representing a 103.9% increase. This significant advance followed the announcement that the Australian Ambassador to the United States initiated a briefing on Nova Minerals' **Estelle Gold and Critical Minerals Project** in Alaska. This briefing precedes a high-level meeting between Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and U.S. President Donald Trump on October 20, 2025, where critical minerals cooperation is a primary agenda item. The **Estelle Project**, encompassing 514 km¬≤ within Alaska‚Äôs Tintina Gold Belt, contains multi-million-ounce gold resources and several antimony prospects. Notably, Nova Minerals' subsidiary, Alaska Range Resources LLC, secured a **US$43.4 million award** from the U.S. Department of War to establish a domestic antimony supply chain by 2026‚Äì27, reducing reliance on foreign sources. **Ericsson (ERIC)**, the Swedish telecommunications and software services provider, experienced a nearly 20% rally in its U.S.-listed shares on Tuesday. This movement was prompted by the company's third-quarter earnings report, which significantly exceeded analyst expectations. Ericsson reported net profits of **11.15 billion Swedish krona**, outperforming analyst estimates by 11% according to FactSet data. CEO Borje Ekholm further bolstered investor confidence by suggesting there could be "scope for increased shareholder distributions," implying potential for higher dividends or share buybacks. **Wells Fargo & Company (WFC)** shares advanced 6.8% after the banking giant released its third-quarter 2025 financial results. The company reported adjusted earnings per share of **$1.73**, surpassing the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1.55. Total revenues reached **$21.44 billion**, exceeding the $21.19 billion consensus and marking a 5.2% increase from the prior-year quarter. Key drivers included a 2.2% year-over-year rise in net interest income (NII) to **$11.95 billion** and a 9.3% increase in non-interest income. The bank also benefited from lower provisions for credit losses, which decreased by 36% to **$681 million**, alongside higher loan balances and improved deposits. Following these robust results, Wells Fargo also raised its profitability target. **Polaris Inc. (PII)**, the American power-sports vehicle manufacturer, saw its stock rise by more than 11% on Tuesday. The surge followed the announcement of its plan to spin off its **Indian Motorcycle** division. As part of the deal, private-equity firm Carolwood will acquire a majority stake in Indian Motorcycle, with the transaction expected to finalize in the first quarter of 2026. Polaris projects this strategic move to improve its annual earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) by **$50 million**. The Indian Motorcycle division contributed approximately **$478 million** in revenue, representing roughly 7% of Polaris's total sales for the twelve months ended June 30, 2025. **Albertsons Companies, Inc. (ACI)** shares jumped more than 11% after the grocery retailer reported strong fiscal second-quarter 2025 results, which concluded on September 6, 2025. The company reported identical sales growth of 2.2% and a significant 23% increase in digital sales. Adjusted net income reached **$248 million**, or **$0.44 per share**. Net sales and other revenue grew 2.0% to **$18,915.8 million**. Albertsons also updated its fiscal 2025 outlook, projecting identical sales growth between 2.2% and 2.75% and adjusted EBITDA in the range of **$3.8 billion to $3.9 billion**. Furthermore, the company announced a **$750 million accelerated share repurchase agreement** and increased its total share repurchase program authorization from $2.0 billion to **$2.75 billion**. ## Analysis of Market Reaction The market ## Market Snapshot: Earnings Volatility and Geopolitical Tensions U.S. equities are navigating a landscape shaped by significant corporate earnings reports and evolving geopolitical factors in the energy sector. Investors are closely monitoring performance shifts within major technology players and airlines, alongside the immediate impacts of international sanctions on commodity markets and domestic labor relations. ## Corporate Earnings and Sector Performance **Tesla (TSLA)** experienced a notable decline in its stock following the release of its third-quarter 2025 earnings report. While the electric vehicle manufacturer surpassed revenue expectations, reporting **$28.095 billion** against an anticipated **$26.27 billion**, it fell short on earnings per share (EPS), delivering **$0.50** compared to an expected **$0.52**. This mixed performance led to an immediate market reaction, with **TSLA** shares dropping to **$433.50** in after-hours trading from a close of **$438.97**. The company's Q3 2025 margin was reported at **5.8 percent**. This recent performance contrasts with earlier periods where the stock rallied despite soft earnings, often on the back of bullish commentary from CEO Elon Musk regarding initiatives like the "robotaxi" and plans for less expensive vehicles and a "Cybercab" in 2025. Tesla's full-year net income for 2024 saw a significant decrease, down **23%** from 2023 and **40%** from 2022's record **$14.1 billion** profit, though full-year revenue improved by **1%** to **$97.7 billion**. **Southwest Airlines (LUV)** delivered a surprising beat on its third-quarter 2025 EPS, reporting **$0.11** against a forecasted loss of **$0.04**, representing a **-375%** surprise. However, the airline's revenue slightly missed expectations, coming in at **$6.9 billion** versus a forecast of **$6.92 billion**, a **-0.29%** surprise. Despite the strong EPS, the stock experienced an **8.74%** drop in after-hours trading, closing at **$31.65** and continuing its decline to **$30.51** in subsequent sessions, underscoring investor sensitivity to broader financial health beyond singular metrics. ## Strategic Restructuring and Labor Dynamics **Meta Platforms (META)** announced a significant restructuring within its artificial intelligence operations, placing approximately **600 employees** from its Superintelligence Labs division on a non-working notice period. This move, intended to streamline AI efforts and reduce organizational complexity, affects primarily legacy AI infrastructure teams, the Fundamental Artificial Intelligence Research (FAIR) unit, and certain product-focused roles. Following the announcement, Meta's stock initially saw a **1% to 2%** dip but quickly recovered, as market analysts interpreted the layoffs as a strategic efficiency measure rather than a retreat from AI development. Institutional investors view these actions as cost control initiatives that could enhance operating margins and cash flow. This market reaction aligns with a broader tech sector trend where initial concerns over job cuts give way to a focus on long-term profitability and innovation. Meta continues to emphasize its commitment to integrating human expertise with machine learning and expanding its hiring of "industry-leading AI-native talent." Meanwhile, **Starbucks (SBUX)** is facing potential labor disruptions as its **Workers United union** initiated a strike authorization vote on October 24, 2025. The union's demands include higher take-home pay, improved hours, and resolution of legal issues ahead of the critical holiday season. This action introduces significant risk to Starbucks' near-term performance, especially given the company's ongoing efforts to address declining comparable sales and operational challenges. A prolonged strike could heavily impact Starbucks' high labor cost structure and turnaround plans. Despite these challenges, Starbucks projects **$45.5 billion** in revenue and **$4.6 billion** in earnings by 2028, requiring **7.5%** yearly revenue growth. ## Geopolitical Impact on Commodity Markets Global oil markets experienced a significant surge in prices following new **U.S. sanctions** imposed on major Russian crude oil companies, **Rosneft** and **Lukoil**, on October 23, 2025. The sanctions, enacted in response to Russia's role in the conflict in Ukraine, led to Brent crude futures rising **5%** and West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures climbing more than **5.2%**. Russian oil and gas revenues, which constitute approximately one-fourth of Russia's budget and are a crucial source of funding for the war, have already seen a **21% year-over-year** decline. The sanctions have prompted major purchasers in China, India, and Turkey to distance themselves from Russian crude, resulting in a substantial decline in seaborne exports. Refiners are exhibiting increased caution, leading to a rise in oil volumes idling at sea. According to Bloomberg data, the four-week average gross value of Russian exports decreased by approximately **$90 million** to **$1.36 billion weekly** by November 2. Seaborne crude exports from Russian ports averaged **3.58 million barrels per day** until November 2, a reduction of approximately **190,000 barrels per day** from the previous period. Major government-controlled entities like **Sinopec** and **PetroChina Co.** have withdrawn from some Russian cargo agreements. Rystad Energy AS estimates that this cautious approach could affect up to **45%** of China's total seaborne crude imports from Russia, equating to roughly **400,000 barrels daily**.

Title: Wall Street Week Ahead: Resilient stocks rally faces earnings wave after AI, Fed wobbles
URL: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/markets/stocks/news/wall-st-week-ahead-resilient-stocks-rally-faces-earnings-wave-after-ai-fed-wobbles/articleshow/125009503.cms

Full Content:

The market is at high valuations, making earnings crucial for future gains. The first week of November is historically positive for stocks. AI investments are a key theme, with companies announcing spending and investors seeking returns. Title: The AI-Driven Stock Runup May Not Be As Good As Many Assume
URL: https://www.forbes.com/sites/eriksherman/2025/10/31/the-ai-driven-stock-runup-may-not-be-as-good-as-many-assume/
Time Published: 2025-11-01T03:37:06Z
Full Content:
ByErik Sherman, Senior Contributor. The witching hour. Is this about All Hallow‚Äôs Eve? No, it‚Äôs about tech companies ‚Äî AI-focused in particular. Promise, hype, and intra-sector cross-investment has created an interesting dynamic of economic concentration and risk. By no means is this to say that tech companies and their stocks are bad. It also isn‚Äôt to say they will be good at all times and past performance is a guarantee of future returns. Technology stocks have shown strong returns, as they have in 2023 and 2024, according to U.S. Bank. The information technology sector gained 23% year-to-date on October 21, 2025. The tech-focused communication services sector gained 25%. In contrast, the S&P 500 increased by 15% and the return for the Nasdaq composite was 19%. More specifically, the so-called Magnificent Seven ‚Äî Apple, Amazon, Alphabet, Meta Platforms, Microsoft, Nvidia, and Tesla ‚Äî comprise 36.6% of the S&P 500 as of October 2025, up from 12.3% in 2015, according to The Motley Fool. In year-to-date performance, the Magnificent Seven had returns of 18.6% compared to 14.5% of the S&P 500. A big reason is due to artificial intelligence growth. Stanford University‚Äôs Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence group calculated that corporate AI investment reached $252.3 billion in 2024. Year-over-year private investment was up 44.5% and mergers and acquisitions, up 12.1%. The current AI and tech success, though, creates some structural issues. ‚ÄúThe S&P 500 is built on a ‚Äòsurvivor bias‚Äô basis, with companies having the most success making up the largest weightings,‚Äù Vince Stanzione, former currency trader and CEO of financial publisher First Information, says. The higher the market capitalization of the company, the higher its standing in the S&P 500. Stanzione compared two S&P 500-related exchange-traded funds: the Invesco S&P 500 Equal Weight EFT (RSP) and SPDR S&P 500 (SPY). ‚ÄúIf you compare the equal-weighted RSP to SPY, you will see the equal-weighted is doing poorly, only up around 8% [year-to-date] compared to 17%.‚Äù The reason SPY did better is that it includes larger shares of top technology stocks. ‚ÄúIt is somewhat worrying to have such high exposure in the S&P 500, and at some stage the sector will correct,‚Äù he adds. ‚ÄúFor my own trading and clients, we have also had large exposure to mining stocks ‚Äî which are hardly represented in the SPY ‚Äî and, even after the recent pullback, this is up 113% YTD and on a far lower [price-earnings ratio] multiple than tech stocks, so there are still opportunities in other sectors. But for those just passively tracking the S&P 500, they remain tech-heavy and will keep dancing until the music stops.‚Äù The market excitement over AI is fueled by investor belief on its future. But the concentration of tech acts in a way like leverage in investing. The expectations can pile on atop the other. An example The Motley Fool gave was Nvidia. Since the end of 2015, the company has added trillions to its market cap, moving from the smallest contributor to the Magnificent Seven to the largest. That was a jump from 0.8% of the combined value to the largest at 21.2%. If you have ever seen a juggler balancing a spinning plate on a pole, then you know the plates must keep rotating to maintain their stability. ‚ÄúThe current market continues to consolidate with outperformance limited to fewer and fewer stocks, mostly based on the promise of AI and, perhaps more compelling, spending on AI infrastructure,‚Äù says Geoff Strotman of investment consulting firm Segal Marco Advisors. ‚ÄúMany of these stocks happen to be the largest stocks in the US stock market (and the largest in history), which is quickly driving performance and valuations higher.‚Äù Strotman notes that while the S&P 500 is at ‚Äúhistorically high valuation,‚Äù there are many other areas of the global stock market ‚Äî US small caps and non-US stocks ‚Äî that remain at average valuations. That can mean good returns with lower investment amounts. He adds that emerging markets are having a strong year, up almost 30% year-to-date. ‚ÄúThe emerging markets outperformance is also a reminder for institutional investors to remain diversified and rebalance into underperforming asset classes in order to take advantage of return divergence and opportunities as Emerging Markets was just about left for dead at the beginning of the year,‚Äù Strotman says. However, concerns about risk from tech, or any other type of stock type, can create its own problems. ‚ÄúThe debate over whether AI is a 'boom' or a 'bubble' is interesting, but in reality, it‚Äôs a distraction to everyday investors focused on long-term wealth,‚Äù says Alex Michalka, head of investments at Weatlthfront. ‚ÄúNo one can know the answer for sure, and attempting to adjust your strategy based on a guess is a form of market timing, which historically is not a wise approach. Instead, you‚Äôre better off focusing on ensuring you have a well-diversified portfolio that includes the level of risk you‚Äôre comfortable with based on your situation and time horizon.‚Äù In other words, if technology is an area where you find heightened risk, you don‚Äôt need to run away from it. A diversified portfolio is an intelligent investment tool. Michalka mentioned direct indexing, in which you buy individual stocks to imitate an existing stock index like the S&P 500 or Nasdaq. You can look for areas of tech that gives some of the upside without being married to it.
--------------------------------------------------

Title: US stock market ends the October on a strong note ‚Äî How did the S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow perform? Here‚Äôs the top gainers and losers on Wall Street
URL: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/us/us-stock-market-ends-the-october-on-a-strong-note-how-did-the-sp-500-nasdaq-and-dow-perform-heres-the-top-gainers-and-losers-on-wall-street/articleshow/125008358.cms
Time Published: 2025-11-01T01:54:42Z
Full Content:
US stock market today surged as Amazon shares jumped 9.6% after reporting Q3 revenue of $180.2 billion and 20% growth at AWS. The Nasdaq rose 0.61% to 23,724.96, the S&P 500 climbed 0.26% to 6,840.20, and the Dow added 40.75 points to 47,562.87. AI-linked names rallied with Palantir up 3% and Oracle up 2.2%. Netflix gained 2.7% on a 10-for-1 stock split and Tesla advanced 3.7%. October ended with the S&P 500 up 2.3%, Nasdaq +4.7% and the Dow +2.5%. No material changes have been made to the investment objective, strategies, or management of these funds as a result. The changes in the risk ratings will be reflected in each fund‚Äôs offering documents, which will be completed in accordance with applicable securities laws. Title: Mind Affirm‚Äôs GAAP‚Ä¶ It Only Misleads
URL: https://www.forbes.com/sites/greatspeculations/2025/10/31/mind-affirms-gaap-it-only-misleads/
Time Published: 2025-10-31T16:13:15Z
Full Content:
ByDavid Trainer, Contributor. Many companies rely on misleading ‚Äúadjusted‚Äù metrics to trick investors into thinking their business is stronger than it is in reality. The law allows companies to invent entirely new metrics or manipulate others to support a narrative that paints a more positive picture of the firm‚Äôs fundamentals. These companies often include disclaimers that caution against using non-GAAP metrics. Yet, the Street often builds its narratives on these ‚Äúadjusted‚Äù metrics. ‚ÄúAdjusted‚Äù metrics are not the only problem. GAAP earnings are often misleading. Unusual, one-time gains or losses frequently distort reported GAAP results and cloud investors‚Äô ability to understand the true economic performance of companies. To uncover real, Core Earnings, investors must dig into the details buried in the footnotes. This week‚Äôs Danger Zone pick is a perfect example of just how misleading reported earnings can be. The company recently reported positive GAAP earnings for the first time since its IPO. Meanwhile, Core Earnings remain highly negative. Further analysis reveals the company is burning through cash at an alarming pace. Only by leveraging superior fundamental data can investors get the truth about this company‚Äôs profitability, or lack thereof. I first put Affirm Holdings (AFRM) in the Danger Zone in October 2021, reiterated my bearish opinion most recently in October 2024, and named it a Zombie Stock in September 2022. GAAP profits may have investors re-thinking this company, so I believe now is a great time to remind investors how GAAP net income is misleading and show how AFRM remains overvalued. Affirm continues to grow its top-line at impressive levels. In fiscal 4Q25, revenue and gross merchandise volume (GMV) grew 33% and 43% year-over-year (YoY), respectively. For the full year of fiscal 2025, Affirm grew revenue and GMV 39% and 38% YoY, respectively. The company also successfully onboarded new customers and merchants, with active consumers and active merchants rising 23% and 24% YoY respectively in fiscal 2025. Perhaps most noteworthy ‚Äì at least to investors that don‚Äôt look beyond the surface numbers ‚Äì Affirm generated positive GAAP net income in fiscal 2025, a first since fiscal 2019. While Affirm reports positive top-line growth and GAAP net income, a deeper analysis, one that accounts for the footnotes and MD&A of company filings, reveals a different picture. Beyond profitability, the company‚Äôs stock price remains overvalued, and after rising 83% last year and 25% YTD, it carries large downside risk. More on that later. Affirm has not reported positive operating profit in any fiscal year of my company model, which dates back to fiscal 2019. The company has not generated positive Core Earnings since fiscal 2019 either. This fact begs the question, how does Affirm report positive GAAP net income if reported operating profit and calculated Core Earnings are negative? The answer is non-operating income or income unrelated to its core business. In fiscal 2025, Affirm reported an operating loss of -$87 million. However, the company reported $149 million in ‚ÄúOther Income, net‚Äù on its income statement. This other income is interest earned on money market funds included in cash and cash equivalents and restricted cash and interest earned on securities available for sale, among other items. In other words, Affirm has a lot of cash and securities from all the stock it has sold, and that‚Äôs where it gets the income to generate positive GAAP net income, not from its core operation. I leverage my firm‚Äôs Robo-Analyst AI Agent to calculate Core Earnings, a proven superior earnings measure that excludes these unusual gains/losses. In doing so, I find that Affirm‚Äôs Core Earnings remain negative at -$78 million in Fiscal 2025. Figure 1 provides a reconciliation from GAAP Net Income to Core Earnings. Figure 1: Affirm‚Äôs GAAP Net Income to Core Earnings Reconciliation: Fiscal 2025 In Affirm‚Äôs quest to take market share, it has adopted a growth-at-all-costs approach, even going so far as stating ‚Äúgrowth is always the answer‚Äù in the company‚Äôs fiscal 4Q24 shareholder letter. Total operating expenses, which include loss on loan purchase commitment, provision for credit losses, funding costs, processing and servicing, technology and data analytics, sales and marketing, general and administrative, and restructuring and other were 103% of revenue in fiscal 2025, which further explains why, as noted above, reported operating income is negative. When I first named Affirm a Zombie Stock in September 2022 it had enough cash on hand to sustain its cash burn for another 10 months. Affirm slowed its FCF burn from -$814 million in fiscal 2024 to -$425 million in fiscal 2025. The lower, yet still negative, FCF means Affirm no longer qualifies as a Zombie Stock because it has enough cash on hand to sustain its fiscal 2025 FCF burn for 61 months from the end of September 2025. Despite positive GAAP net income, Affirm continues to burn through cash each year. Affirm‚Äôs free cash flow (FCF) has been negative on an annual basis in every year since fiscal 2019. On a quarterly basis, FCF has been negative in 14 of the 15 quarters over the same time. In fiscal 2025, the company burned -$425 million in FCF excluding acquisitions. From fiscal 2020 through fiscal 2025, Affirm burned through a cumulative $5.1 billion (18% of enterprise value) in FCF excluding acquisitions. See Figure 2. Figure 2: Affirm‚Äôs Cumulative Free Cash Flow: Fiscal 2020 ‚Äì Fiscal 2025 Per Figure 3, Affirm‚Äôs shares outstanding increased from 47 million in fiscal 2019 to 323 million in fiscal 2025. Whether through new share issuances or stock-based compensation, funding the business with new investors capital is not sustainable and not that different from a ponzi scheme. Figure 3: Affirm‚Äôs Shares Outstanding: Fiscal 2019 Through Fiscal 2025 In my recent report on Klarna (KLAR), one of Affirm‚Äôs key competitors, I pointed out how a growth-at-all-costs strategy can be successful in attracting users and growing GMV. In fact, Klarna used this approach to grow both users and GMV than traditional buy-now pay later peers Affirm and Afterpay (owned by Block, ticker XYZ). However, compared to PayPal (PYPL), the pure-play BNPL companies are miniscule. PayPal generated $1.7 trillion in total payment volume (TPV) in the TTM, with upwards of 434 million users/accounts. The scale and ubiquity of PayPal create strong competitive advantages, which ultimately manifest in higher margins and profitable operations. Figure 4: Comparing Users and GMV: BNPL Competitors: TTM * User data from end of 2023, when Afterpay last disclosed users**Annualized based on latest disclosed GMV of $8.24 billion in 3Q24 Payment plans or installment loans may look more attractive in an economic slowdown and as affordability of everyday items decreases. But such a slowdown doesn‚Äôt make one BNPL firm more attractive than another. Ultimately, each company is offering a largely undifferentiated product. Of buy now pay later (BNPL) users, PayPal (PYPL) is the clear top choice, with 56% of BNPL users having used PayPal, compared to 38% for Affirm. Additionally, merchants and retailers benefit from BNPL providers like Affirm and Klarna, which assume the credit risk of payment in return for a small fee paid by the merchant. Sure, Affirm gains users and GMV, but this structure leaves BNPL firms exposed to all the risk of payment. A recent study from LendingTree found that 41% of BNPL users say they paid late in the past year, which is up from 34% a year ago. Given these dynamics, it shouldn‚Äôt be surprising that the two pure-play BNPL companies are only competitors that don‚Äôt generate an ROIC and NOPAT margin above 0%. See Figure 5. Each of the other competitors, including PayPal (PYPL), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), American Express (AXP), Synchrony Financial (SYF), and others have more profitable business lines that can offset offering 0% interest loans and payment plans. Figure 5: Affirm Profitability Vs. Competitors: TTM Below, I use my reverse discounted cash flow (DCF) model to analyze the future cash flow expectations baked into Affirm‚Äôs stock price. I also present an additional DCF scenario to highlight the downside risk in the stock if Affirm fails to achieve the overly optimistic expectations in the current stock price. To justify its current price of $76/share, my model shows that Affirm would have to: In this scenario, Affirm‚Äôs revenue would reach $42.8 billion in fiscal 2035, or 13.3 times higher than the company‚Äôs fiscal 2025 revenue and 110% of Visa‚Äôs TTM revenue. In this scenario, Affirm‚Äôs NOPAT would reach $6.6 billion in fiscal 2035, or 1.3x PayPal‚Äôs TTM NOPAT and 2.8x Block‚Äôs TTM NOPAT. If I assume Affirm maintains a revenue to GMV rate of just under 9% (equal to fiscal 2025), then this scenario implies Affirm‚Äôs GMV in fiscal 2035 equals $487 billion compared to fiscal 2025 GMV of $37 billion. For context, Amazon‚Äôs (AMZN) 2024 (calendar year) U.S. GMV is estimated at $792 billion. In other words, Affirm would need to generate nearly two-thirds the GMV of Amazon to justify its current stock price. Also keep in mind, companies that grow revenue by 20%+ compounded annually for such a long period are also ‚Äúunbelievably rare‚Äù, making the expectations in Affirm‚Äôs valuation even more unrealistic. If I instead assume: the stock would be worth just $45/share today ‚Äì a 41% downside to the current price. In this scenario, Affirm‚Äôs revenue would reach $23.0 billion in fiscal 2035, or 7.1 times higher than the company‚Äôs fiscal 2025 revenue and 97% of Block‚Äôs TTM revenue. In this scenario, Affirm‚Äôs NOPAT would reach $3.6 billion in fiscal 2035, or nearly equal to Synchrony‚Äôs TTM NOPAT. If I again assume Affirm maintains a revenue to GMV rate of just under 9%, then this scenario implies Affirm‚Äôs GMV in fiscal 2035 equals just under $262 billion, up from $37 billion in fiscal 2025. Lastly, if I assume: the stock would be worth just $28/share today ‚Äì a 63% downside to the current price. This scenario still implies that Affirm generates $2.3 billion in NOPAT in fiscal 2035. Figure 6 compares Affirm‚Äôs implied future NOPAT in these scenarios to its historical NOPAT. For reference, I include PayPal and Block‚Äôs TTM NOPAT. Figure 6: Affirm‚Äôs Historical and Implied NOPAT: DCF Valuation Scenarios Each of the above scenarios assume Affirm grows revenue, NOPAT, and FCF without increasing working capital or fixed assets. This assumption is highly unlikely but allows me to create best-case scenarios that demonstrate the high level of expectations embedded in the current valuation. For reference, Affirm‚Äôs invested capital has grown 32% compounded annually since fiscal 2019. If I assume Affirm‚Äôs invested capital increases at a similar rate in the DCF scenarios above, the downside risk is even larger. Given that the performance required to justify its current price is overly optimistic, I dig deeper to see if Affirm is worth buying at any price. The answer is no. The company owes $32 million in total debt, has $728 million in outstanding employee stock option liabilities, $695 in minority interests, and has no excess cash. Affirm has an economic book value, or no growth value, of -$2/share. In other words I do not think equity investors will ever see $1 of economic earnings under normal operations, which means the stock would be worth $0 today.
--------------------------------------------------

Title: Mind Affirm‚Äôs GAAP‚Ä¶ It Only Misleads
URL: https://www.forbes.com/sites/greatspeculations/2025/10/31/mind-affirms-gaap-it-only-misleads/
Time Published: 2025-10-31T16:13:15Z
Full Content:
ByDavid Trainer, Contributor. Many companies rely on misleading ‚Äúadjusted‚Äù metrics to trick investors into thinking their business is stronger than it is in reality. The law allows companies to invent entirely new metrics or manipulate others to support a narrative that paints a more positive picture of the firm‚Äôs fundamentals. These companies often include disclaimers that caution against using non-GAAP metrics. Yet, the Street often builds its narratives on these ‚Äúadjusted‚Äù metrics. ‚ÄúAdjusted‚Äù metrics are not the only problem. GAAP earnings are often misleading. Unusual, one-time gains or losses frequently distort reported GAAP results and cloud investors‚Äô ability to understand the true economic performance of companies. To uncover real, Core Earnings, investors must dig into the details buried in the footnotes. This week‚Äôs Danger Zone pick is a perfect example of just how misleading reported earnings can be. The company recently reported positive GAAP earnings for the first time since its IPO. Meanwhile, Core Earnings remain highly negative. Further analysis reveals the company is burning through cash at an alarming pace. Only by leveraging superior fundamental data can investors get the truth about this company‚Äôs profitability, or lack thereof. I first put Affirm Holdings (AFRM) in the Danger Zone in October 2021, reiterated my bearish opinion most recently in October 2024, and named it a Zombie Stock in September 2022. GAAP profits may have investors re-thinking this company, so I believe now is a great time to remind investors how GAAP net income is misleading and show how AFRM remains overvalued. Affirm continues to grow its top-line at impressive levels. In fiscal 4Q25, revenue and gross merchandise volume (GMV) grew 33% and 43% year-over-year (YoY), respectively. For the full year of fiscal 2025, Affirm grew revenue and GMV 39% and 38% YoY, respectively. The company also successfully onboarded new customers and merchants, with active consumers and active merchants rising 23% and 24% YoY respectively in fiscal 2025. Perhaps most noteworthy ‚Äì at least to investors that don‚Äôt look beyond the surface numbers ‚Äì Affirm generated positive GAAP net income in fiscal 2025, a first since fiscal 2019. While Affirm reports positive top-line growth and GAAP net income, a deeper analysis, one that accounts for the footnotes and MD&A of company filings, reveals a different picture. Beyond profitability, the company‚Äôs stock price remains overvalued, and after rising 83% last year and 25% YTD, it carries large downside risk. More on that later. Affirm has not reported positive operating profit in any fiscal year of my company model, which dates back to fiscal 2019. The company has not generated positive Core Earnings since fiscal 2019 either. This fact begs the question, how does Affirm report positive GAAP net income if reported operating profit and calculated Core Earnings are negative? The answer is non-operating income or income unrelated to its core business. In fiscal 2025, Affirm reported an operating loss of -$87 million. However, the company reported $149 million in ‚ÄúOther Income, net‚Äù on its income statement. This other income is interest earned on money market funds included in cash and cash equivalents and restricted cash and interest earned on securities available for sale, among other items. In other words, Affirm has a lot of cash and securities from all the stock it has sold, and that‚Äôs where it gets the income to generate positive GAAP net income, not from its core operation. I leverage my firm‚Äôs Robo-Analyst AI Agent to calculate Core Earnings, a proven superior earnings measure that excludes these unusual gains/losses. In doing so, I find that Affirm‚Äôs Core Earnings remain negative at -$78 million in Fiscal 2025. Figure 1 provides a reconciliation from GAAP Net Income to Core Earnings. Figure 1: Affirm‚Äôs GAAP Net Income to Core Earnings Reconciliation: Fiscal 2025 In Affirm‚Äôs quest to take market share, it has adopted a growth-at-all-costs approach, even going so far as stating ‚Äúgrowth is always the answer‚Äù in the company‚Äôs fiscal 4Q24 shareholder letter. Total operating expenses, which include loss on loan purchase commitment, provision for credit losses, funding costs, processing and servicing, technology and data analytics, sales and marketing, general and administrative, and restructuring and other were 103% of revenue in fiscal 2025, which further explains why, as noted above, reported operating income is negative. When I first named Affirm a Zombie Stock in September 2022 it had enough cash on hand to sustain its cash burn for another 10 months. Affirm slowed its FCF burn from -$814 million in fiscal 2024 to -$425 million in fiscal 2025. The lower, yet still negative, FCF means Affirm no longer qualifies as a Zombie Stock because it has enough cash on hand to sustain its fiscal 2025 FCF burn for 61 months from the end of September 2025. Despite positive GAAP net income, Affirm continues to burn through cash each year. Affirm‚Äôs free cash flow (FCF) has been negative on an annual basis in every year since fiscal 2019. On a quarterly basis, FCF has been negative in 14 of the 15 quarters over the same time. In fiscal 2025, the company burned -$425 million in FCF excluding acquisitions. From fiscal 2020 through fiscal 2025, Affirm burned through a cumulative $5.1 billion (18% of enterprise value) in FCF excluding acquisitions. See Figure 2. Figure 2: Affirm‚Äôs Cumulative Free Cash Flow: Fiscal 2020 ‚Äì Fiscal 2025 Per Figure 3, Affirm‚Äôs shares outstanding increased from 47 million in fiscal 2019 to 323 million in fiscal 2025. Whether through new share issuances or stock-based compensation, funding the business with new investors capital is not sustainable and not that different from a ponzi scheme. Figure 3: Affirm‚Äôs Shares Outstanding: Fiscal 2019 Through Fiscal 2025 In my recent report on Klarna (KLAR), one of Affirm‚Äôs key competitors, I pointed out how a growth-at-all-costs strategy can be successful in attracting users and growing GMV. In fact, Klarna used this approach to grow both users and GMV than traditional buy-now pay later peers Affirm and Afterpay (owned by Block, ticker XYZ). However, compared to PayPal (PYPL), the pure-play BNPL companies are miniscule. PayPal generated $1.7 trillion in total payment volume (TPV) in the TTM, with upwards of 434 million users/accounts. The scale and ubiquity of PayPal create strong competitive advantages, which ultimately manifest in higher margins and profitable operations. Figure 4: Comparing Users and GMV: BNPL Competitors: TTM * User data from end of 2023, when Afterpay last disclosed users**Annualized based on latest disclosed GMV of $8.24 billion in 3Q24 Payment plans or installment loans may look more attractive in an economic slowdown and as affordability of everyday items decreases. But such a slowdown doesn‚Äôt make one BNPL firm more attractive than another. Ultimately, each company is offering a largely undifferentiated product. Of buy now pay later (BNPL) users, PayPal (PYPL) is the clear top choice, with 56% of BNPL users having used PayPal, compared to 38% for Affirm. Additionally, merchants and retailers benefit from BNPL providers like Affirm and Klarna, which assume the credit risk of payment in return for a small fee paid by the merchant. Sure, Affirm gains users and GMV, but this structure leaves BNPL firms exposed to all the risk of payment. A recent study from LendingTree found that 41% of BNPL users say they paid late in the past year, which is up from 34% a year ago. Given these dynamics, it shouldn‚Äôt be surprising that the two pure-play BNPL companies are only competitors that don‚Äôt generate an ROIC and NOPAT margin above 0%. See Figure 5. Each of the other competitors, including PayPal (PYPL), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), American Express (AXP), Synchrony Financial (SYF), and others have more profitable business lines that can offset offering 0% interest loans and payment plans. Figure 5: Affirm Profitability Vs. Competitors: TTM Below, I use my reverse discounted cash flow (DCF) model to analyze the future cash flow expectations baked into Affirm‚Äôs stock price. I also present an additional DCF scenario to highlight the downside risk in the stock if Affirm fails to achieve the overly optimistic expectations in the current stock price. To justify its current price of $76/share, my model shows that Affirm would have to: In this scenario, Affirm‚Äôs revenue would reach $42.8 billion in fiscal 2035, or 13.3 times higher than the company‚Äôs fiscal 2025 revenue and 110% of Visa‚Äôs TTM revenue. In this scenario, Affirm‚Äôs NOPAT would reach $6.6 billion in fiscal 2035, or 1.3x PayPal‚Äôs TTM NOPAT and 2.8x Block‚Äôs TTM NOPAT. If I assume Affirm maintains a revenue to GMV rate of just under 9% (equal to fiscal 2025), then this scenario implies Affirm‚Äôs GMV in fiscal 2035 equals $487 billion compared to fiscal 2025 GMV of $37 billion. For context, Amazon‚Äôs (AMZN) 2024 (calendar year) U.S. GMV is estimated at $792 billion. In other words, Affirm would need to generate nearly two-thirds the GMV of Amazon to justify its current stock price. Also keep in mind, companies that grow revenue by 20%+ compounded annually for such a long period are also ‚Äúunbelievably rare‚Äù, making the expectations in Affirm‚Äôs valuation even more unrealistic. If I instead assume: the stock would be worth just $45/share today ‚Äì a 41% downside to the current price. In this scenario, Affirm‚Äôs revenue would reach $23.0 billion in fiscal 2035, or 7.1 times higher than the company‚Äôs fiscal 2025 revenue and 97% of Block‚Äôs TTM revenue. In this scenario, Affirm‚Äôs NOPAT would reach $3.6 billion in fiscal 2035, or nearly equal to Synchrony‚Äôs TTM NOPAT. If I again assume Affirm maintains a revenue to GMV rate of just under 9%, then this scenario implies Affirm‚Äôs GMV in fiscal 2035 equals just under $262 billion, up from $37 billion in fiscal 2025. Lastly, if I assume: the stock would be worth just $28/share today ‚Äì a 63% downside to the current price. This scenario still implies that Affirm generates $2.3 billion in NOPAT in fiscal 2035. Figure 6 compares Affirm‚Äôs implied future NOPAT in these scenarios to its historical NOPAT. For reference, I include PayPal and Block‚Äôs TTM NOPAT. Figure 6: Affirm‚Äôs Historical and Implied NOPAT: DCF Valuation Scenarios Each of the above scenarios assume Affirm grows revenue, NOPAT, and FCF without increasing working capital or fixed assets. This assumption is highly unlikely but allows me to create best-case scenarios that demonstrate the high level of expectations embedded in the current valuation. For reference, Affirm‚Äôs invested capital has grown 32% compounded annually since fiscal 2019. If I assume Affirm‚Äôs invested capital increases at a similar rate in the DCF scenarios above, the downside risk is even larger. Given that the performance required to justify its current price is overly optimistic, I dig deeper to see if Affirm is worth buying at any price. The answer is no. The company owes $32 million in total debt, has $728 million in outstanding employee stock option liabilities, $695 in minority interests, and has no excess cash. Affirm has an economic book value, or no growth value, of -$2/share. In other words I do not think equity investors will ever see $1 of economic earnings under normal operations, which means the stock would be worth $0 today.

Title: Roku Stock Spikes On Big Earnings Beat For Streaming Video Platform

Title: US stock market rising sharply today: Why is Dow Jones, S&P 500, Nasdaq climbing? Amazon, Netflix, Tesla, and Palantir boost Wall Street confidence
URL: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/us/us-stock-market-rising-sharply-today-why-is-dow-jones-sp-500-nasdaq-climbing-amazon-netflix-tesla-and-palantir-boost-wall-street-confidence/articleshow/124998052.cms
Time Published: 2025-10-31T15:18:58Z
Full Content:
US stock market is on fire today. The S&P 500 is up 0.6%, the Nasdaq 1.2%, and the Dow 99 points higher. Amazon stock exploded 11% after AWS revenue soared 20% to $33 billion. Netflix, Tesla, and Palantir all jumped as Wall Street cheered fresh AI momentum. A surprise Trump‚ÄìXi trade truce and tariff cuts added fuel. By month‚Äôs end, the S&P 500 has climbed 2%, the Nasdaq 5%, and the Dow 2%, sealing October as one of the market‚Äôs brightest months of 2025. (Catch all the US News, UK News, Canada News, International Breaking News Events, and Latest News Updates on The Economic Times.) Download The Economic Times News App to get Daily International News Updates. Title: Netflix Stock Is Set for a 10-for-1 Split. What You Need To Know
URL: https://www.investopedia.com/netflix-stock-is-set-for-10-for-1-split-what-you-need-to-know-11840971
Time Published: 2025-10-31T14:52:09Z
Full Content:
Netflix said it plans to undergo a 10-for-1 stock split, in a move that could make its stock more accessible to a wider range of investors. The split, which is set to take place after the closing bell on Friday, Nov. 14, means shareholders will receive nine new Netflix (NFLX) shares for every one they owned heading into the split. Their overall stake in the company won‚Äôt change because of it, but each share will subsequently be worth about 10% of its price before the split took effect. Trading at the split-adjusted price is scheduled to begin when the market opens on Monday, Nov. 17. Netflix said the change is meant to ‚Äúreset the market price of the Company's common stock to a range that will be more accessible to employees who participate in the Company's stock option program.‚Äù That could also make it more attractive to investors outside the company who may have shied away from the stock at its recent levels after a run-up this year. Shares of Netflix were up over 3% around $1,123 in recent trading, bringing their year-to-date gains to about 26%, outpacing the broader S&P 500's roughly 16% over the same period. Netflix‚Äôs 10-for-1 stock split follows similar moves by large-cap tech companies looking to make their shares more affordable to employees and retail investors. Stock splits can help boost liquidity and make trading easier for buyers and sellers. Though Netflix shares took a hit earlier this month after the company's third-quarter earnings missed analysts' estimates due to a one-time tax expense in Brazil, it's been a strong year for the streaming giant's stock, which has benefited from a well-received slate of content and expectations of continued growth, along with the perception that it's relatively insulated from shifting tariff policies. The decision to undergo a split, typically considered a positive signal by investors, could also point to confidence in further gains ahead for Netflix. By contrast, reverse stock splits‚Äîwhich consolidate shares to raise the price of each individual share‚Äîare often taken as a sign of concern about a marked decline in the price of a stock.
--------------------------------------------------
